name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the statement by the President of the European Commission on the State of the Union (2017/2709 (RSP)). Before giving the floor to President Juncker, whom I greet and thank together with all the members of the European Commission for being here today, I would like to give you some information concerning the course of today's debate. Yesterday, I told you that I consider the European Parliament to be the beating heart of the European Union, the place where the debate on the future of the Union will take place; I recalled the importance of the speech that President Juncker will give today and I invited all the Heads of State to come back and speak in this House. I believe that we too will have an open debate on the future of the Union, because we are convinced that this Parliament can truly make a decisive contribution to the growth of the Union and its improvement, to change the things that need to be changed, but also to work together with other institutions, to carry out all the necessary reforms, the institutional ones, those concerning action against terrorism, against illegal immigration and against the exploitation of human beings, but also to work on the creation of new jobs. From what we have read, there is a strong commitment from the Commission to support industrial policy, which the European Parliament has emphasized. We will work alongside the Commission to resolve all problems affecting citizens. That is why today we will listen with great attention to President Juncker's proposals: there will be an in-depth debate, at the end of which President Juncker will formulate his observations and, subsequently, the presidents of the groups will sum up this very important morning. So, just after President Juncker has intervened, the presidents of the groups will intervene, followed by the debate, the reply from President Juncker and the conclusions of the group presidents. I recommend that you respect the times allotted to you, because this will allow everyone to express themselves and then to President Juncker to give a complete and detailed response to the comments that will be made to him by the representatives who sit in this Parliament.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, when I stood before you this time last year I had a somewhat easier speech to give. It was plain for all to see that our Union was not in a good state. Europe was battered and bruised by a year that had shaken our very foundation. We only had two choices: either come together around a positive European agenda, or each retreat into our own corners. Faced with this choice, I argued for unity. I proposed a positive agenda to help create, as I said last year, a Europe that protects, a Europe that empowers, a Europe that defends. Over the past 12 months, this Parliament has helped bring this agenda to life. We continue to make progress with each passing day. Just last night you worked to find an agreement on a trade defense instrument and on doubling our European investment capacity, and you succeeded. Thank you for that. I also want to thank the 27 leaders of our Member States. Days after my speech last year, they welcomed my agenda at their summit in Bratislava. In doing so, they thing unity. They chose to rally around our common ground. Together, we showed that Europe can deliver for its citizens when and where it matters. Ever since, we have been slowly, but surely, gathering momentum. It helped that the economic outlook swung in our favor. We are now in the fifth year of an economic recovery that really reaches each and every single Member State. Growth in the European Union has outstripped that of the United States over the last two years. It now stands above 2% for the Union as a whole and at 2.2% for the monetary area. Unemployment is at a nine-year low. Almost eight million jobs have been created during this mandate so far. With 235 million people in work, more people are in employment in the European Union than ever before. The Commission cannot take the credit for this alone, though I am sure that had eight million jobs been lost we would have taken the blame. But Europe's institutions played their part in helping the wind change. We can take credit for our European investment plan which has triggered EUR 225 billion worth of investment so far. It has granted loans to over 450,000 small firms and more than 270 infrastructure projects. We can take credit for the fact that thanks to determined action, European banks once again have the capital fire power to lend to companies so that they can grow and create jobs. And we can take credit for having brought public deficits down from 6.6% to 1.6%. This is thanks to an intelligent application of the Stability and Growth Pact. We ask for fiscal discipline but are careful not to kill growth. This is in fact working very well across the Union, despite some criticism. Ten years since the crisis struck, Europe's economy is finally bouncing back and with it, our confidence. Our 27 leaders, this Parliament and the Commission are putting ‘Europe’ back into our Union, and together we are putting ‘Union’ back into our Union. In the last year we saw all 27 leaders walk up to the Capitoline Hill in Rome, one by one, to renew their vows to each other and to our Union. All of this leads me to believe the wind is back in Europe's sails. We now have a window of opportunity, but it will not stay open forever. Let us make the most of the momentum, catch the wind in our sails. For this, we must do two things. First, we should stay the course set out last year. We still have 16 months in which real progress can be made by Parliament, Council and Commission. We must use this time to finish what we started in Bratislava and deliver on our own positive agenda. Secondly, we should chart the direction for the future. As Mark Twain wrote, and I quote: ‘years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do’. Now is the time to build a more united, a stronger, and a more democratic Europe for 2025. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we look to the future, we do not cannot allow ourselves to be diverted from our course. Together, we have set ourselves the goal of completing an Energy Union, a Security Union, a Capital Markets Union, a Banking Union and a Digital Single Market. Together, we have come a long way. As advised by your Parliament, the Commission has already presented 80% of the proposals promised at the start of the mandate. We must now work together to ensure that these proposals become legislative acts and that these acts materialize in practice. As always, some concessions will have to be made. The proposals presented by the Commission to reform our common asylum system or to establish new and stronger rules on the posting of workers are - I know - controversial subjects. We will get good results if everyone builds their part of the bridge so that the positions can come together. I would like to say that the Commission will be open to compromise, as long as the end result is good for the Union and fair for all its Member States. We are now ready to submit the remaining 20% ​​of initiatives by May 2018. This morning, I addressed the President of the Parliament and the Estonian Prime Minister - whose strong action in the European field I would like to salute here - a letter of intent outlining the priorities for the coming year. I will not and cannot enumerate all these proposals for you, but let me mention five that are particularly important. First, I would like us to strengthen our European trade program. Europe is open to trade, yes, but there has to be reciprocity. We will have to get as much as we give. Trade is not an abstract concept. Trade is jobs, new opportunities for European companies, large or small. Every billion more exports represents 14,000 additional jobs in Europe. Trade is the export of our social and environmental standards and of our data protection or food safety standards. Europe has always been an attractive economic space, but since last year I have seen our partners from all over the world flock to our doorstep to conclude trade deals with us. With the help of your Parliament, we have just concluded a trade agreement with Canada which will apply on a provisional basis from next week. We have reached a political agreement with Japan on a future economic partnership, and by the end of the year we have a good chance of doing the same with Mexico and the countries of South America. Today, we propose to open trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. I would like all these agreements to be finalized by the end of this mandate and I would like them to be negotiated with the greatest transparency. Openness to trade must go hand in hand with increased transparency in our decision-making processes. The European Parliament will have the final say on all trade agreements and therefore its members, as well as national and regional parliaments, must be kept fully informed from day one of negotiations. The Commission will ensure this. From now on, the Commission will publish the full draft negotiating mandates that it presents to the Council. Citizens have the right to know what the Commission is proposing. No more lack of transparency, no more rumors and lawsuits that the Commission is constantly subject to. I invite the Council to do the same. (Applause) I would like to say once and for all that we are not naïve supporters of free trade. Europe must always defend its strategic interests. This is the reason why we are now proposing a new European Union framework for investment screening, Investment Screening, in English. If a foreign public company wants to acquire a strategic European port, part of our energy infrastructure or one of our companies in the field of defense technologies, this can only be done in transparency, through in-depth examination and debate. It is our political responsibility to know what is going on at home so that we can, if necessary, protect our collective security. (Applause) Secondly, the Commission would like to make our industry stronger and more competitive. This is particularly true of our industrial base and the 32 million workers who form its backbone. They're the ones who make the first-class products - our cars, for example - to which we owe our lead over others. I am proud of our auto industry, but I am shocked when customers and consumers are knowingly and intentionally deceived. (Applause) I call on the auto industry to make amends and put things right. Instead of trying to deceive and mislead, manufacturers should invest in the clean cars of tomorrow. Ladies and gentlemen, today we are presenting a new industrial strategy for Europe, which will allow our industry to remain or become number one in innovation, digitization and decarbonization. Thirdly, I would like Europe to be at the forefront of the fight against climate change. Last year, we set global climate standards with the ratification of the Paris Agreement, right here in this House. Faced with the weakening of the ambitions shown by the United States, Europe must ensure that it large the planet and the indivisible part of all mankind. The Commission will shortly present a proposal to reduce carbon emissions in the transport sector. Fourth, I would like us to better protect Europeans in the digital age. Over the past few years, we have made notable progress in securing the internet. New rules proposed by the Commission will protect our intellectual property rights, our cultural diversity and our personal data. We have stepped up the fight against terrorist propaganda and online radicalization. But Europe remains ill-equipped to deal with cyber attacks. Cyber ​​attacks are sometimes more dangerous for the stability of democracies and economies than guns and tanks. In the last year alone, we have recorded over 4,000 ransomware attacks and 80% of European businesses have experienced at least one cybersecurity incident. Cyber ​​attacks know no borders. They spare no one. This is why the Commission is now proposing new tools and in particular a European Cybersecurity Agency to better defend ourselves against these attacks. Fifth, migration must remain on our radar. Although the issues revolving around migration have often sparked debate and controversy, we have managed to make real progress on many fronts. Today we are protecting our external borders more effectively. More than 1,700 officers from the new European Border and Coast Guard now support the 100,000 national border guards of the Member States and patrol in particular Greece, Italy, Bulgaria and Spain. We have common borders, but the Member States which are on the front line due to their geographical location should not be solely responsible for their protection. Common borders and common protections must go together. We have succeeded in stemming the flow of irregular migrants, a source of great concern in many countries. We have reduced the number of irregular arrivals in the Eastern Mediterranean by 97% thanks to our agreement with Turkey. And, this summer, we were able to better control the central Mediterranean route. Arrivals there fell 81% in August compared to the same month last year. In this way, we have significantly reduced the number of lives lost in the Mediterranean. I cannot speak of migration without paying tribute to Italy for its perseverance and generosity. (Applause) During the summer months, the Commission worked in harmony with the Italian Prime Minister, my friend Paolo Gentiloni, and his government. We have done it and we will continue to do so because, in the Mediterranean, Italy saves the honor of Europe. We must also urgently improve the living conditions of refugees in Libya. I am appalled by the inhumane conditions that prevail in the detention centers or reception centers. Here, Europe has a responsibility but a collective responsibility, and the Commission will act in concert with the United Nations to put an end to this scandalous situation which cannot last. (Applause) Although it saddens me that not all of our Member States show the same level of solidarity, Europe, taken as a whole, has continued to show solidarity. In the past year alone, our Member States have granted asylum to over 720,000 refugees or provided for their resettlement. This is three times as many as Australia, Canada and the United States taken together. Europe, contrary to what is said, is not a fortress and should never be. Europe is and will remain the continent of solidarity where we must be able to find refuge those who are prosecuted for unacceptable reasons. (Applause) I am particularly proud of the young Europeans who volunteer to give language courses to Syrian refugees or of all these young people who, by the thousands, have put themselves at the service of our new European Solidarity Corps. These young people give life and color to European solidarity. (Applause) But we have to redouble our efforts. At the end of the month, the Commission will present a new set of proposals focusing on returns, solidarity with Africa and opening channels for legal migration. Regarding returns in particular, I would like to repeat that people who are not entitled to stay in Europe must return to their country of origin. While only 36% of irregular migrants are returned, it is evident that we must considerably step up our effort and action in this area. Only in this way will Europe be able to show solidarity with refugees who are in real need of protection. (Applause) Solidarity cannot be an exclusively intra-European affair. It is also about building greater solidarity with Africa. Africa, cradle of humanity, noble continent, young continent. Our Trust Fund for Africa, with a budget of 2.7 billion euros, is opening up job opportunities across the African continent. But, while the EU budget has provided the bulk of the funding, the contribution of all our Member States combined is only 150 million euros. The fund is now reaching its limits. We know, or should know, the risks of a funding shortage. In 2015, many migrants wanted to join Europe when and because the UN's World Food Program funds ran out. I therefore invite the Member States to join in speak up and ensure that the Africa Trust Fund does not suffer the same fate. The risk is great. (Applause) We will also work to open up avenues for legal migration. Irregular migration will only end when migrants have no option but to embark on a perilous journey. (Applause) We are about to resettle 22,000 refugees from Turkey, Jordan or Lebanon, and I join in the appeal by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to resettle another 40,000 refugees from from Libya and neighboring countries. Otherwise, Europe is an aging continent, all the more reason to endow it with a legal migration system, which is an essential necessity. This is the reason why the Commission has made proposals to facilitate migrants' access to the EU Blue Card and I thank Parliament for its support in this regard. Sehr verehrter Herr President, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren Abgeordnete! Ich habe nur einige wenige der Initiativen angesprochen, die wir in den kommenden 16 Monaten zum Abschluss bringen wollen und zum Abschluss bringen müssen. Doch dies allein reicht nicht aus, wenn wir die Herzen, ja, auch die Köpfe der Europäer zurückgewinnen wollen. Jetzt ist es an der Zeit, die Strecke in Richtung Zukunft abzustecken. Im März hat die Kommission ihr Weißbuch zur Zukunft Europas mit fünf Szenarien vorgelegt, wie Europa im Jahr 2025 aussehen könnte. Diese Szenarien wurden diskutiert - manchmal oberflächlich, sehr oft heftig -, sie wurden analysiert und mitunter teilweise zerrissen. Das ist auch gut so, denn genau dafür waren sie gedacht. Ich wollte einen Prozess in Gang bringen, in dem die Europäer selbst über ihren Weg in die Zukunft bestimmen. Die Zukunft Europas kann man nicht - gewissermaßen von oben herab –diktieren. Solche Entscheidungen müssen auf einer demokratischen Debatte und letztlich auf breitem Konsens fußen. Dieses Haus hat aktive Beiträge zu dieser Debatte geleistet, wofür ich mich besonders bei den Berichterstattern bedanken möchte. Auch möchte ich mich bei den Kollegen bedanken, die an den mehr als 2 000 öffentlichen Konsultationsveranstaltungen teilgenommen haben, welche die Kommission seit März überall in Europa organize hat. Jetzt ist es an der Zeit, die ersten Schlussfolgerungen aus dieser Debatte zu ziehen. Es ist an der Zeit, den nächsten Schritt zu machen: vom Nachdenken zum Handeln, von der Debatte zur Entscheidung. Heute möchte ich Ihnen meine Sicht der Dinge vorstellen: mein - wenn Sie so wollen - persönliches „Szenario 6“. Dieses Szenario beruht auf jahrzehntelangen persönlichen Erfahrungen. Mein ganzes Leben lang habe ich das europäische Projekt gelebt, dafür gekämpft und dafür gearbeitet. Ich habe gute Zeiten gesehen, aber auch schlechte Zeiten erlebt. Ich habe an vielen Seiten des Verhandlungstisches gesessen - als Minister, als Premierminister, als Präsident der Euro-Gruppe und nun als Kommissionspäsident. Ich war in Maastricht, Amsterdam, Nizza und Lissabon dabei, als sich unsere Union weiterentwickelt und erweitert hat. Ich habe stets für Europa gekämpft, habe manchmal auch an Europa gelitten und bin an Europa verzweifelt. Ich bin mit der Europäischen Union durch dick und dünn gegangen - und nie habe ich meine Liebe zu Europa verloren. Es gibt - wie wir wissen - keine Liebe ohne Enttäuschungen, jedenfalls sehr selten. Ja, Liebe zu Europa, weil Europa und die Europäische Union in dieser zerklüfteten Welt Einmaliges erreicht hat: Frieden nach innen und Frieden nach außen. Wohlstand, wenn auch nicht für alle, so doch für viele. Daran sollten wir 2018 aus Anlass des Europäischen Jahres des Kulturerbes denken. 2018 muss ein Fest der kulturellen Vielfalt werden. (Beifall) Die Wertegebundenheit Europas gibt uns ein sicheres Zuhause. Für mich ist Europa mehr als Binnenmarkt, Geld, Währung, Euro. Es geht immer vorrangig um Werte. Mein Szenario 6 geht deshalb von drei Grundprinzipien aus - drei unverrückbaren Grundprinzipien: Freiheit, Gleichberechtigung, Rechtsstaatlichkeit. Europa ist zunächst eine Union der Freiheit. Damit meine ich die Freiheit von Unterdrückung und Diktatur - Phänomene, die unser Kontinent, vor Allem die Länder Mittel- und Osteuropas, leider nur allzu gut kennt. Ich meine die Freiheit, die eigene Meinung zu sagen, als Bürger und als Journalist…. (Beifall) - eine Freiheit, die wir allzu oft als Selbstverständlichkeit empfinden. Auf diesen Freiheitswerten wurde unsere Union aufgebaut. Doch Freiheit fällt nicht vom Himmel. Wir müssen für sie kämpfen. In Europa und in der Welt. (Beifall) Europa muss eine Union der Gleichberechtigung und der Gleichberechtigten sein. Das bedeutet Gleichberechtigung ihrer Mitglieder - ob groß oder klein, ob im Osten oder im Westen, ob im Norden oder im Süden. Europa reicht von Vigo bis Varna, von Spanien bis nach Bulgarien. (Beifall) Europa muss mit beiden Lungenflügeln atmen, mit dem östlichen und dem westlichen. Ansonsten gerät unser Kontinent in Atemnot. In einer Union der Gleichen kann es keine Bürger zweiter Klasse geben. Es ist nicht hinnehmbar, dass auch 2017 noch Kinder an Krankheiten sterben, die in Europa schon längst ausgerottet sein müssten. (Beifall) Kinder in Rumänien oder Italien sollten gleichermaßen Zugang zu Masernimpfstoffen haben wie Kinder in anderen Ländern Europas. Ohne Wenn und Aber. (Beifall) Deshalb arbeiten wir mit allen Mitgliedstaaten zusammen, um ihre nationalen Impfmaßnahmen zu unterstützen. Vermeidbare Todesfälle darf es in Europa nicht geben. (Beifall) In einer Union der Gleichen kann es keine Arbeitnehmer zweiter Klasse geben. Menschen, die die gleiche Arbeit am gleichen Ort verrichten, sollen das gleiche Gehalt bekommen. (Beifall) Diesem Ziel dienen die Kommissionsvorschläge zur Entsendung von Arbeitskräften. Wir sollten sicherstellen, dass alle EU-Vorschriften zur Mobilität von Arbeitskräften auf gerechte, einfache und wirksame Art und Weise durchgesetzt werden - und zwar mit Hilfe einer neuen europäischen Aufsichts- und Umsetzungsbehörde. Es ist absurd, dass eine Bankenaufsichtsbehörde darüber wacht, ob Bankenstandards eingehalten werden, dass es aber keine gemeinsame Arbeitsmarktbehörde gibt, die für Fairness innerhalb des Binnenmarkts sorgt. Wir werden diese Behörde schaffen. (Beifall) In einer Union der Gleichen kann es keine Verbraucher zweiter Klasse geben. Ich kann nicht akzeptieren, dass den Menschen in manchen Teilen Europas, vornehmlich in Mittel- und Osteuropa, qualitativ schlechtere Lebensmittel verkauft werden als in anderen, obwohl Verpackung und Markenkennzeichnung identisch sind. (Beifall) Slowaken haben nicht weniger Fisch in Fischstäbchen verdient, Ungarn nicht weniger Fleisch in Fleischgerichten oder Tschechen weniger Kakao in der Schokolade. Das EU-Recht verbietet solche Praktiken schon jetzt. Nun müssen wir die nationalen Behörden mit umfassenden Befugnissen ausstatten, sodass diese flächendeckend gegen diese illegalen Praktiken vorgehen können. (Beifall) Drittens: In Europa gilt die Macht des Rechts, und die Macht des Rechts ist an die Stelle des Rechts des Stärkeren getreten. Das bedeutet, dass Recht und Gesetz durch eine unabhängige Justiz gewahrt werden. Teil einer Union zu sein, die auf Rechtsstaatlichkeit beruht, heißt auch, rechtskräftige Urteile zu akzeptieren und zu respektieren. (Beifall) Unsere Mitgliedstaaten haben dem Europäischen Gerichtshof die Befugnis übertragen, in letzter Instanz zu entscheiden. Die Urteile des Europäischen Gerichtshofs sind in allen Fällen zu respektieren. Sie nicht zu respektieren oder die Unabhängigkeit nationaler Gerichte zu untergraben, heißt, Bürgerinnen und Bürger ihrer Grundrechte zu berauben. Rechtsstaatlichkeit ist in der Europäischen Union keine Option. Sie ist Pflicht. Unsere Union ist kein Staat, aber sie muss ein Rechtsstaat sein. (Beifall) Diese drei Grundsätze - Freiheit, Gleichberechtigung und Rechtsstaatlichkeit - müssen das Fundament bleiben, auf dem wir eine stärkere und demokratischere Union aufbauen. Wenn wir über diese Zukunft reden, dann sagt mir meine Erfahrung, dass neue Verträge und neue Institutionen für die Menschen nicht die Antwort sind, nach der sie suchen. Sie sind lediglich Mittel zum Zweck, nicht mehr und nicht weniger. Für uns hier in Straßburg oder in Brüssel haben sie Bedeutung. Andernorts bedeuten sie nicht viel. Ich bin an institutional Reformen nur interessiert, wenn sie zu mehr Effizienz der Europäischen Union führen. Statt Zuflucht in künftigen Vertragsänderungen - die irgendwann kommen müssen - zu suchen, müssen wir uns zunächst von der Vorstellung verabschieden, dass einige verlieren müssen, damit andere gewinnen können. In der Demokratie geht es um Kompromiss. Und die richtigen Kompromisse machen auf Dauer alle zu Gewinnern. In der Europäischen Union sind Kompromisse weder negativ noch obszön, Sondern die Kunst, Gegensätze zu überbrücken und zueinander zu finden. Wer nicht kompromissfähig ist, ist weder demokratiefähig noch europatauglich. (Beifall) Um ihre Einheit zu stärken, muss die Europäische Union auch inklusiver werden. Wenn wir den Schutz unserer Außengrenzen zu Recht verstärken und noch mehr verstärken wollen, dann müssen wir Rumänien und Bulgarien unverzüglich den Schengen-Raum öffnen. (Starker Beifall) Im Übrigen sollten wir auch Kroatien die volle Schengen-Mitgliedschaft ermöglichen, sobald alle Kriterien erfüllt sind. Wenn wir wollen, dass der Euro unseren Kontinent mehr eint als spaltet, dann sollte er mehr sein als die Währung einiger ausgewählter Länder. Der Euro ist dazu bestimmt, die einheitliche Währung der Europäischen Union als Ganzes zu sein. Alle außer zwei Mitgliedstaaten sind verpflichtet und berechtigt, dem Euroraum beizutreten, sobald sie die Bedingungen erfüllen. Doch die Mitgliedstaaten, die dem Euroraum beitreten möchten, müssen dies auch tun können. Deshalb schlage ich die Schaffung eines Euro-Vorbeitrittsinstrumentes vor, das ihnen technische, manchmal auch finanzielle Heranführungshilfen bietet. (Beifall) Wenn wir wollen, dass Banken überall auf unserem Kontinent nach denselben Regeln und unter derselben Aufsicht arbeiten, dann sollten wir alle Mitgliedstaaten ermutigen, der Bankenunion beizutreten. Dazu müssen wir die verbleibenden Risiken in den Bankensystemen mancher Mitgliedstaaten verringern. Die Bankenunion funktioniert nur, wenn die Begrenzung und das Teilen von Risiken Hand in Hand gehen. Um dies tun zu können - das weiß jeder -, müssen Vorbedingungen erfüllt werden, so wie es die Kommission im November 2015 vorgeschlagen hat. Eine gemeinsame Einlagensicherung kann es erst dann geben, wenn jeder seine nationalen Hausaufgaben gemacht haben wird. Wenn wir der sozialen Fragmentierung und dem Sozialdumping in Europa ein Ende setzen wollen, sollten die Mitgliedstaaten sich so schnell wie möglich, spätestens beim Göteborg-Gipfel im November, auf die europäische Säule sozialer Rechte einigen. Nationale Sozialsysteme werden noch lange unterschiedlich und eigenständig bleiben. Doch wir sollten uns zumindest auf eine Europäische Union der Sozialstandards verständigen, in denen es einen Konsens darüber gibt, was in unserem Binnenmarkt sozial fair und was in unserem Binnenmarkt sozial unfair ist. (Beifall) Ich bleibe davon überzeugt: Damit Europa gelingt, darf es den Arbeitnehmern nicht die kalte Schulter zeigen. Wenn wir mehr Stabilität in unserer Nachbarschaft wollen, müssen wir auch eine glaubhafte Erweiterungsperspektive für den westlichen Balkan aufrechterhalten. (Beifall) Während dieses Kommissions- und Parlamentsmandats wird es keine neuen Mitglieder geben, weil die Beitrittsbedingungen nicht erfüllt werden können. Doch die Europäische Union wird in den darauffolgenden Jahren mehr als 27 Mitglieder zählen. Bei allen Beitrittsländern haben Rechtsstaatlichkeit, Justiz und Grundwerte oberste Verhandlungspriorität. Das schließt eine EU- Mitgliedschaft der Türkei in absehbarer Zeit aus. (Beifall) Die Türkei entfernt sich seit geraumer Zeit mit Riesenschritten von der Europäischen Union. Journalisten gehören in Redaktionsstuben, in denen freie Meinungsäußerung gilt. Sie gehören nicht ins Gefängnis. (Beifall) Ich appelliere heute an die Verantwortlichen in der Türkei: Lassen Sie unsere Journalisten frei, und nicht nur unsere! Hören Sie auf, unsere Mitgliedstaaten, Staats-und Regierungschefs als Faschisten und Nazis zu beschimpfen! (Beifall) Europa ist ein Kontinent reifer Demokratien. Wer aber bewusst beleidigt, verbaut sich Wege zu ihnen. Manchmal habe ich den Eindruck, einige in der Türkei möchten sich bewusst Wege verbauen, um dann später die Europäische Union für das eventuelle Scheitern der Beitrittsgespräche haftbar machen zu können. Von unserer Seite wird immer eine Hand ausgestreckt bleiben für das große türkische Volk und all diejenigen, die bereit sind, auf der Grundlage unserer Werte mit ihr zusammenzuarbeiten. (Beifall) Meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! Ich hätte gerne, dass unsere Union stärker wird, und deshalb müssen wir auch den Binnenmarkt stärken. Ich möchte, dass wir in wichtigen Binnenmarktfragen öfter und einfacher im Rat mit qualifizierter Mehrheit entscheiden unter gleichberechtigter Mitwirkung des Europäischen Parlaments. Dazu brauchen wir keine Vertragsänderungen. Die derzeitigen Verträge enthalten sogenannte „Brückenklauseln“, die es ermöglichen, in bestimmten Fällen - vorausgesetzt, der Europäische Rat entscheidet dies einstimmig - mit qualifizierter Mehrheit, statt einstimmig zu entsiden. Ich bin dafür, bei Beschlüssen über die gemeinsame konsolidierte Körperschaftsteuer-Bemessungsgrundlage, über die Mehrwertsteuer, über eine faire Besteuerung der Digitalwirtschaft und über die Finanztransaktionssteuer diezhrithitizfssier qualifying. (Beifall) Europa muss nämlich schneller und effizienter entscheiden können. Dies gilt auch in dem Bereich, der darauf abstellt, die Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion handlungsfähiger zu machen. Der Euro-Raum ist heute widerstandsfähiger als noch vor Jahren. So haben wir unter anderem den Europäischen Stabilitätsmechanismus (ESM) geschaffen. Ich denke, der ESM sollte nun schrittweise zu einem Europäischen Währungsfonds ausgebaut werden, der Allerdings fest im Regel- und Kompetenzwerk der Europäischen Union verankert sein muss. Die Kommission wird hierzu im Dezember konkrete Vorschläge vorlegen. Wir brauchen einen Europäischen Wirtschafts- und Finanzminister, einen europäischen Minister, der positive Strukturreformen in unseren Mitgliedstaaten fördert und unterstützt. Er wird dabei auf der Arbeit aufbauen können, die die Kommission seit 2015 mit unserer Sondereinheit zur Unterstützung von Strukturreformen leistet. Der Europäische Wirtschafts- und Finanzminister soll alle Finanzierungsinstrumente der EU koordinieren, die in Bewegung gebracht werden müssen, wenn ein Mitgliedstaat von einer Rezession oder einer Fundamentalkrise betroffen wird. Ich plädiere nicht für die Schaffung eines neuen Amtes. Ich plädiere aus Effizienzgründen dafür, dass der für Wirtschaft und Finanzen zuständige EU-Kommissar - idealerweise ein Vizepräsident der Europäischen Kommission - mit dieser Aufgabe betraut und Vorsitzender der Eurogruppe wird. (Beifall) Der Europäische Wirtschafts- und Finanzminister muss selbstverständlich dem Europäischen Parlament gegenüber Rechenschaft ablegen. Wir brauchen keine Parallelstrukturen. Wir benötigen deshalb keinen separaten Euro-Haushalt, probem eine starke Eurozonen-Budgetlinie im Rahmen unseres EU-Haushalts. (Beifall) Ich kann auch der Idee eines gesonderten Europa-Parlaments und eines gesonderten Euro-Parlaments wenig Reiz abgewinnen. Das Parlament des Euroraums ist dieses Europäische Parlament. (Starker Beifall) Die Europäische Union muss auch stärker bei der gemeinsamen Terrorbekämpfung werden. In den letzten drei Jahren sind wir zwar auch diesbezüglich ein großes Stück weitergekommen. Doch im Falle grenzübergreifender terroristischer Bedrohungen reagieren wir nicht schnell genug. Ich plädiere deshalb für die Schaffung einer europäischen Aufklärungseinheit, die sicherstellt, dass Daten über Terroristen und Auslandskämpfer automatisch zwischen unseren Nachrichten- und Polizeidiensten ausgetauscht werden. (Beifall) Aus meiner Sicht spricht auch vieles dafür, die neu geschaffene Europäische Staatsanwaltschaft mit der Verfolgung von grenzübergreifenden terroristischen Straftaten zu betrauen. Die Europäische Union muss sich auch um mehr Gewicht auf der Weltbühne bemühen. Um mehr Gewicht zu erlangen, muss sie außenpolitische Beschlüsse schneller fassen können. Deshalb bitte ich die Mitgliedstaaten zu prüfen, welche außenpolitischen Beschlüsse nicht mehr einstimmig, Sondern mit qualifizierter Mehrheit gefasst werden können. Der Vertrag ließe dies zu, wenn denn der Europäische Rat dies einstimmig beschließt. Wir brauchen auch in der Außenpolitik Mehrheitsentscheidungen, um effizient arbeiten zu können. (Beifall) Im Verteidigungsbereich sind weitere Anstrengungen vonnöten. Die Schaffung eines europäischen Verteidigungsfonds steht auf der Tagesordnung; die Permanente Strukturierte Zusammenarbeit im Verteidigungsbereich ist auf gutem Weg. Bis 2025 brauchen wir eine funktionierende Europäische Verteidigungsunion. Wir brauchen sie. Und die NATO hätte sie gerne. Nicht zuletzt möchte ich - in Weiterführung der Kommissionsbemühungen der letzten Jahre -, dass sich unsere Union stärker auf die wirklich wichtigen Dinge konzentriert. Wir sollten die Bürger Europas nicht mit Regelungs-Klein-Klein nerven, Sondern in großen Dingen Größe zeigen, nicht pausenlos neue Initiativen vom Zaun brechen und Befugnisse, dort wo es sinnvoll ist, an die Nationalstaaten zurückgeben. (Beifall) Deshalb hat diese Kommission versucht, in großen Dingen Größe zu zeigen und sich - und das hat sie getan - in kleinen Dingen zurückzuhalten. Sie hat weniger als 25 neue Initiativen pro Jahr vorgelegt, während es bei den Vorgänger-Kommissionen noch weit über 100 waren. Um die begonnene Arbeit sinnvoll zu Ende zu führen, setzen wir noch in diesem Monat eine Task Force Subsidiarität und Verhältnismäßigkeit ein. Der erste Vizepräsident, mein Freund Frans Timmermans, der sich jetzt schon erfolgreich um bessere Rechtssetzung verdient gemacht hat, wird diese Task Force leiten. Dieser Timmermans-Task-Force werden auch Mitglieder dieses Parlaments und der nationalen Parlamente angehören. In einem Jahr ist Bericht zu erstatten. Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, our Union needs a democratic leap. I would like the European political parties to launch their campaign for the next European elections earlier than in the past. Too often, European election campaigns have been reduced to a mere addition of national election proposals. European democracy deserves better. Today the Commission proposes to adopt new rules on the funding of political parties and foundations. It is not about replenishing the coffers of extremists who are against Europe, it is about allowing European parties to better articulate themselves. (Applause) I am aware that the idea is contested by more than a few, but I must tell you that I have sympathy for the idea of ​​presenting transnational lists in the European elections. (Applause) And I will try to convince the chairman of my parliamentary group to follow me in this ambition, which adds democracy and clarity to Europe. (Applause) I also believe that in the coming months we should involve national parliaments and civil society at national, regional and local level in the work on the future of Europe. Over the past three years, members of the Commission, as we had promised, have visited the national parliaments more than 650 times, they have participated in more than 300 citizens' dialogues in more than 80 cities in 27 Member States. This is why I support President Macron's idea of ​​holding democratic conventions across Europe in 2018. As the debate develops, I will pay particular attention to Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Romania. 2018 is the year these four countries will celebrate their 100th anniversary. Those who have the ambition to shape the future of our continent must know and honor our common history and therefore the history of the four countries mentioned, countries without which the European Union would not be complete. (Applause) The need to strengthen democracy and transparency obviously has consequences for the European Commission. Today I am sending the European Parliament a new code of conduct for Commissioners. First of all, this new code specifies that commissioners can stand under normal conditions as candidates in European elections. It is evident that the new code will strengthen the integrity obligations of commissioners during and after their mandate. Anyone who wants to strengthen European democracy cannot accept that the small democratic progress that the innovation of the top "Spitzenkandidaten" leaders constituted is not renewed. I would like the experiment to continue. (Applause) And I will not be a candidate. More democracy means more efficiency. European efficiency would gain in strength if we could merge the presidencies of the European Council and the European Commission. (Applause) This proposal is in no way aimed at my excellent friend Donald, with whom I have worked harmoniously and in complete complicity since the start of our mandate. This proposal does not target Donald or myself. The European landscape would simply be more legible, more understandable if the European ship was piloted by a single captain. Having a single president would better reflect the true nature of our European Union, both as a union of states and as a union of citizens. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, the vision of a more united, stronger, more democratic Europe that I present today combines elements of all the scenarios that I outlined to you last March. But our future cannot remain a simple scenario, a sketch, an idea among many, it is today that we must prepare the Union of tomorrow. This morning I sent President Tajani, President Tusk, and future rotating Council presidencies by March 2019, a roadmap indicating the direction we should take. Important in this respect are the budgetary proposals that the Commission will present in May 2018. Here again, we have a choice: either we confine the ambitions of the European Union to the strict framework of the current budget, or we increase the budgetary capacity of the European Union. European Union so that it can better meet its ambitions. I am for the second solution. (Applause) On March 29, 2019, the UK will leave the European Union. It will be both a sad and a tragic moment. We will always regret it and you will regret it soon. (Applause) But we have to respect the will of the British people, but we will move forward. We are going to move forward because Brexit is not everything, because Brexit is not the future of Europe. On March 30, 2019, we will be a Union of 27. I suggest that we prepare well for it. The elections to the European Parliament will take place just a few weeks later, in May 2019. It will be an important meeting with European democracy. European citizens will have to go to the polls with a clear vision of how the European Union will develop in the years to come. It is why I invite President Tusk and Romania, who will exercise the Presidency in the first half of 2019, to organize a special summit in Romania on March 30, 2019. My wish would be that this summit be held in the beautiful city of Sibiu, also known as Hermannstadt. This should be the time to come together to take the decisions necessary to build a more united, stronger and more democratic Europe. My hope is that, on March 30, 2019, Europeans will wake up to a Union where we will defend all our values, where all Member States will unreservedly respect the rule of law, where to be a full member of the euro area, to banking union, the Schengen area will have become the norm for everyone, where we will have consolidated the foundations of our Economic and Monetary Union in order to be able to defend our single currency in all circumstances, good or bad, without having to resort to external aid and where our single market will be fairer for workers in both East and West. I would like Europeans to be able to wake up in a Europe where we have managed to agree on a solid base of social standards, where profits will be taxed where they are made, where terrorists will find no loophole to exploit and where we will agree on the creation of a genuine European Defense Union, where a single President will lead the work of the Commission and the European Council to completion, after being elected after a campaign pan-European democratic election. Mr. President, if our citizens wake up in this Union on March 30, 2019, the European Union will be a Union that has met their justified expectations. Ladies and Gentlemen, Members of Parliament, Helmut Kohl and Jacques Delors, whom I have had the honor of working with, have taught me that Europe only moves forward when it is bold. The single market, the Schengen area, the single currency: these are ideas and projects that were considered from their birth as mere imaginations. Yet these three major achievements are part of our daily lives today. Now that Europe is better, I am told that we must not overload the European boat, but we must not, at this time, err on the side of caution. We are mending the roof of Europe, but today and tomorrow we must patiently, floor by floor, moment by moment, inspiration after inspiration, keep adding new floors to the Europe house. The Europe house must be completed now that the weather is nice and while the weather is nice, because when the clouds form on the horizon - and they will form one day - it will be too late. So let's cast off, "Leinen los" as the Germans say, set sail and take advantage of the favorable winds. Thank you for your attention. (The Assembly, standing, applauds the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: I thank the President of the Commission for his speech, which has given us the opportunity to start an important discussion on the future of our European Union.You have provided this House with many food for thought, certainly of great interest: now you will listen to the words of the representatives of the European peoples.As President of Parliament, I can only share your position on the need for a more democratic Europe.Thank you for stressing this need.I share more than one point you have made, and I thank you, because you have accepted Parliament's positions on some issues of great importance.While waiting for this Parliament too to have the legislative initiative, we count on the Commission's support to take initiatives in the areas of greatest importance.I now give the floor to the presidents of the political groups.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! Europe needs courage and Europe needs optimism and creativity. We heard that today in Jean-Claude Juncker's speech. I thank you for this new beginning and I also thank the entire EU Commission for the hard work it is doing for our continent. Trust comes from action, so we have to talk about our successes - as Jean-Claude Juncker did. The Paris Climate Agreement, CETA, effective border protection, more money for Africa, growth in Europe, reducing unemployment: the people, many people in Europe, are doing better today than in previous years. We deliver, and when I say “we deliver”, I would like to say explicitly that the European Parliament - the people's chamber of Europe - delivers. There is only a Juncker Commission at all because of the European Parliament's assertiveness. The first political commission is a child of this House, is a child of parliamentarians, is a child of European democracy, and that is why we can be proud of what we have achieved together: Parliament and the Commission are going in the same direction. What is it now? On behalf of the EPP Group, I welcome our Commission President's ideas on deepening our European Union. The world is not waiting for us - we must go ahead now. But I don't want to talk about treaties and institutions today, I want to argue for the EPP Group from the people's point of view. And that's where people see the rough wind of globalization. They are afraid of social dumping, of unemployment. We Europeans oppose this with our idea of ​​the social market economy: justice, secure jobs and fair wages. The idea that ownership obliges. The idea that strong unions can stand up to large corporations. We say yes to trade, to world trade, but we also say yes to the protection of our core industry and protection of social standards in the European Union. The European way of live is social, and the weak are the focus for us as an EPP. Many people are afraid - to open up a second perspective - in view of the pictures of the many people who arrive as illegal immigrants and arrive at our external border. They no longer believe politicians who say this is good for us. They fear for their culture and for their identity, and that is why we have to do everything to secure and control our borders. Not to build a wall around Europe, but to ensure that illegal migration - the breach of law - is stopped. The European Way of Live helps people in need, but at the same time it secures the borders with all severity against illegal migration and the gangs of smugglers. Both are necessary, and we have to make it clear that integration means that our guiding culture, our values ​​and our laws are respected and practiced. Citizenships in Europe should be linked to these basic values, everyone else must leave Europe again. A third concern expressed by the people is the view of Turkey. Many people are shocked when they look there: People are being arrested and imprisoned in an apparently arbitrary manner, the constitution has been changed, the rule of law is being dismantled. Turkey is moving away from Europe. People don't understand why Europe isn't acting now. We as the European Parliament have made it clear that we have to suspend the accession talks in order to send out a signal that there can be no “business as usual” in the current situation, and I wonder why the European Council and, dear Jean- Claude Juncker, the EU Commission reacted so hesitantly. We in Parliament believe that a clear signal is needed. Our European way of live demands honesty in our relations with our neighbors. Many people are afraid of terrorism - Barcelona and Turku this summer - and many say that Islam is a danger. During the attack on Charlie Hebdo in Paris two years ago, a French policeman was executed by the terrorists. His name was Ahmed Merabet. He was a Muslim who gave his life to defend the freedom of journalists. It is not a conflict between Christians and Muslims. It is a conflict between humanity and barbarism, between values ​​and terrorism, between our European way of life and the madness of the terrorists. (Applause) We must exchange our information now - immediately - and data protection must not be turned into protection of terrorists. The European way of life protects the freedom of religion. It does not know national egoism when fighting together against the terrible acts of terrorists. Many people - as a last perspective from the people’s point of view - are afraid when they look eastwards. In some days, a maneuver of the Russian and Belarussian armies will start at the borders to our Baltic states, about 100,000 soldiers directly on our border. Many people are afraid. After the wars in Georgia, Ukraine and Syria, what is Putin planning now? The European way is to defend ourselves and that is why the ideas of the European Defense Union are going in a good direction. We need them now. (Applause) This is also why we should stop Nord Stream 2. Our security has priority over making money. (Applause) Finally, there are a few other perspectives from the people’s point of view - what they are asking us to do - and we have to give proper answers. Let's act now. But with regard to all these points, I think there is a need to combine them and to bring them together. That is, from an EPP point of view, to defend - and to defend in the future - the European way of life. In the past our founding fathers of the European Union achieved peace. They were successful because they believed in themselves. Today we must defend the identity of Europe. Today we must defend the European way of life in a world that is changing rapidly and we will also be successful.Let's start now.(Applause)

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, it is true: a wind of new hope is blowing and citizens are growing the idea that without Europe we are more alone and more defenseless. You did not use triumphal tones and did well, because serious problems remain and we have a shot in the barrel of our gun and we cannot miss the mark. You have made interesting proposals, many of which come from the Socialist Group, and we are grateful to you for that. But we need to transform the proposals into results and we need to be bold, as you said, hitting all the multinationals that have defrauded the tax authorities, forcing them to return what they have hidden with the cheat. We must launch a great initiative against the precariousness and exploitation of young people: some of the young people, even with a master's degree, receive 500 euros a month! This is a scandal we must oppose! We must be inflexible, as the European Commission, Vice-President Timmermans, is doing on the issues of freedom, equality, the rule of law and democracy. You have said that these are the pillars of your policy. I would say: these are the pillars, the DNA of the European Union. We need to strengthen our decision-making process: the unanimity rule is a virus for democracy in the Council; we must have a European Treasury Ministry, but one that is not an obscure guardian of the treaties, of public accounts, but a democratic institution, with fiscal capacity. I say this clearly, President Juncker: we do not want a minister who acts as a gendarme! We want a ministry for growth and work. We need to get out of the "triple A" rhetoric on social issues - welcome, Hon. Weber, in social Europe; we like it; tell your popular colleagues to push, as we have been pushing for years, on these issues and on these dossiers in the competent committees; we must have a child guarantee for European girls and boys! Not a child should be left without food, without education, without home; this also applies to unaccompanied minor migrants. We need more courage on investments, sustainability, climate, industrial policy, on which Parliament has done a great job. We show Trump that disasters can be prevented if Europe takes the lead in these battles. And then, as regards immigration: thank you for the recognition of Italy - I say this as a European, not as an Italian - but more needs to be done, we need to have a revision of the Dublin Treaty. But beware: the Socialist Group will not vote on any revision without eliminating the aberrant rule of the country of first landing; be clear. We must have legal channels for migrants, President Juncker. The blue card is an old, outdated and reductive tool. We must have the courage to open legal channels: we cannot just close the clandestine routes. That's right, but if you close routes and don't open other legal channels, you haven't solved the problem. And then we need a partnership with Africa, which I would call the partnership of dignity. You said: more money, where do we get it? And who do we give them to? It is very important: who do we give them to? I would say: let's give them to young entrepreneurs, who create jobs and wealth and create development in Africa. Finally, an adequate budget, an effective and strong cohesion policy, a budget with its own resources. We also think about the web tax, let's think about it, in addition to the taxes on financial transactions. And then, President Juncker, yes to transparency on trade treaties, but we must defend the interests of citizens first and foremost. We want to go further than CETA. Let me be clear: the socialists want to go further than CETA on the issue of the interests of citizens and consumers. We have a blank page that we can write together. You referred to innovation, great progress, to artificial intelligence.Often we here discuss the sex of angels and we do not realize that the world goes on, that soon we will have an artificial intelligence that will decide on our own whether to wage wars or not to wars, whether to go nuclear or not.We need to keep up with these great transformations.We have an example, an important reference: the 2030 agenda for sustainable development.Let us take that example and work with that love which is in His heart but which is also in our socialist heart.Let's work together, with tenacity and loyalty!

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Juncker that when it comes to jobs, security and freedom, a Europe that protects cannot be a Europe that is protectionist. The ECR Group believes that the EU needs to create more opportunities, not more regulations and more agencies. Many of our citizens tell us that they feel as if they have little say in the decisions we make about their lives, their countries and their futures. When it comes to their concerns over migration, security and jobs, they prefer an EU that complements their national and local governments, not seek to overrule them. Speaking as both a future neighbour who wishes to see a prosperous EU trading and cooperating with a prosperous UK, and speaking today as one of the leaders of the ECR Group with MEPs from across the EU, being critical of the policies of the EU should not be seen as an attack on the EU, but a genuine desire to see an EU which regains the trust and confidence of its citizens. As a liberal Conservative and a passionate believer in free trade, I welcome the emphasis on open trade in your speech. But modern open trade needs countries to shed the cloak of protectionism. Modern open trade needs to be open to the latest investment in technology to allow frictionless borders. Modern open trade needs faster broadband networks to allow SMEs to trade securely online with the rest of the world. And for our businesses and economies to thrive, let us prioritise the REFIT agenda. Let us improve access to finance for businesses, small and large, via peer-to-peer lending and crowdfunding. Let us train our workers with the skills demanded by modern digital economies. But also, let us unleash the spirit of free enterprise in our young people to create their own businesses, and let them be allowed to try and try again if at first they do not succeed. Because, just as Soviet five-year plans did not create creative economies, EU growth plans do not create jobs: it is businesses that create jobs. We must also remember that our economic prosperity depends upon global stability, and we cannot show disunity in our dealings with Russia or other unpleasant regimes. We must maintain sanctions and show in words and in action at the Eastern Partnership Summit that, for countries like Ukraine, NATO, the EU and the West can offer them a better, stronger and more stable future than turning to face the east. Mr Juncker, no one expects there to be a quick fix to all the challenges, or for you to have all the answers by the next time we meet. But the people outside of this building want to know that the people inside this building will continue to steady the ship and not set sail into yet more storms. So no matter what side of the argument, or what side of the Channel, all our countries need to prepare to face the global challenges from a position of optimism, from a position of strength, and from a position of honesty with our voters.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to say to Jean-Claude: what a difference to last year. I liked his speech on the State of the Union. I think it was full of vision, ambition, for 2019, and quite a difference to last year, but let’s be honest between us, a lot has in fact changed in the meanwhile in the Union since last year. In August 2016, for example, it was Mr Hofer who said that he wanted to take Austria out of the euro and the Union, and five months later, after his defeat, he said exactly the opposite. He changed his mind and he said no, no, we want to stay in the euro and in the Union.  And then in March of this year, in the Netherlands, it was Mr Wilders who promised a spring of populism and in what he created, he reaped the opposite. It was the pro-European parties which won the election. And in France, exactly the same, it was Emmanuel Macron who won the campaign with a pro-European programme, and since then even the Front National does not want to exit the euro and the Union anymore. Even in Hungary Viktor Orbán is piping down. He accepts now the authority of the European Court of Justice and he said, two days ago I think, on a radio interview that there is no way that Hungary would ever leave the Union.  So on the occasion of this State of the Union address, I want to say to Mr Hofer, to Ms Le Pen, to Viktor Orbán, welcome to the side of reason, even when we all know that it is not that they have changed their mind, it is not through conviction that they have changed their mind, but it is through fear of losing votes that they have changed their minds now.  The only one for the moment who still does not get it is, I think, Mr Farage. He is still going on. Last weekend he called on the German AfD to campaign on Brexit. I think it is fantastic advice to campaign on Brexit. You have to keep up the good work, Nigel. I hope they take your advice, but unfortunately I do not think they are as stupid as to do that in Germany in the AfD. Because let’s be honest, it is clear what our citizens want: they do not want to destroy Europe, they want to reform Europe – but to destroy it, no bloody way. That is the message from our citizens. And that is what I liked so much in the State of the Union address this year by Jean-Claude Juncker. Let’s not make the mistake of thinking, okay, the war is over, we have won a few elections in a number of countries and now the wind is blowing in the right direction. No, what the people want is not to continue with this Europe. They want a reformed European Union; 73% of our citizens want more European action on the side of migration; 75% want more European action against climate change. The same number want a European army and, at the same time, even more Europeans want European capacities and capabilities in the fight against terrorism.  So it is true, Jean-Claude, that the last three years were not easy, it was mainly crisis management, but I completely agree with you that now is the moment – now or never I should say, as in the song – to build up the European Union that the people are asking for and that we together have already been dreaming of for a number of years.  And what does this mean? It means that we create a European asylum system so that we can finally get rid of this broken Dublin system, because that is the real origin of the problem. Dublin is not European. It is national egoism: that is Dublin. Not Dublin as a city naturally, sorry, please do not misunderstand me because otherwise I will have my Irish friends against me if I continue like that! A European border and coastguard and a system of legal – indeed, Gianni – migration so that people no longer die on our shores, because every dead body that we find in the Mediterranean is a scandal for us, for Europe; even one person dead in the Mediterranean.  A European defence union so that it is not the Americans and the Russians who decide, Ms Mogherini, in our backyard; which is still the case today. A European FBI – why? Because terrorists do not recognise borders. That is the reality, so why do we continue to do so? And then a real government for the euro area so that we can steer the European economy and we can create what, in fact, we are missing – European champions. Our competition rules are far too narrow. The fact that we have no unified markets with single regulators is why we have no European champions that can become world champions and compete at world level.  But there is one thing on which I have a little difference in point of view with you, and it is the institutional problem. I always think that good institutions produce good policies and that bad institutions create a standstill, stagnation and crisis. And there are a number of examples of that. That is the reason why we in this Parliament, and I thank you for your support because it is really very helpful, want also to create transnational lists and a real European constituency. And why do we want to do that? Because it is time to lift democracy to a continental scale – Europe is more than the sum of 27 national democracies; we are more than that, we are in fact a democracy on a European scale – and also to defend our values and our principles outside the Union, but also inside the Union.  This European democracy is necessary, for example, to withstand alt-right governments such as we see today – also inside, in Poland and in Hungary – who think that Trump with his white supremacy is the example, or that Putin and Orbán, who jail opponents, are the example. That will never be the example in whatever Member State in the European Union. And for that reason we have to create this European democracy with a transnational responsibility because, as Emmanuel Macron said, standing near the Acropolis, we need to be the counterweight to all these developments and yes, to autocratic leaders worldwide – a beacon of openness, a beacon of freedom and a beacon of hope in the 21st century.  (Applause)

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, you have drawn up a picture of the European Union which in no way corresponds to what our fellow citizens are experiencing. Indeed, no statistics tell the exact perception of this Union by workers thrown into the street because we do not fight offshoring, the feeling of the small peasant who is dying of low prices and the end of milk quotas, of the unemployed. who has nothing to do with the unemployment rate that is constantly brandished under his nose in order to better suggest that he become a precarious and poor worker, and even less with the growth rate which is in fact a growth in profits and pollution. We can deposit all the billions we want on this desk, how can that be perceived when there are so many people who do not have enough to end the month to the nearest 10 euros? It is from there that the crisis of the European idea is born, which traverses the continent like a wisp. Because we do not listen to the populations, because the European Union does not carry an ideal of social and ecological humanism. The terrible cyclone that has just ravaged the West Indies, Cuba and part of the United States commands us to act energetically against climate disruption caused by transport and carbon energies, free trade treaties, such as the one with Canada. that you have just praised Mr. President, but which is contrary to the options of the Paris Agreement. There is an urgent need for a European construction combining social progress and environmental progress in transport, energy, housing, the renovation of cities, agriculture and to help the transformation of production systems. This would create millions of jobs in Europe, it would require new training, new research. This could be possible, not by creating a European Monetary Fund as you have just done, but by transforming the fund that carries your name, the Juncker Fund, in a large social and environmental development fund linked to the European Central Bank, to deleverage States and launch innovative investment projects, creating work, by developing public services, by launching new projects securing the professional careers of all Europeans, starting with young people. From this point of view, comply with the request of the Greek government, which wants training and apprenticeship programs for people deprived of employment to be eligible for European regional social funds and the fund called Juncker. It is urgent to get out of this Europe of competition and division in order to launch without delay the foundations of a social Europe, including minimum wages, the elimination of job insecurity for job security, defense social protection and pensions, the eradication of poverty by distributing wealth differently, a fair directive for posted workers, equality between men and women, more power for employees in their companies. A social Europe also means tax harmonization and the fight against tax evasion and tax havens. Instead of the nauseating debates on refugees and this shameful agreement with Turkey, and now Libya, let's make a Europe of solidarity, launch a co-development pact with Africa, with the Maghreb and act for a Middle East free from the violence and wars, where people can become masters of their own destiny. It is urgent to listen and to hear the peoples. Democracy is knocking on the door, we all say it, but we must act. Let us ask citizens which Europe they want. Let us launch consultations, forums, from the municipalities and regions to the European institutions, within the framework of general states of democratic, social and ecological overhaul of European construction. The The voice of the European Union must also be heard to help resolve tensions and conflicts; it must be an actor in nuclear disarmament in particular, and for peace.For this, it must not itself take the path of militarization, as has just been proposed, but the one which defends the works of life, that of education and culture.We want the debate, a real debate, Mr President, to make the European Union a force for social and ecological progress, a force for peace in democracy.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Mr Juncker, listening to you very attentively, I have tried to put myself in the shoes of all our fellow citizens who can no longer take it; who can no longer pay the price for a financial crisis that they did not cause and from which those responsible continue to profit; who are tired of having to contribute more than their share to the financing of our public services and our social protection, while the richest among us still largely escape taxes; who can no longer eat, drink, breathe poisons, on the grounds that banning these poisons would be harmful to business; who can no longer have to accept as workers, with or without a job, ever more flexibility to ensure ever more security for the holders of capital; who can no longer see their individual freedoms cut off and their personal data captured en masse in the name of the fight against terrorism, or more prosaically so that they are flooded with advertisements; who can no longer, finally, see the future of their children, their grandchildren, compromised by the mad rush for the benefit of a few. Often these citizens attribute to Europe these scourges which they support less and less, and yet we all know that the governments of the 28 Member States bear an overwhelming responsibility in these political choices. But too often, the Commission that you chair pushes in the same direction. Of course, we can be happy that the Le Pen and the Wilders still do not make the majority around them, but we would be wrong to rejoice too quickly, because the anger and the spite of many of our fellow citizens did not disappeared however, and I would even say that national chauvinist ideas, Mr Juncker, are even progressing in your political family - look at Austria. During your inauguration, you told us being the President of the Faint Hope Commission and, sometimes, watching your action, one might get the impression that this is the last chance to anchor the neoliberal agenda. Nevertheless, I know you and I want to believe that you had something else in mind, namely to reconcile European citizens with the very idea of ​​European integration by putting this project at their service. Seizing that last chance requires a change of course and it's true that a lot of the things we've heard today are music to our ears. I am thinking in particular of your proposals on the euro zone, I am obviously thinking of this idea of ​​transnational lists that the Greens have been carrying for more than a decade. I am not, however, sure that what you are proposing here is likely to give the boost we need and so let me suggest to you perhaps what you could have said today. My dear fellow citizens, many of you legitimately wonder if your democracy is working for you. So, I am now committed to aligning all the action of my Commission around the dual objective of reducing inequalities and bringing our ecological impact within the limits that nature sets for us. Our goal will now be to ensure that everyone has the possibility of a life worth living. And how will we get there? I pledge that, here, any action, any legislation, any recommendation issued by my Commission will be scrutinized for its effect on inequalities and on our ecological footprint, and that only those which will reduce them will be pursued. A few examples to illustrate my point: my Commission will spare no effort to put an end to tax and social competition between Member States. Cooperation and upward convergence will become the watchwords of our action. We will initiate a complete reorientation of our trade policy, which will now have to make access to our market conditional on compliance with social, environmental and health standards that we have freely chosen. We will therefore propose to freeze the provisional application of CETA and to review the negotiating mandates of all other agreements under discussion. We will restore the precautionary principle as the foundation of the internal market and, so that you have no doubts about our determination, we will phase out glyphosate. We will take it off the market and we will strengthen the definition of endocrine disruptors. But I do not only offer you a Europe that protects, I also suggest that Europe be the instrument through which we build our common future and, for me, the only chance for Europeans to find their place in a globalized economy. , it is to become the pioneers of energy, industrial, agricultural and other solutions which will allow humanity to live sustainably on this planet. Therefore, rather than the defenders of the established economic order, my Commission will henceforth support all the initiatives which engage us in this great transformation. And I am convinced that a Europe reconciled with itself, a Europe in which no one will feel left behind will know better than ever how to assume its responsibilities towards those who knock on our door and cry out. help. The transition must also take place towards a more democratic society and - let's say it - our democracies are injured. When governments drunk on power bring justice, parliaments, the media and universities to heel. They are threatened when the executives allow themselves to put citizens under surveillance or place them under house arrest, without any judicial control. They are undermined when, both for security reasons and to put social benefit recipients under control, governments collect and conserve massively data, except of course those relating to holders of large fortunes. They are perverted when the making of our laws is subject to the less and less discreet influence of the money powers. No, my dear friends, democracy is not an irreversible achievement. We must anchor the European Union - and you said this, Mr Juncker - as the guarantor of freedoms, the rule of law and the general interest. My dear fellow citizens, collectively the European Union is rich in assets and, in fact, much richer than it was when the project was started 60 years ago, much richer, believe I. We are capable of meeting the challenges we face, but I am telling you bluntly: the only way to regain control over our future is together. Dear Mr Juncker, by implementing such an agenda, I think you would seize your last chance to make history, not as the former boss of a tax haven who joined the gravedigger battalion of Europe, but on the contrary as one of those who will have restarted it.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Juncker that this was the most open, honest and truly worrying speech I have heard in my long years in this place. The message is very clear: Brexit has happened, full steam ahead. So new plans: there is to be one powerful President for the whole of the European Union; a Finance Minister with fresh powers to – as you say yourself – intervene as and when he sees necessary; a stronger European army in a militarised European Union with a stronger, and perhaps more aggressive, foreign policy too; and more Europe in every single direction, and all of it to be done without the consent of the people. Your plan to fight the next European elections with pan-European lists, funded by the European Union, but not, as you said, to fund extremists, means that what we will find is that genuine democratic parties of opposition will not be able to compete in elections on the same playing field. It is reminiscent of regimes of old. Indeed, the way you are treating Hungary and Poland must already remind them of living under the Soviet communists when you attempt to tell them how they should run their own countries. All I can say is thank God we’re leaving, but you have learned nothing from Brexit. If you had given Cameron concessions, particularly on immigration, the Brexit vote – I have to admit – would never ever have happened, and yet the lesson you take is that you are going to centralise and you are going to move on to this new – I think very worrying –undemocratic union. You are deluding yourself, Mr Verhofstadt, if you think that the ‘populist wave’, as you define it, is over. If these plans of Mr Juncker’s come to fruition, far from the populist wave being over, I doubt it has even begun.  (Applause)

name: Harald Vilimsky
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, addressed to all apologists for this euro-centralism: Europe is not the European Union and the European Union is not Europe. The European Union is nothing more and nothing less than an association that has rules, and these rules can be changed and you do not determine the direction in which we should make changes here! I also do not claim to be able to determine them. It is the peoples of Europe who, in free and uninfluenced choice, set this direction here. What Commission President Juncker said today goes in the completely opposite direction. Juncker wants de facto for the introduction of the euro in all countries of the European Union. We all know that the euro is anything but a success story, it is a huge failure. Debt has grown immeasurably. We have record unemployment and record bankruptcies, and it is hardly possible to get the euro fairly stable after many waves. The second thing Juncker would like: he would de facto want to dissolve all internal borders - knowing that tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands, millions of Africans and Arabs are rushing to our continent, that soldiers of fortune and terrorists are among them. You know very well that the Bataclan assassins came to Europe this way. To belittle that is a real security threat to all citizens of this continent. The third thing that is called for here: a defense union, which is in fact a military union. No, we don't want that. We Austrians in particular, who are a neutral country, cannot and do not want to participate. The right way for a good future for Europe can only be to allow more democracy, to let the peoples vote on whether Schengen should be maintained - with borders, yes or no, that a vote is held on whether or not the free movement of workers should be maintained during a period of record unemployment.If you care about this Europe, then allow more democracy again.Allow pluralism.Grant the states a little more sovereignty and Europe will work.It's not working now, and you know that well as well.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the sixth scenario we have heard about the future of Europe - the European Union, not Europe - is another compromise in the fierce competition within the European Union and the eurozone, given Germany's lead. at the expense of the rest. At the same time, with sympathy in all states regardless of whether they are over-indebted, governments, in the name of development, are pushing hard for barbaric anti-labor equalization measures down - and in Greece, France, Italy, everywhere - with tax breaks and subsidies to large capital and its profitability. European Union empowerment marks the European Union's great opposition to the United States, China, Russia and Britain. The hypocritical declarations of peace cannot hide the fact that the European Union is actively involved in the imperialist wars and is preparing intensively for young people as well. The European Union of Monopolies is only getting worse, more reactionary, more unpopular. Popular discontent with the European Union can only take place if the popular struggle is aimed at overthrowing the real adversary, their monopolies and their power.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am speaking not on behalf of the Council; the Council cannot have a position on this. Speaking on behalf of the Estonian Presidency of the Council, I thank President Juncker for his ambitious, clear and, most importantly, thoughtful speech. At this moment, with the wind in our sails, we should bear in mind a couple of lessons that the last couple of years have taught us. First, that we who care for our Union must have the courage to make the positive case for the EU. It is not only the right thing to do, but it also may pay off in elections. Secondly, we should not be afraid of speaking of the cost of non-EU: of the consequences of (so far, thank God) only hypothetical rolling back some advantages of European integration. Thirdly, we must keep looking for issues, initiatives and ways that unite us, and not those that pose a risk of dividing Member States. We should look for initiatives that balance things and build bridges. For instance, it is much easier to talk about the EU social pillar – something that the Estonian Presidency will duly take forward – when we simultaneously take real steps in deepening the single market, in particular in the field of services. So not only better paid jobs but also better access to these jobs. Fourthly, of course we must keep developing the EU further, but doing this, we must not forget that this time around, in 2017, it is not the institutional setup that is most important – it is important, of course – but reshaping the institutions must go hand in hand with providing concrete benefits for our citizens. Our citizens must be at the centre of our attention, and delivering concrete benefits for citizens is what the guiding principle of the Estonian Presidency is.
