For the last few years, we have all been working on building a digital single market. The free movement of data is one of its cornerstones. We need to ensure that European citizens and businesses are able to benefit from data and that we create no new barriers to the single market. As with the EU’s other freedoms, free movement does not mean freedom from rules. Next year, new EU personal data protection rules come into force, and we look forward to starting work on the Commission’s new proposal on the free flow of data. Thank you, President Juncker, for this proposal. Member States have repeatedly emphasised that legislation in this area is necessary. The Estonian Presidency will now move swiftly, attempting to consolidate Member States’ positions on the concrete proposal. As we grow Europe’s data economy and enter the era of the Internet of Things, cyber security becomes a matter for everyone. We welcome the renewal of the EU Cybersecurity Strategy proposed by the Commission. Cybersecurity is a challenge that cannot be tackled by any Member State on its own. We all need to fulfil our responsibilities by fully implementing the existing EU legislation and must deploy all parts of our toolbox, working on the new legislation and engaging with the private sector. The EU also has an important role to play, setting international norms, pursuing cybercriminals, standing up for European values such as freedom and privacy, guiding the development of the global market for secure products and services, and reacting to states that sponsor and support malicious cyber activity. The EU Heads of State and Government will address these key issues at the Tallinn Digital Summit on 29 September. I earlier listed some recent lessons for the EU. We have also learned that, while strengthening the EU internally is, of course, key for the health and functioning of the Union itself, at the same time, to be and to appear strong, the EU also needs to remain engaged and open to the outside world. We are a model to a number of countries in our neighbourhood, and we should not forget it. The EU’s transformative power is still very much there. The Eastern Partnership Summit in November is an opportunity to reconfirm our commitment to our neighbours’ positive transformation. In the field of trade, the EU must perform a tough balancing act. President Juncker laid out very eloquently the elements of it. We, of course, welcome the message that we can now proceed with the free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand and to expand the network of liberal trade relations in this globalised world. The Commission has gone a long way with its reflection paper on harnessing globalisation and deserves to be commended for that. With regard to the proposals on investments and the Multilateral Investment Court, as the Presidency we will make our best efforts to proceed in the best possible way to build a consensus among the Member States, in a manner that will enable the EU to continue its leading role in trade policy. With regard to migration: the crisis which shook the fundamentals of the EU and showed that the EU does not the really have a headquarters to manage an acute operational crisis. The EU does not have a general, if you will. This is not to say that we have not achieved a lot in the field of migration. Work on the external dimension is going well, and, maybe for the first time, the Union is using all the tools in its foreign policy toolbox at the same time: assistance, development, trade, military operation, and even enlargement policy. The Estonian Presidency is working hard on migration issues, not least while carrying forward work on a common asylum system. On legal migration, we eagerly started working with the European Parliament on the Blue Card Directive. On security, we are ready to engage with the Parliament on ETS and, hopefully, on SIS initiatives. And of course, we are confident that an inclusive and ambitious permanent structured cooperation in the field of defence can be launched by the end of this year. Ladies and gentlemen, the speech by President Juncker and the debate we have had so far shows us once more that in our Union there is much more of what unites us than what creates tensions. Estonia, a country that was deprived of the advantages of European integration during its first 40 years, feels that particularly deeply. That is the compass while we act as a Member State; that is our compass, especially while we are performing the duties of the Presidency of the Council of the EU, with the wind in our sails.

name: Presidente. –
text: Given the times, I inform you that the Presidency, during this discussion, will not authorize "blue card" questions.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: - Mister President! A year or two ago the mood was bad here. Commission President Juncker said that we have a window of opportunity open at the moment and we should urgently use this window in the next few months. But Manfred Weber mentioned: Many people are worried, for example about globalization. Please let us use the opportunities for our employees and citizens in the next few weeks, for example through quick, transparent negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. But please also help ensure that we can better protect our employees. We urgently need to complete the reform of our trade defense instruments, and we must also adopt the instrument against strategic foreign investment proposed today as quickly as possible in order to avert further damage to our industrial base. Second: Many people are worried about jobs - in Germany at the moment several hundred thousand in the automotive industry. We are all annoyed about the breach of trust, but on the other hand it also applies: When it comes to climate change, we also have to keep an eye on jobs. Yes, we need climate protection and cars and jobs - we don't need climate protection instead of cars and jobs, and here too I call on all of us to pay attention to this in our legislative projects over the next few weeks and months. Please allow me to make one more point on transnational lists, Mr President. Many citizens have the impression that we are too aloof here in Europe, that some here in Parliament are remote from the citizens. We urgently need more proximity to the citizen, and we are convinced that such a transnational list will not be closer to the citizen, but more remote from the citizen, and that is why we clearly reject such a list.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is the moment for us, as a last shot, to have real vision and ambition. What is at stake for this legislature? It is indeed to develop the European house and to move to the next stage, a new floor. It is to make Europe not only a single market or a eurozone, but also a political entity able to respond to the new world in front of us. We need the European Union to be a big democratic power, supporting our way of life and making sure that we have the means to deliver our values and our way of life. We need new means for peace and security, to manage migration and to support development. But to have this, we need a brand new Community budget for the future, based on new own resources; we need to turn to the future and not the past. This means, when it comes to own resources, that big corporations should pay their taxes because while they should benefit from the single market, they should pay what they owe.  If we have in mind a new democratic political entity, this can only be based on stronger European citizenship, above all fully respecting the fundamental political rights of our citizens, but also making sure that we can count on updated social standards with regard to access to social protection and to skills, but also making sure that everybody in employment, whatever kind of job they have, can count on a decent labour contract and access to social protection. This should be the ambition of the upcoming European Social Pillar, but can we say that this Europe, as a land of equal opportunity, of fairness, is being delivered to all European citizens? We do not think so. Europe is still working as a machine for divergence and inequality and we need to reverse this very undermining trend. So we call on the Commission to come up with an ambitious proposal for the European budget, turning the European project into a project for equality and convergence. This should apply to the European Union as a whole and also to the eurozone. This is our request for the upcoming work of the Commission.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: - Mister President! Mr. Juncker! You took 60 minutes to draw castles in the air, to stir up illusions, to awaken illusions that have no real anchoring, that do not address the real problems of the European Union. If you have talked about the reality of the European Union, then you thought it was right to talk about fish fingers and vaccinations and the cocoa content of chocolate. But it's about the big problems that have to be overcome. And you didn't come up with a solution. You mentioned the rule of law, but you did not mention that the Maastricht Treaty has been broken, that the Fiscal Compact has been violated hundreds of times, that the Dublin Agreement has been broken again and again, that the European Central Bank is still today Violates the AEU Treaty and practices monetary state financing. As long as you don't address these issues, as long as you create illusions about a Juncker plan - a plan that bears your name and which is said to have generated EUR 220 billion in investment, with promotional banks saying there is actually no project that we are not anyway - as long as you do not address Europe's real problems and the European Union will not come out of the crisis.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that to President Juncker: not bad at all. I think that this is something that I can very well work with on the Czech domestic political scene. President Juncker, you spoke about your life and having been a fighter. For me, on a different level, I have been going through a similar experience in the Czech Republic, and I think that, with this vision and with these ideas, I am happy to confront some of your former counterparts – politicians who have views from the first half of the 20th century. So thanks for that, even though there are, of course, some disagreements. But that is absolutely normal. Let us forget the five scenarios. I think that we both know that three of them were not scenarios at all. I think that, if we now had the priority agenda, I would perhaps have wished that you had shortlisted two or three more. But I understand that we will find them in the report. But I think that the implementation of these priorities – the reform agenda that you have emphasised and that I subscribe to – will lead us to the outcome, and that is the sixth scenario: the European Union that we want to have. Maybe some will fall behind, but that, of course, remains to be seen. My final remark: unity. I believe, as you do, that we are in better shape, but if we still have a problem, it is a lack of unity in the Council and a lack of ability on the part of the Member States to deliver even on what they themselves have proclaimed before. One final remark, President Juncker: I am not offended that you have forgotten the Czech Republic as a country that will also be a hundred years old next year. No offence taken.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: - Sir. Chairman! I must admit that, unfortunately, I think it is arrogant, Mr President of the Commission, when you say that it is moving forward. Because that is not what the citizens are experiencing. Citizens are experiencing poverty, they are experiencing declining welfare, they are experiencing pressure on wages and working conditions, they are experiencing high unemployment, especially among young people. And then they experience an EU that does not solve their problems, but instead makes them worse. Not least, they experience an EU that neither listens nor is interested in listening to them. But instead of dealing with the real problems, you are sitting there with the rest of the EU elite in your glass tower and saying that we just need more EU, more power for the EU and more power for the Commission. A Minister of Finance who will steer Member States even more in the direction of the Commission, and a President of all Presidents who will ensure that we have one Union with one President. I think it is arrogant towards the citizens and I think it is arrogant towards democracy. And I honestly think that you in the Commission already have ample power.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: - Monsieur le Président Tajani, Monsieur le Président Juncker, aujourd’hui, je vais m'adresser à vous in Spanish. Mr President, President Juncker, surprisingly you have not mentioned the situation in Spain with the next referendum in Catalonia. Because hundreds of thousands of Catalans repeatedly ask for a self-determination referendum like the Scottish one. The Government of Spain has never even wanted to talk about it. No way. Never. And the Parliament of Catalonia has approved the referendum law by an absolute majority. As if it were a crime to vote, the reaction of the Government of Spain has been the judicial complaint against the president of Parliament and other parliamentarians and threats to the Government, more than a thousand public officials and the Catalan media so that they do not speak or act in favor of the referendum. These are clear and unacceptable attacks on freedom of expression. I am not asking you to speak out for independence. That must be done by the Catalans. I do ask you to mediate with the Government of Spain in favor of an agreement on the referendum. And I ask you: Why does the Commission not intervene to defend freedom of expression in Spain? In other countries, it surely would.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Mr President!"Full steam ahead!"It's a line I remember from the movie Titanic - you know the scene where the captain stands on the bridge and looks out over the sea and says: “I do not see any icebergs.Full speed ahead!"You have some similarities with that captain, Jean-Claude Juncker, and we know how it unfortunately ended with the Titanic.As you remember, I have also told you before that the people of Europe are not interested in hearing these kinds of visions and dreams.You want to hear concrete solutions to the worries you see in your everyday life.The migration dreams that the EU is unable to deal with, the social dumping that kills serious companies that do not take care of themselves and the worries about the future and old age - these were questions that the people of Europe wanted answered today, but which I feared became visions and dreams.the building of an EU army and even more so of federalism, where the silence of criticism of the EU is a priority task ahead of the next EU elections.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: - Mr President, then Mr Juncker has this Parliament found favor in your eyes or do you still find it "ridiculous" as in last July? We already knew how little consideration you had for the peoples of Europe, that day you showed all the contempt you have for their representatives. However, you do not only despise the Members of Parliament that we are, but also the heads of government of Hungary, Poland and Slovakia who resist your injunctions. Mr Juncker, you said earlier, "Europe is an aging continent". You announce that you want to create new legal avenues for extra-European immigration, even though it is causing deep identity, security, economic and social disorders. You seek to distinguish legal immigration, which you encourage, from illegal immigration, which you claim to fight, without ever giving yourself the means to do so. However, these two immigrations do not cancel each other out, but they are cumulative. We must give back to the peoples of Europe confidence in the future, by recreating the conditions for their own demographic dynamism, give them back control of their destiny and build a Europe of cooperation, this is our vision, the opposite of yours. , which is federalist, rigid and increasingly totalitarian.

name: Martin Sonneborn (NI).
text: - Presidents, colleagues! Almost more presidents than colleagues here - but it doesn't matter. In the last three years I have done a great job as an MEP: I sent the English home, I ousted Martin Schulz and demoted him to the position of SPD candidate for Chancellor, and I made sure that Chancellor Helmut Kohl was taken off the grid and dismantled and is finally disposed of in a safe way. However, I failed to teach the Orbán regime and the Polish PiS party basic democratic values. I am particularly proud that the EU has now adopted one of my party's very own ideas: that of a wall, a wall around Europe. Only recently we demanded an upper limit for refugees in the spirit of the Christian Union parties. Germany should not have to absorb more than the Mediterranean every year. And now - before the Mediterranean is full - the EU is building a wall in the Sahara, in the broken states of Mali, Niger and Chad. Finally, I would like to apologize to all the foreigners here that so many important decisions had to be postponed until after the election in Germany. A good week, then another party will rule. (Boos)

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: - Madam President!We are a parliament here where freedom of expression is allowed.We are a parliament here where everyone can say anything they want.But if you talk about a dead person like Mr. Sonneborn just talked about Helmut Kohl, then that is unacceptable.I ask that the Bureau look into this.This behavior is not worthy of a parliamentarian.(Applause)

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Mr Weber. We will look into that matter.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: - The climate in Europe is different today, the tone of the 2017 State of the Union address was different. This is more than just official optimism. Last year we were shocked after the British referendum, the successors of Brexit were searched for and guessed. It seemed that populism and xenophobia would rule public emotions in Europe. But luckily the shock turned into shock therapy, and today it is not Europe but the British Isles that are overshadowed by Brexit. Today we are sure that the great work of the founding fathers of the European Communities will be continued. We have scenario number six. Today, the economy and politics are a source of good news, but there are exceptions, and because there are exceptions, I would like to state with full force that my country, Poland, which will also be celebrating the centenary of independence next year, is inhabited by people who the vast majority of people feel at home in Europe because they feel at home. And I would like to declare on behalf of my delegation that we will do everything in our power to ensure that Poland also fully participates in the search and creation of a new European unity.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - Mr President Juncker, congratulations on your address! There are three critical things in my heart, and that is the rule of law, young people and the Western Balkans. The rule of law is not a la carte, you said, the rule of law, the judgments of the courts must be respected. Do Hungary, Poland, and even Croatia respect them today? If countries cannot arbitrarily dictate what they will do and what they will not act and respect, then the Commission, I hope, will take action here. This is also the way for citizens to start trusting the Union again. Young people are becoming very uninterested, they are witnessing irresponsible politicians, they are highly unemployed, they do not have the right perspective. It is especially difficult for them in the countries of the Western Balkans, and I am counting on your commitment to a credible enlargement policy, because this part of Europe is becoming a dangerous proving ground for geostrategic interests. There must be no second-class citizens and second-class countries in Europe, so we are investing in Europe, as you said, which will not be a fortress, which will not be a continent under a fence, which will not be a fortress of intolerance, hatred and my greatest wish is that in this Europe, same as yours, we breathe again along with full lungs.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the crisis in Europe began in 2008. You, Mr Juncker, will leave your post in 2019 and this period will go down in history as a lost decade or, perhaps, as the decade of cuts in Europe. The European Union is paralyzed, but it is not a problem of speed - as they have often said - but of political direction. With his speech, you insist on advancing along the same path that has led us to this situation and, furthermore, in a triumphalist manner. They are recipes that an undemocratic machine builds, resorting if necessary to threat and financial blackmail to impose a failed neoliberal policy, generating disaffection and euroscepticism in more and more layers of the European population. The crisis of the European project is not solved with new neoliberal trade agreements, more Australian-style externalization of borders, larger military budgets, nor with a financial authority that imposes austerity measures that respond to the agendas and interests of the large multinational governments and lobbies. . We need a change of direction, a 180-degree turn in foreign, economic and environmental policy to build a European project, not for the elites, but democratic and from below. That would be a change of course.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker touched on many important issues: security, immigration and above all the economy. Here, I would like to focus on the economic points. Transforming the European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund is an issue that some people find very difficult to interpret, but not me, especially also the proposal of a European Finance Minister: a structure that will therefore implement what is the troika mechanism In an institutional way: that is, the Member States will pay the money through the European Stability Mechanism and receive it back in exchange for liberal and very unpopular reforms. Instead, we should solve the problems of currency imbalances. Since the quantitative easing program launched by the European Central Bank ends, the structural problems of the eurozone will emerge once again: Germany that does not accept its responsibilities, does not accept real Eurobonds, does not accept fiscal transfers and therefore they propose these undemocratic structures which will still bring suffering to the peripheral countries. This is absolutely not acceptable.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, I am so pleased that Mr Juncker thinks everything in the EU garden is rosy. There is no mention of the 50 000 jihadists waiting to blow us up, who have got in through your failed immigration policies, and no mention of your failed immigration policies and the marauding migrants breaking into our countries. At least the eastern European countries have got the right idea. There is no mention of your failed youth employment schemes, but there is good news.  In the UK, we have record employment, despite Brexit, we have got record inward investment, despite Brexit, the volume of output is the highest in 20 years, despite Brexit, and Bill Gates said that despite Brexit, Britain can still lead in the science and technology institutes. Our order books are the highest in 30 years, despite Brexit, the City of London is still number one, despite Brexit. So I am sorry to invade your space, Mr Juncker, but you, the EU and your ideas are really past their sell-by date.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Mr President, our weakness is to be too often in the reaction, as on the judgment of the Court of Justice on Singapore or following the failure of multilateralism. Above all, we must react to a turning point in globalization characterized by the planning of our economy by foreign powers. Dumping, hostile investments, takeovers of strategic companies, increasingly strict rules for our companies abroad, unfair competition and the total lack of reciprocity are all involved. There was no agreement yesterday during the trilogue on the question of dumping. But the risk with such a tight schedule is that a mere delay may be seen as a failure. If it comes at the cost of the precision of our political message, especially on the burden of proof, then it is not expensive. Europe must protect itself without falling into protectionism. This message is clear. The uncertainty in our policies stems from our treaty which makes us walk on eggshells on our legal obligations. The ambitious draft regulations, which I have already read, should above all prevent us from stepping on our heads. We have wasted time and, in reality, we are losing jobs, our know-how and our technological advance in the hands of a country which, as we know, organizes the investments of its public and private companies. We are not against foreign investments but against strange investments, those which will ensure that our European products, and perhaps a future Apple iPhone, will one day be "designed" and assembled only in China!

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank President Juncker for his speech. President Juncker, I know that you are a deeply convinced European and, in your sixth scenario, I do not see a Europe which is divided or a several speed Europe, which is very positive. But, at the same time, you know that people are tired of words and promises and it is time for action from the Commission as well. The strongest tool which you possess as a Commission is the draft of your budget for the next multiannual financial framework. We should stop thinking about how to reduce the European budget but look for own resources. We should really focus on political priorities and the major priority is how to move from a Europe of divergence and inequalities towards a Europe of convergence, strong economic growth and social justice. Frankly speaking, I expected a stronger social dimension. We really need a European social action plan today in order to regain trust.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: - Madam president; Favorable winds, Mr. Juncker, it's true. We have left the euro crisis behind us. Now it remains for that bonanza to also be transferred to employment and social protection. I liked his speech, a political speech: freedom, equality, the rule of law. It is true, in the European Union, sometimes it seems that we care more about solving financial crises than social crises or political crises. Brexit, for example, is our biggest failure, and here I hear about Brexit as just another free trade deal. From now on, Europe is no longer synonymous with the European Union and it is not up to the European Union exclusively to defend the idea of ​​Europe. We must avoid that, in the future after Brexit, there will again be two different Europes within our continent. I share your statement about the courts of law, respect for European courts and national courts, and that the rule of law is part of the raison d'être of the European Union. There are countries that are attacking the separation of powers and, in my country, in one region, the Constitution is being attacked. Nationalism spreads and spreads like a virus. The Constitution of each Member State is also the Constitution of the European Union, the unity of my country is also the unity of the European Union. That is why the Commission also has - and I share it - the responsibility to defend the Constitution of the Member States and the responsibility to defend the unity of the Member States. The rule of law is born from individual freedom, but it grows and lives thanks to the law and the courts of justice.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, I am disappointed. First, your Last Chance Commission is entering its last useful year and while, for the left, the account is not there, you do not present us with a battle plan for this end of term of office, but a vision of the future. Of which act. In this perspective, you are sketching out a new European contract on which we can agree on a certain number of social, fiscal and public freedoms priorities. But to move from words to deeds - as you said this morning - we would need a serious budget and this is my second disappointment. Of course, you tell us your preference to get out of the current budgetary straitjacket, but you stay on the doorstep. Nothing on the advisability and urgency of breaking the 20% cap. Nothing specific on the urgency of integrating own resources, on the advisability today of a tax on multinationals, which would have both the virtue of tax justice and that of filling two coffers: that of the European Union and that of the Member States. Finally, I am disappointed with economic and monetary democracy. It does not matter whether it is an assembly of the euro zone, or this Assembly, endowed with new prerogatives, what we want is a Parliament, because it is the democratic body which must be able to decide on economic choices, including questioning the austerity dogma, without being limited to being an ordoliberal policeman.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President of the Commission, today you have drawn a broad picture of the future of Europe by talking about many things that can be shared, starting with the defense of Europe's strategic interests. Indeed, according to some analysts, this would be the geopolitically most interesting and relevant message of all her speech. I would also like to talk about the reform of the Dublin Treaty - for us a priority and unavoidable: I would like to deepen - the need to support European industry more and better, starting with small and medium-sized enterprises, youth unemployment. But in the few seconds I have left, I limit myself to asking you one question, because you have recognized that this Europe needs more democracy. And so you did not say something that, in my opinion, is fundamental: this House, directly elected by the citizens, has no legislative initiative, as you know. Don't you think it should be on the agenda? You see, we would catch the wind with our sails, as you wished, if the citizens had a clear perception that they are always at the center of all our actions.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: - Madam President, years ago Europe has ceased to be an important part of our dreams, and that project, synonymous with development, opportunities and equality has become a very different scenario: precariousness, austerity, economic crisis. Today, those of us who believe in the European project will share the need and concern to share and advance new policies for the European Union. The European social pillar must be a priority axis. It is not possible that in the Europe of the 21st century there will continue to be a working class that lives below the threshold of poverty. Let us talk about the fight against climate change, about confronting the fight against terrorism, about asylum and immigration policy. It's fundamental. Thank you, Mr Juncker, for your reference to the rule of law. Europe is a project based on democracy and, therefore, it is essential to ensure respect for the constitutional order in each and every Member State. There is no time to lose, it is necessary to address the changes now. Diversity, dialogue, respect, cohesion: that defines Europe. Let us not allow anything or anyone to change the meaning of this word.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I most welcome the emphasis on the idea of Europe as a community of values, placed by Mr Juncker, and the need to ensure freedom, equality and the rule of law all over the EU so that there are no longer second-class citizens in our integration project. Still, European citizens belonging to national autochthonous or language minorities can be treated very differently depending on where they live. Only last week in Romania, the Hungarian minority language Catholic High School of Târgu Mureș ceased to exist because of the systematic harassment by various authorities where hundreds of minority-language speaking children were insecure until the last moment about whether they would be able to attend their school again.  What do the parents of these children who are interrogated by the Romanian anti-corruption agency for enrolling their children in the school feel about the rule of law that the EU is supposed to guarantee them? The EU still has a long way to go to ensure its values and prevent discriminative practices. More than 60 million citizens expect acknowledgement of their existence by the EU institutions.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Madam President! We are currently experiencing a strange situation across Europe. Thanks to Brexit and Trump, approval rates for the Union are increasing, but the state of the Union is in contrast. We are far from having the migration issue under control and the upswing you cited has not caught on everyone. Entire regions, especially in the east, feel left behind. In addition, there is a dangerous and growing gap between East and West. I think it is good that Vice-President Timmermans is following a very clear line here. Yes, the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must ensure that the Charter of Fundamental Rights is respected. Of course, this also requires a willingness to engage in dialogue. I miss that especially with those whose political business model consists in making a name for themselves at the expense of Brussels. But there is a way to counter this: Brussels must become better, more democratic and more social, and you have provided a good template for this.

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean (PPE).
text: – Madam President, congratulations to President Juncker for his strong messages on the State of the Union today. For the first time in years, our citizens show growing faith in the EU and its direction. Their confidence is justifying proof that the EU remains where they put their hopes and where they want to live and prosper. For all this, we are obliged to keep our word and deliver on what we have promised. Some will say we need more ambition; I say we need stability, consolidation and proper implementation of EU policies. We need to defend our values to make sure our citizens can fully benefit from their rights and freedoms, and that the competitiveness of our companies is both defended and supported. Yet, the engine of our internal market is not fairness, but competition. It has to be a real one. You cannot send people home, telling them to go and compete in their own country while we protect our national markets. The internal market is not the sum of national markets. The State of the Union should also be about how we can offer more Europe for everyone.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, trade policy is one of the most powerful tools we have and, even though we know that it cannot solve everything by itself, it must be continually updated and improved to respond to global challenges. We appreciated that he began his speech with this and in particular his words on transparency but we believe that we must insist in at least three directions. First, because it continues to be an authentically European policy, open to democratic confrontation but without losing the prerogative of unity. And for this the European Parliament will have to be increasingly involved in all stages of the process and not just to give the last word. Second, for the chapter on sustainable development to be effective and binding. The path undertaken by the Commission is well, but at this point it is necessary to continue the reflection, make it practical and endow it with resources. Parliament is ready to make its contribution. Third, because commercial openness is based on fairness and reciprocity. And exceptions are not possible, regardless of who our trading partner is, if we do not want to put our entire economic system at risk.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: - Dear President, Dear President Juncker, first of all allow me to congratulate you and thank you for today's speech which gives a new impetus and which encourages all those who, like President Juncker, love Europe. I was going to challenge him here that is not among his immediate concerns, at least those he presented here. This year there was a great wave of fires in Portugal, with tragic consequences, there have been floods all over Europe, even now in Poland with tragic consequences, last year we saw several earthquakes in Italy, also this year in Greece, we know that with the climate change there will be many of these accidents. It would not be time for us to create a genuine European Civil Protection Force that, on the one hand, is also closely linked to internal security - it may also have rescue missions in the Mediterranean, etc. - but who could, whenever there is a major disaster of these, within a few hours, move to the disaster site and help national forces to combat these disasters and mitigate their consequences? I think that it is time to have a European civil protection force that, in fact, in many respects, would be an embryo of what could become true European armed forces.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: - Mister President! Mr President Juncker! You gave a speech that more than meets your own standards. She was bold. In addition to many correct demands, which we support, there was one basic idea: The East needs the West, but the West also needs the East. I would like to add: The same applies to the relationship between north and south. I have seldom been so disgusted in recent years as in the times when I had to read in the gazettes of my own newspapers in Germany: “If you want coal, sell us Corfu”. That was the stupid gossip of politicians that was quoted, and I thank you for not only never taking part in it, but for resisting it. Mr Weber! I know that this is not your standard, but we also cannot say that the economic policy of the European Union is geared towards who is in power somewhere. Whether Greece gets a haircut is a technical question. But it has nothing to do with whether and when your party friends should rule again. We need a new policy - a policy of solidarity for the south so that the south can develop. But we need the south in a burning world. (Applause)

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I welcome what I have heard from Mr Juncker. Our goal now is to make it happen, and my appeal is to the Member States. Their main responsibility is for how effective or ineffective the European Union is. Very often, unfortunately, national selfishness prevails over solidarity. Next year, the European Union must prove that these promises of physical and social security for European citizens will come true. Here, we must focus our efforts on greater cooperation in the fields of defense, the fight against terrorism, the protection of the external borders, the restriction of migrant flows and the sharing of the burden in solidarity. I welcome the proposal for a European intelligence agency, finally for a European cyber agency. In addition, the European Union must not deviate from its commitments in the fields of regional development, competitiveness, innovation and health, which directly affect the standard of living of European citizens. Now is the time for decisive steps towards more integration where the crisis has hit us hardest. The euro area must be consolidated, but not at the expense of the integrity of the European Union. I welcome what you said, that we do not need a separate Eurozone budget and we do not need a separate Eurozone parliament. The European Union must not be divided into a core and a periphery.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: - Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, I would like to thank you today for the courage, vision and wisdom of your speech, but especially for the strength to oppose those who favored division and double standards in the multi-speed Europe project. I share with you, on behalf of the Romanian delegation, on behalf of my group and on behalf of my country, the ideas and the vision and we assure you of all your support. If we look at your speech, I agree: in foreign policy, security, defense, Europe can be a serious, important player, only if we are united, if we speak with one voice and if there is complete trust between all members. If we look at cohesion policy, it is fundamental to the implementation of the principle of solidarity and the reduction of disparities, and I therefore ask and ask you to pay attention to the continuation of this fundamental instrument of the Union. Union and solidarity mean, yes, that there are no double standards in cases of enhanced cooperation, that Schengen cannot be refused when conditions are created, that the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism cannot continue, if it is no longer necessary and if food quality , as you said, it is the same for all Europeans.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank President Juncker for his speech. It is good to remind us about how things have changed since last year. Just to remind all of us: growth is up, unemployment is down, employment is up, we have a stable financial sector and improved fiscal policy. This is just the economy; you mentioned more. You can say that these are just numbers, but these are not just numbers. This means that life for people in Europe is better and that is what people expect from us. As you know from the past, the good times are exactly when people make a lot of mistakes. You urge us not to make mistakes during these good times and, instead, to do many good things. I agree and I appreciate it. One of the obstacles that I want to stress is that trust is still missing: trust among politicians, trust among people, trust among countries. I hope that in your next speech you will remind us that this has improved. This is very important. At the end of your speech, you mentioned that we should not be over-cautious. This is exactly the way to make mistakes and to miss opportunities. I hope we will not miss them.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: –Commission President Juncker, you gave an optimistic speech. It was a little hypothermic, but that's how we know you. But it was an optimistic speech with elements that we from our group will support with great enthusiasm, such as making the mandate in the trade agreements transparent, the leadership in the field of climate, protecting our industry and ensuring that more democracy is coming. Yet we also remain a bit hungry. After three years of promises about the triple-A for social policy, after three years of talking about social dumping, we have not yet achieved any results. When are we really going to ensure that our people receive equal pay for equal work? When are we going to ensure that our social rights and access to social security are really anchored in European legislation? At the end of this mandate, that will determine what balance we will take and how we as Social Democrats view this Commission.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Mr President of the Commission, thank you for your speech and thank you for taking up sound labor market rules. Healthier labor market rules will be crucial for cohesion in the EU. Nothing else can be as strong. There is nothing more divisive than social dumping, which means that workers must compete by selling their labor as cheaply as possible. It is an obscenity for Europe. On that point, there are many who are hoping for you, that is to say, a control authority, but first a posting directive and strong social partners - no authority can take over - and eventually a social protocol to add to the treaty. As for your thoughts on the eurozone, I must point out that many of us assume that you have full respect for the countries that have said no. In Sweden, for example, a clear majority in a referendum has said no to the euro, and this must of course be fully respected.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: - President Juncker, the people are waiting for us to show our Europe immediately, against populism and extremism. Our Europe must support, strengthen and reward structural change. Only then will there be prosperity for all. The Union Minister for Finance must oversee the consistent implementation of the rules but also reward progress, encouraging citizens. Our Europe must be fortified against terrorism. The automatic exchange of information was delayed, as was the creation of the European Intelligence Agency. Our Europe hosts millions of refugees but, at the same time, the Member States must share the responsibility and when that does not happen there will be sanctions. You owe a good word to the Greeks, President Juncker, who, together with the Italians, took on the historic responsibility of hosting the refugees. Our Europe must provide sustainable jobs for young people, and this is certainly not achieved through research budget cuts.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam president;President Juncker, in this final stretch you have made your longest and most deliberate speech, but we demand more and, above all, concreteness: legal routes for migrants and refugees - the blue card is not enough for economically selective migration if there is no humanitarian visa;social pillar;decent work, especially for young people;fight against child poverty and inequality;against fraud and tax havens, after what we have seen in the PANA Investigation Commission;but, above all, the rule of law, which is the rule of law.Disobeying the judgments of the courts is not defending democracy or freedom of expression;it is breaking the law, it is committing a crime and it is the denial of Europe.And let's call things by their name;This can happen in Poland, Hungary or Catalonia: everywhere it is the negation of Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr Juncker, finally, after the five scenarios for change in the European Union, you have added a sixth scenario. The continuation of the same policy, with the same institutions and the same balances of the old political world. The policy of German Europe, the policy of austerity and the draconian stability pact, the anti-democratic eurozone with the uncontrollable Eurogroup and the mighty European Central Bank. The European Union of "banking" and the new European Monetary Fund, as tough and unpopular as the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). The European Union of "outsourcing", TTIP and CETA leading to the deindustrialisation of Europe and the "Chineseization" of European wages. European Union unemployment and youth marginalization. The European Union is flooded with millions of refugees and illegal immigrants. Mr Juncker, Europe's demographic problem is intertwined with poverty and unemployment and will not be solved by mass migration and "Muslimization". It will be solved with a policy that will support the European family.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr. president; Mr. Juncker, as you can see here, my party, the PNV, celebrated the Basque national holiday in 1932 under the slogan "Euskadi — Europe." That is why we like his proposals, but he failed to remember the women who suffer inequality and violence. We believe in the Union it describes: convinced and consistent partners supporting this plan; all in everything to protect, to empower and defend the people; Social Europe, open, refuge, united in the face of terror; more industry, support for the real economy, financial and political capacity; promote the single digital market for energy and transport, victims of the short-termism of many states; democratic values ​​and defense of the rights of all, including those of national minorities, that exist. And when, as in Catalonia, instead of recognizing that reality, it is preferred to suffocate without politics, without dialogue, a European problem is created. The Intergroup of Minorities in this Parliament calls for European mediation in its Strasbourg Manifesto, democracy so that no one can impose, but also so that no one can prevent a political solution to this problem.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, we must accept one thing for the Union today: that it remains steadfast in pursuing the same policies that have led to the impoverishment of peoples, the dismantling of the welfare state and labor relations, and the deepening and institutionalization of neoliberal austerity and memory policies. . Mr Juncker's sixth scenario follows the same logic of widening social and regional disparities and leads to a Union of many speeds, a Union of the rich core and the poor region. The strengthening of military capital, through the Defense Fund, and financial capital, through EMU, the Banking Union and the proposal for a Ministry of Finance, continues steadily. The policy of lack of solidarity with the refugees continues: instead of overturning the unacceptable agreement with Turkey, similar agreements are now being proposed with Libya and other countries. As the Left, we are in favor of overthrowing these policies of neoliberalism, inequality and poverty. We need more public investment to create decent jobs, we need a social Europe of solidarity and peace, we need a Europe in the interests of the people.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Commission! The Greens' motto for Europe is: "Stay critical of the EU, but stay!" We want a socially just, ecologically sustainable Union so that citizens can finally believe in it again. Cosmetic changes are simply not enough. You have made a couple of interesting suggestions, but as far as trade relations are concerned: The interests of large corporations are still in the foreground, transparency is still not what it should be in a democracy. What we need are fair trade agreements, otherwise any talk about combating the causes of displacement is really false. I liked your commitment to our freedoms such as the rule of law, that there should be European electoral lists for the next election, and also that you are now working with the European Parliament to change the rules for funding European parties and foundations in such a way that that right-wing, anti-European groups can no longer fill their coffers to incite against the Union and against the solidarity principle. Overall: It is not enough to describe the state of the Union. We have to get out of the situation again and ensure that this Union is really solidarity and credible for all citizens.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, in Mr Juncker’s position I think it would be a very good idea to watch television every now and then. These days, if you do so, you can see really good news from Syria and from Iraq. The wars are almost over, rebuilding has begun and refugees are returning home. Do you not think – and please answer this question – that it is high time to fundamentally reconsider the relocation and resettlement quota idea of the European Union? Stop bashing Hungary, stop preaching to us about solidarity, and talk about solidarity to those strong, healthy, young Syrian and other men who should go home and rebuild their countries. That is solidarity with those nations.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I really welcome the speech by the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, because I consider it to be of historical value and importance, because it focuses on the core of the creation of the European Union, which is its principles and values. We agree, Mr Juncker, that the European Union must henceforth take into account freedom, equality and the rule of law. We will defend it with all our might, because in this way we will be led to prosperity and a strong European Union. I believe, however, that we must no longer show any other tolerance and no discount in countries like Turkey, which have shown that they respect no principle and no value. As a European citizen, I can be proud when I also enjoy my freedom, which I do not enjoy now, because I can not return to the house where I was born, because I am deprived of a country that violates human rights inside, but and in my homeland. These countries cannot knock on the door of the European Union and we can in no way reward them, either by upgrading the Customs Union or by other privileges and funding. The message is strong: a strong Europe in principles and values ​​and we will move forward together, dear President of the European Commission.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, thank you for your important speech and for your truly pro-European vision, a sail also driven by the newfound greater pro-European spirit of some important countries, by the fears of many citizens, especially young British people about the impact Brexit, especially from the awareness that sustainable development, security, defense, foreign policy, greater justice, the role of Europe in the world can only be guaranteed by more Europe, a free, united, just and reformed Europe in its institutions, but also in its priorities. But the construction of common values ​​and a shared future for the new generations passes through a cultural and educational dimension of the European project, as main axes. Thirty years after the launch of the Erasmus project, we ask you to propose that at least the number of young people eligible in the next programming has finally doubled - currently only 5% of young Europeans - and, therefore, that resources be doubled and that 'European Year of Cultural Heritage, which you have rightly mentioned and which will be presented in Milan, in December, together with the new cultural diplomacy for which I thank Vice President Mogherini and Commissioner Navracsics - an extraordinary opportunity for the construction and sharing of common values , shared memory, intercultural dialogue but also development, social cohesion and new quality employment.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - Mr Juncker, we are all talking about a more democratic Europe, about reclaiming the hearts and minds of the citizens.As a Member of Parliament, I try to keep a finger on the pulse close to home, because that's where our democracy starts.I therefore fully agree with what my colleague Terricabras from Catalonia said a moment ago.Hundreds of Catalans colored the streets of Barcelona last weekend.Their peaceful optimistic pursuit of deciding their own political future within the EU should please us all as Democrats.You know that the political problem between Barcelona and Madrid is being heard in court today, where judges and politicians in Madrid are ordering officials to boycott the October 1 referendum.Media is being intimidated, you know that.Is this the Europe we stand for?Well, we as Flemings certainly not.It is for a Europe that respects citizens and their democratic aspirations.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: - President Juncker, the real situation in Europe is not what you described to us. Workers see in the Union the reduction of wages and salaries. Retirees see new pension cuts in the new Union Finance Minister. The unemployed see in the Union budget the "carrot" of private investment for job creation, but also at the same time the "whip" of wage cuts and the violation of labor and legal protection. Mr Juncker, in your sermons and hymns on Democracy, yours as well as Mr Macron's recently in Athens, European citizens see the violation of democracy, the burial of the 2015 referendum of the Greek people and the statements of your Commissioner, Mr Moscovici, who scandalously characterized the imposition of austerity in Greece in terms of the democratic process. Mr President, we want a Europe of sovereign states on the basis of equality and democracy, a Europe in which we work together on economic, industrial and environmental issues, but for the benefit of the peoples and to the detriment of multinationals and, of course, a Europe of peace and friendship. and not a Europe of armaments and wars.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I have been speaking, it seems to me, for a little over an hour. It was difficult for you, but it was even more difficult for me because I have very painful sciatica, so I have to rest a bit and therefore cannot answer you in detail. I would simply say that it would be wise if, on the points where the Commission has already taken initiatives, those who are concerned join their efforts with ours to legislate. Particularly in the social field, Parliament and the Council are seized of a whole series of proposals which I did not have to re-enumerate or describe in front of you because you are seized of these texts. The Commission should not be held responsible if the Posted Workers Directive has not yet been reviewed. We have made a proposal and we agree to continue this work, and what I am saying about the Posted Workers Directive, I could say about other proposals as well. You will benefit from reading the letter of intent that Vice-President Timmermans and I sent to the Speaker of Parliament. You will find there in detail, and over many pages, the exact description of the Commission's intentions. We will closely involve the Council and Parliament in the work which will lead us, by 24 October at the latest, to adopt the Commission work program, a program that I would like Parliament to be able to accompany with a harmonious resolution. Finally, I would like us to end the year, in terms of the programs of intentions and ambitions, with a joint declaration by the presidents of the three institutions. Thank you and I apologize for having to leave you. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thanks Jean-Claude, we can recommend some good doctors to cure you definitively, so that you can always be strong and answer all our questions.I also thank Vice President Mogherini for the effort she made yesterday with a long performance in the Chamber.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, I wish Mr Juncker a speedy recovery. Of course, from what I heard before when he spoke to us, I thought for a moment that I was dreaming in paradise for all these achievements of Europe. But the account of the current European Commission's achievements is more poverty, unemployment, illegal immigration, the uprooting of young people through internal migration and the blood of innocent people by jihadist Islamists. But the biggest achievement is the complete lack of democracy. Any opposing view is detached and targeted as nationalistic and populist. The political elites of Europe can not stand criticism. But you endure and are not moved by the disastrous results of your globalized policy. Shameless self-promotion for Ballistic Products and a great bargain on a neat little knife for you. The Greeks, the Italians, the French, the Hungarians, the Poles, and even the British who voted to leave the Union do not want more or less Europe, but a fairer, more democratic, more secure Europe with respect for national sovereignty and integrity. of the Member States.

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (NL) Mr President, anyone who says that the European Union is doing better is lying around or living on Fantasy Island. There are now 50,000 terrorists from Islamic countries in the EU. Every month there is a major attack or one prevented at the last minute. Every day women and children are raped and people robbed, abused and murdered by immigrants from Islamic countries. There is no security in the EU anymore. This parliament itself is turning into a bunker and you still deny the danger of Islam. You pay the Libyan coastguard millions of taxpayers' money because the EU coastguard does not and cannot do its job because of the political unwillingness of the Juncker Commission. And there are still millions of unemployed people in the Union and the debt problem is still not resolved and the EU is still losing its share of the world market. The EU is not doing well. The United Kingdom has now left the Titanic, the eastern member states that have established a sensible immigration stop are being denounced and chased away. But a dictatorship like Turkey is backed by billions to join. And that is the state of the Union: economic failure, social failure, security failure. Mr. Juncker - and he has now run away - please stop this election propaganda and start lifting this failed project.

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group.- Mr President, at the outbreak of World War II, British MP Leo Amery criticized Prime Minister Chamberlain Cromwell in the House of Commons for his misconduct or inaction, and I quote: 'You have been herelet us go out of us for God's love. "Mr Juncker, I do not apply this to you, but I would certainly suggest that you remind those who are constantly itchy to raise the hands of the countries of Eastern and Central Europe, and those who have an interest in strengthening their economies at the expense of other Community members.And I’m not a strong sailor, but it seems to me that sailing downwind isn’t the highest speed of a boat.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, in the debate we had this morning, there was no self-criticism on the effects of the austerity policies that have been imposed on the people. However, there is no way out for European construction without a new social project. Much has been said about democracy, but I believe that the combination of a single President of the Commission and of the Council - we do not know by whom he would be appointed, moreover - and the transformation of the Stability Pact into a European Monetary Fund - when we know the function of the International Monetary Fund - are very worrying, since we are going to witness both the centralization of powers and greater surveillance of the state budgets, and therefore a strengthening of this same austerity. There is nothing good to be expected from that side and it is contrary to what is being said, moreover, by saying that we want to make a more democratic Europe.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: au nom du groupe ALDE. – Monsieur le Président, je veux simplement dire à M. Le Hyaric que la chose la plus importante, c’est qu’on peut choisir nous-mêmes nos leaders au niveau européen. J’espère donc que le GUE va soutenir l’idée commune de listes transnationales, qui sont la réalisation de ce rêve d’avoir notre mot à dire dans la désignation de ceux qui dirigent l’Europe. For the other points, I have only two conclusions. Mr de Graaff says that things are going badly for the European Union; I think things are going badly for the populists and the nationalists in the European Union. He is mistaken. The problems at the moment are in his movement, not with the European Union. He is even saying that there is no increase, for example, in the number of jobs. Well, everybody knows that there is an increase in the number of jobs in the European Union. My second conclusion, Mr Timmermans, is that, hopefully, you have seen here in the centre of this House a broad support for the ambitious programme that Mr Juncker has presented. You have to take that on board and use it as a tool with our Member States and with the Council, so that from their side there will be the same support for that ambitious programme.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! I must admit that I am a bit surprised that President Juncker has said little about the Brexit conclusions. Whoever, like me, believes that the British exit is a great failure and a great loss for the Union would expect the President to tell us that some of the causes of Brexit have been eliminated. Meanwhile, nothing was said about it, and it was even given the impression that Britain's exit from the EU was a success. I think this is not a success but a failure. President Juncker said he had proposed several scenarios, and there was a discussion or debate. I have to ask: what kind of debate? We can talk about a debate when we do not know yet what conclusions will be drawn. Here, however, these conclusions had already been expressed, and even before they were pronounced, it was known what they were supposed to be. These conclusions are "even more of the same" or, in European jargon, "more Europe". Is this the right solution? Are we taken seriously? If we participate in a debate, we listen to arguments and respond to them. Please note the words that have been said here today about those with a different point of view. There was talk of idiots, the virus, extremists, and even the threat of their money being taken from them. Is this a serious conversation? If everything is to continue this way, it is now possible to predict what will happen: sooner or later the next steps will be taken, ie 'more Europe'. There will be one chairman, another minister, then another minister. It does not matter what is happening, we must at all costs - as one of the gentlemen said - keep going. Well, no - no need to go any further, ladies and gentlemen. You have to look at what is happening. One of my colleagues rightly said that it is not true that breaking the rules of law and order concerns the latter, others. It is happening here, it is happening within the Union European.The rules are repeatedly broken by the great institutions of the European Union, including the European Commission, and the application of the principle of double standards has become compulsive.This means that there are groups, institutions or parties that are allowed to do virtually everything and get away with it with impunity, and others, obviously weaker and smaller, who are allowed very little.So let's start with tidying up our own yard.President Juncker spoke about the renovation.So let's start with the renovation.Let the Commission start with the renovation of the Commission, and only then we will build some other super institutions, because we must first cure the disease that affects the European institutions.May it happen as soon as possible.

name: Presidente. –
text: Since this is an extremely important debate and we have been flexible in the course of it, the Verts / EFA Group would, as a rule, have used up all of its speaking time.However, in the reply phase, if Mr Ska Keller and Mr Philippe Lamberts wish to speak for a minute, they have the right.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, I get a free minute, it is sales day today, I was not even aware, thank you Mr President, you are too kind! I just want to say - I see there is only Mr. Timmermans left and in the end maybe not bad - because Mr. Timmermans, I hear all the language of your boss, I hear everything he wants to do, I hear him talking to me about a Europe where there will be no second-class citizens. That's what he says, but today some of our citizens must continue to swallow products that you refuse to ban in the name of "better regulation". Today, there are towers that are burning, as in the United Kingdom, because we do not want to ban products that flare too easily and we do not want to make European standards for these products that resist fire, because we will be satisfied with national standards. So I would simply like to ask that the Commission join the action of all your legislative proposals with the word of your boss.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that a Europe that works is in the interest of the citizens. A Europe that does not work goes against the citizens and provokes the dissatisfaction of the citizens. Let's face it frankly: there are forces in Europe, and in this Parliament too, working to make Europe not work, in order to take the votes in their countries. Exactly the opposite of what we want: we want a visionary project for a Europe that works and gives citizens answers. First: a Parliament with legislative power. Tell me all of you which parliament in the world does not have the possibility to propose to make a law? No parliament in the world, except the European Parliament. First innovation: it serves the citizens, it serves democracy. Second: transnational lists. Mr Weber, the card is ready for you and all your colleagues in the popular group to join the club of transnational lists, a form of European democracy. Third: a President elected directly by the citizens and in this case the double hat is fine - the same person with two hats - but without the popular investiture, attention: we must guarantee the popular investiture. And then: the European treasury, the federal budget, the European Central Bank as a lender of last resort. All this accompanied and driven by European culture, because European culture is the real mastic of European integration, it is a dream, it is a desire for us, it is a program, it is a political project. For us it is the utopia of the possible.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the debate today showed that Jean-Claude Juncker can count on the support of Parliament for this programme and we showed political diversity. That is the nature of a parliament. I just want to react to three points. One is about the debate on legal migration. Everybody is in favour of high—skilled workers being able to arrive in Europe with a blue card. There is no debate about this. But we have to be frank. Do we really think that more legal migration to the European Union will solve the illegal migration problem? How many Africans do we invite to come to Europe? Do we really think that this will solve the problem? On behalf of my Group, I think that, first of all, we have to bear in mind the millions of young Europeans who at the moment have no jobs. We cannot say to them that we are opening the door for more legal migration when they themselves have no jobs.   The second point is about the transnational list. Everybody wants to strengthen European democracy and I have to be clear to Jean-Claude Juncker that the PPE is not in favour of this transnational list because we are not convinced – Guy – about the main argument because, yes, the European Parliament is more than 27 individual votes. That is clear. But, sorry, the overwhelming majority of all the Members of this Parliament show every day that we are not only national MEPs, but we are doing a transnational job today. We think in all our interests and that is why an additional list is not necessary for this. I am from Germany. I cannot elect Angela Merkel in my constituency in Bavaria because in Germany we only have regional lists. So if that works even in Germany, it can also work in Europe.  Finally, on the social union, so for Gianni. First of all, very seriously, when we talk about climate change, the Socialists are in favour of fighting against climate change, as are the Greens and the PPE. When we talk about trade, then we have a good understanding that we are in favour of trade and when we talk about a social union, then please admit that other Groups are also defending social principles in this European Union. Social policy is not occupied by the Socialists, frankly speaking, it is an issue for all of us.  When you ask us, as the PPE, to look into the social union, look first at reality. In countries where the Socialists govern or governed – France or Italy for example – we have a big unemployment problem, and in a lot of countries where the PPE is governing – in Germany and in Ireland – we have a good economic situation. That is why we are working on the social union and you are only speaking about the social union.  (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The discussion on the future of the Union opens, which will have to see the European Parliament at the center of all initiatives because if President Juncker calls for a more democratic Europe, we are the physical representation of the most democratic Europe.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: written. - Years ago, the European Union ceased to occupy an important part of our dreams. This project, synonymous with right, development and opportunities, became a very different scenario: economic crisis, austerity and inequality. Today, those of us who believe in the European project should share this concern and therefore the need to promote changes. The social pillar must be a reality and not a mere announcement. We have to work to guarantee decent wages, recover the rights of the working class, guarantee a pension framework and fight against child poverty. Of course, without forgetting that the European Union is a project based on democratic guarantees and therefore it is essential to guarantee respect for the constitutional order and the rule of law in all member states. There is no time to lose, there are no excuses, because the challenge is important; that the Union stops being part of the problem to become the most important part of the solution. Diversity, dialogue, cooperation, respect, cohesion and equality. This defines the European Union. Let us not allow anything or anyone to change the meaning of the word.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - After a year of discussions on the future direction, it should be clearer which path the European Union wants to take in the future. Our joint effort must be to improve mutual cooperation. The individual Member States and their leaders must be able to better communicate the results and benefits of the functioning of the European Union to their own citizens. At present, we most often encounter the term so-called the core of the European Union. All the Member States must show a common effort and effort to move closer to the goals set in the individual areas, which are very ambitious, and we will certainly not achieve them other than working together. Here too, however, volunteering must be the basic principle, as it is when accession to the European Union. Deeper cooperation will only be an opportunity, never an obligation. There is therefore no need to attach importance in the future to the excuses of some of the leaders of the Member States that they are being pushed into something. Citizens expect the European Union to solve problems, and it is therefore essential that they receive answers to their questions as soon as possible.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - Mr J-C, President of the Commission. In the Juncker report on the situation and prospects of the European Union, we heard a number of interesting ideas and suggestions on how to make the European Union more united, more democratic, more secure and better able to meet the challenges of the time. I welcome a number of the proposals, especially the need to legislate for common EU social standards. The President said that if we wanted to avoid social fragmentation and social dumping in Europe, the Member States must do so as soon as possible, and in November at the latest. Gothenburg Summit, to agree on a European Pillar of Social Rights. He called for work on a European Union of Social Standards with a common understanding of what is socially just. I also welcome the proposal to set up a European labor institution, thus strengthening cooperation between labor market institutions at all levels and better managing cross-border situations, as well as taking further initiatives in support of fair mobility. We very much look forward to concrete legislative proposals being submitted as soon as possible. I also very much welcome the Commission's intention to ensure that lower quality goods are not sold in Eastern Europe and that our workers are not discriminated against in the EU labor market. Equal pay for equal work must be ensured. I am also glad that the President of the European Commission mentioned the forthcoming century of the restoration of the Lithuanian state as a very important event and stated that without our country the European Union would not be full-fledged.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Brexit disaster and some concomitant international events seem to have created in European citizens a greater awareness of the role played by the Union at European and global level. Paradoxically, a moment of deep crisis can turn into a new impetus for the European project. It is up to the European institutions - all of them - not to waste the next 18 months that separate us from the 2019 elections, when European citizens will seek answers. The adoption of the new Multiannual Financial Framework is urgent - for which an ambitious proposal on own resources is needed to increase the EU budget and reduce dependence on Member States. We need to change the EU's approach to migration, changing our vision of Africa: from a continent of problems to a continent of opportunity. It is essential to work on the issue of security, paving the way for the creation of a European federal intelligence system to prevent future attacks. Above all, after years of economic crisis, it is necessary to optimize the investments available and work on the social pillar to guarantee free medical assistance, adequate housing and proper nutrition for families in conditions of poverty and decent working conditions for all forms of employment.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – I believe there is more to Juncker’s vision for Europe’s future than markets and fiscal rules, and that did shine through his speech. However, he has remained too beholden to the mess he inherited from the Barroso era, when markets and finance ruled our Continent, and their champions were put in charge of a mess of their own making. We were told we would face a lost decade if we did not put our taxpayers on the line to save the financial sector. Yet a lost decade we had, but with a haemorrhage of public money and of our youth. The glimpses of optimism that shone through Juncker’s speech, his last one with a full political year ahead of him at the Commission’s helm, are overcast with dark clouds from far right populist quarters. We may have got some reprieve from the recent electoral cycle, but they are still lurking, ready to exploit the deterioration of basic social conditions for many, and to stoke fear and hatred against easy, vulnerable targets. What is more is that big business keeps on dodging tax, and the fiscal constraints imposed on very different economies, keep on tearing our social fabric and the sense of common purpose among the peoples of the EU.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
