text: written.- I welcome this year's State of the Union from Mr Juncker.In my eyes he gave hope.After the numerous crises in recent years, it has shown that we are on the right track.Europe has wind in its sails again - a good picture to describe how things are in Europe.We are moving forward, but the goal still seems uncertain.I therefore support Mr Juncker in our need to win back the hearts and minds of Europeans.We have to act now so that citizens can see that we understand their concerns in Europe and that we have the will to change.Citizens need to see and understand the added value of the EU again.Many of the points Juncker raised may seem like visions, but we need visionaries again in Europe.It remains to be seen how the visions will develop in detail.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have repeatedly emphasized in my parliamentary work that the European Union must pursue a consistent policy towards the Western Balkans if it is to maintain the commitment of the candidate countries to European integration and values. The candidate countries in the Western Balkans need a clear message, so I welcome what President Juncker said in his State of the Union speech on enlargement policy. I am pleased that, after some somewhat contradictory statements in the past, it has been made clear and clear that, in future, the European Union is ready to add new Member States to its ranks, that the number of EU Member States will not stop at twenty-seven. This political message would have been needed before, but better later than ever. Now that it has become clear that there is the political will, I would call once again on the European Commission and the governments of the countries of the Western Balkans to seize this opportunity and work to speed up and deepen the accession negotiations. Thank you for listening.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The EU's responsibilities in the deep crisis Europe has plunged into, in the unbearable imbalances and inequalities between states, have been deliberately concealed in this speech. As has become clear, the aim is to force an escape forward. To insist on the same paths, the same policies and guidelines that brought us to the economic and social disaster. But now in a reinforced dose. More federalism, more neoliberalism, more militarism. The direction that the President of the European Commission has come to announce, speaking on behalf of the beneficiaries and principals of European capitalist integration, is not an inevitability, nor is it something that the workers and peoples of Europe have to conform to. On the contrary. Europe's real future is not limited to the scenarios that the EU now sets for its own future. It will be the struggle of the workers and peoples of Europe, for the right to their sovereign development and for the rupture with the constraints that prevent it, that will define the ways that the future of the continent will be made. This struggle will pave the way for a project of partnership for solidarity between sovereign states and equal in rights, based on mutual benefit, peace and social progress. A project that, as it becomes increasingly clear, requires the defeat of the EU.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – The President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, presented today (13.09.2017) his annual State of the Union speech, in which he addressed the biggest issues and challenges of the present EU. I welcome the intention to escape from the multi-speed scenario that could place Poland, along with the other Member State outside of the euro area, in a less favourable position. Having in mind the deepening divide between the East and the West, the old Member States and the new ones, I find the commitment to the united and cooperating Europe as a fundament for a positive future development of the EU. Jean-Claude Juncker also mentioned the topics regarding double standards of food and the posting of workers in the single market, reacting to a problem of different wages for the same job. I believe that the rules to tackle those urgent issues are in place, thus we should focus on their effective application, as President Juncker also implied. We are not in need for new laws, we are in need for more effective legislation enforcement tools. Referring to the conclusion of his speech I hope that the sun will shine long enough for fixing the roof of Europe completely.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: signed up. - I liked the sixth scenario that you presented as personal, but I'm worried because no one can do anything alone. I thought you were presenting us with a scenario of the team, of the Commission. I liked what you said not only because you pronounced the name of my country, recognizing its rights, but also because you emphasized the need for fair trade agreements and industry, things that I have always supported. But, Mr President, you have talked too little about social cohesion, even if you have talked about the importance of the East-West lungs. I would like you to review the way the Strategic Investment Fund is used so as not to have adverse effects on social cohesion. And you also need, Mr President, to find appropriate tools for implementing the measures, but also the effects. But use, Mr President, the same measuring instruments, don't change the standard for measuring effects. We need a united Europe, but with equal treatment for all citizens.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - Years ago, the European Union ceased to occupy an important part of our dreams. This project, synonymous with right, development and opportunities, became a very different scenario: economic crisis, austerity and inequality. Today, those of us who believe in the European project should share this concern and therefore the need to promote changes. The social pillar must be a reality and not a mere announcement. We have to work to guarantee decent wages, recover the rights of the working class, guarantee a pension framework and fight against child poverty. Of course, without forgetting that the European Union is a project based on democratic guarantees and therefore it is essential to guarantee respect for the constitutional order and the rule of law in all member states. There is no time to lose, there are no excuses, because the challenge is important; that the Union stops being part of the problem to become the most important part of the solution. Diversity, dialogue, cooperation, respect, cohesion and equality. This defines the European Union. Let us not allow anything or anyone to change the meaning of the word.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The most important issue today is the future of the Union: whether the bloc of 27 Member States will stay together or become two speeds, leaving the missing out on the periphery. In his speech, President Juncker committed himself to preserving the unity of the EU, a major step forward from last year’s White Paper. This means recognizing that a multi-speed Europe is causing serious damage not only to those who are lagging behind, but also to 'core Europe': the former are not only affected by the depletion of EU funds, the failure to shape policies that benefit them, and the need for coherent foreign policy action. lack of it can cause serious damage. The risks for the core countries are to allow the creation of a 'peripheral region' that carries political, economic and social insecurities, exposing the EU, including Russia, to influence. It is therefore important that President Juncker's 'Sixth Plan' addresses not only pan-European problems, but also those in the southern and eastern peripheries: social problems, helping non-eurozone countries, food quality, demonstrating the Commission's sensitivity to EU-wide problems. Equally important is the President's warning: assistance is important, but EU rules must be respected by everyone. This is not an option but a duty. President Juncker's plan is to be welcomed, but the devil lies in the details. That is why, as legislator, we must ensure that a 'Europe of equals' is truly a matter for all Member States.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: in writing. – This is an important moment for setting our priorities not only for the second part of the term, but also for the future of the EU. The EU has been going through a rough path, yet the way to overcome it is to work closer together. I would like to address one issue you have touched upon. I am glad to hear the encouragement for the Western Balkan countries, a region aspiring to become future members of the EU. We cannot afford to lose focus of this process. It is in our strategic interest to bring these countries to the Union. Therefore, I would appreciate if in preparation of scenarios for the future of the EU, we already bring the question of future enlargement to the table in a similar way we do now with Brexit. We need to be a clear and predictable partner, not only in the Western Balkans, but also in our close Neighbourhood. The State of the Union has to address the questions of our place and critical interests in the external policies. Our leaders, including you Mr President, have a crucial role in shaping our external partnerships.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: signed up. - The EU's priorities for the coming year must be accompanied by the adoption of concrete Commission initiatives on trade, pre-investment verification, cyber security. The EU needs to strengthen its projects to achieve an energy union, a security union, a capital markets union, a banking union and a digital single market. Trade will play a decisive role as it will create jobs and new opportunities for European businesses. Industry needs a new strategy because European industries must be kept in Europe and must be globally competitive in terms of innovation, digitization and decarbonisation. A solid legislative framework is needed to strengthen the digital market. Great strides have been made in the digital field - the removal of roaming charges, wifi access in public spaces, the agreement to use the 700 MHz radio band as support for 5G and smart vehicles. However, online commerce, copyright rules, securing online platforms and setting standards for cyber attacks remain to be strengthened. In addition to a single market and a monetary union, Europe needs a security union. The area of ​​Freedom, Security, Justice will never be complete without the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - You have expressed anguish for a Europe of peace, which many of us share. In essence, you focused on the importance of enforcing the Rule of Law to move forward in the future, emphasizing that it is not a choice but an obligation of all. I would add that the application of the rule of law throughout the EU is a fundamental issue for the existence of the EU because it concerns common values ​​that must be fully respected. For the application of the rule of law in labor matters, we congratulate the announcement of the establishment of a joint European Supervisory Authority to monitor the compliance of Member States with European legislation and in particular with court decisions to eliminate the social dumping that is observed. But while we are talking about the application of the basic rules of law, decisions of the EU Court of Fundamental Human Rights in the protection of private property and punishment of offenders, do not apply in the occupied territory of Cyprus but the occupation regime is rewarded. Thousands of European citizens, including me, are deprived of our paternal home and our land. The application of court decisions to labor is indeed important. But the implementation of EU Court rulings on the protection and enjoyment of private property concerns the existence and future of the EU.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union has faced significant, often dramatic, challenges over the past year. There were few who already envisioned the end, disintegration and collapse of the Union. Today, however, it must be said that the Union is beginning to overcome the difficulties. This is the case even if there is not much progress in the Brexit negotiations and the number of refugees has not fallen significantly. However, the biggest threat to the EU today is not these events, but rather the illiberal democracy represented by the Hungarian and Polish governments, which is fundamentally attacking the EU, the values ​​on which the EU is built. It is unacceptable that some Member States are unwilling to accept the judgment of the European Court of Justice. The danger is great not only because this ideology based on primitive images of enemies is easy to sell, but also because the EU does not have real means against these Member States. That is why one of the most important questions for the next period will be whether the Commission will have the political courage to take decisive action against governments that are consciously and regularly confronted with European values. A two- or multi-speed Europe is not the answer. After all, the consequence of this will be that the countries that have an anti-European government will remain. I am convinced that Europe needs more division today, but rather close unity.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: written. - Dear President of the Commission, in your speech today you put your finger in some European wounds. If you warn against the fact that there should be no second-class citizens in Europe, then we are at the heart of the social question. Europe will or will not be social. This means that we can no longer look the other way when a worker in Eastern Europe earns less than half that of a worker in Western Europe. Nor should we look the other way when every second young person in southern Europe has no job and at the same time young people across Europe are only precariously employed. We need a European Union of social standards - you have my full support for this, Mr Juncker. You also have my full support with your proposal to create a European labor market authority. There is also no way around finally revising the Posting of Workers Directive. The principle: equal pay for equal work in the same place must finally become a reality. Let's get to work!

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: written. - The atmosphere ahead of the German Bundestag elections is very expectant, although the direction is clear. The German-French intergovernmental working group has been sitting for months to outline behind closed doors a new direction for Europe. The development of the federation continues, there is a desire to increase the solidarity of the member states, the European Stability Mechanism will become the EU Monetary Fund, and soon we will certainly have a common Minister of Finance. There has been no open political debate on this issue in Finland, although there has been no problem with joining the euro, which is problematic for us. President Macron's speech on September 8, 2017 in Athens heralds a grandiose federal plan. The Commission has proposed three different funds: one to secure investment in a recession, another to help Member States with their unemployment spending, and a third to deal with bad times. The proposals for the three funds are not clear and are not sufficiently substantiated to make their operation easy to understand. It is equally difficult to understand the rationale for a common finance minister or the eurozone's own budget. Federal construction is probably the most significant factor behind it. Europe is made up of sovereign nation states, all linguistically and culturally unique. From Finland's point of view, the development is worrying, as we have been given the role of payer. Seeing how little the EU countries and the Commission want to invest in combating tax evasion, I would like all the energy put into setting up new agencies, offices and funds to be channeled into the fight against tax evasion.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – This year’s State of the Union message gave a look back. It presented the remaining programme of activities the Commission will implement by the end of its mandate and provided post-mandate strategic guidelines for the EU’s future development. We have swung from the depths of last year’s frustration and disappointment to a strong optimism. However, this is leading to contradictions as old integrative dreams for Europe re-emerge. On the one hand, the claim is that the European project has to be further democratised and brought closer to the people. One the other, the suggestions are for further deepening, some to be implemented under the radar by an extension of existing rules and of the ‘Community method’. The priority of ensuring consolidation by combatting through political means, the strong divergences existing between parts of the Union, is likely to be lost. It happened in the past; it can happen again. Deepening as of now will create new realities for which the political and economic mechanisms to manage them properly will be lacking. We should not let an unexpectedly good outturn deflect us from the strategic need to consolidate. Otherwise, the past will beckon.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Mr President of the Commission, I warmly welcome your words that there must be no second-class citizens in the EU, including employees or consumers. Last year, when Czech consumers were asked during the survey how they perceive a situation where many food producers supply products with a different composition under the same name in the internal market, nine out of ten consumers were bothered by this practice. No, the Czech consumer really has no other expectations than the German one. Personally, I have been drawing attention to this perhaps uninteresting or marginal problem for some people for six years now. Thanks to the initiatives of the Czech and Slovak Prime Ministers, the Commission and the Member States are finally beginning to deal with double quality, albeit very timidly, and I believe that the European Parliament will also contribute to concrete proposals for solutions. The internal market is one of the main positive symbols of European integration. However, citizens are increasingly perceiving that the internal market does not always play fair. If we continue to pretend that there are no double standards, we are doing a disservice to the heart of the European Union project. It would be difficult for us to regain the lost trust of citizens, which is also being talked about today. I'm glad you realize that.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - Mr Juncker, you present a future for the Union based on making the working class and the peasantry precarious through competitiveness. It is committed to the Energy Union to benefit electricity companies without questioning the need to reduce energy consumption, or the environmental, landscape or health impacts of populations. He talks about delving deeper into the euro, the banking union, the Stability Pact, without mentioning poverty or the impact on public services of these policies. We need public policies to relocate production and industries; living wages; remunerative prices for farmers; for fishermen; fair distribution of the right to produce and fish; stop free trade agreements; models of food production and marketing based on agroecology and short circuits; budgets for public health, education and social services systems, not for militarizing the Union. You have forgotten about women: do you think that in terms of equal rights and the fight against sexist violence there is nothing more to do in Europe? Europe must take as a priority objective to adopt measures to end sexist violence and inequalities that half of the population suffer.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: in writing. - This year's speech by the President of the Commission was visionary and bold. In the tone of the head of the Commission, it was clear that he wanted to breathe a new spirit into the European project, in order to accelerate it and allow it to escape from the problems that have not been lacking in the Union recently. The 2017 message was particularly marked against the backdrop of last year's, which came in the period just after the British decided to leave the EU and before the elections in Austria, the Netherlands and France, in which further successes of anti-European parties were expected. This year, as President President admitted, Europe has "caught the wind in its sails". However, one cannot become over-optimistic. Perhaps the risk of a populist march to power in key Member States has now been averted, but the number of Eurosceptics continues to grow. It's good that we repelled the onslaught of populist forces, but have we learned from their growing popularity? Have the causes of Brexit been identified? We cannot afford to focus solely on the exit conditions without drawing appropriate conclusions. President Juncker's optimism also stems from the steadily improving economic situation on the continent. Economic indicators are the best in years: employment is at its highest ever, unemployment is falling and approaching pre-crisis levels, investment is rising and debt is falling.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing - The speech by Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission, on the state of the European Union was in a positive and encouraging spirit.The economy is in good shape, more than eight million jobs have been created, which is record numbers.Juncker confirmed that the European Union will expand and accept new members in the near future.This is particularly positive news for Slovakia, because our priority is for Ukraine to be a stable and functional country.I was pleased that it emphasizes the same rules for all EU citizens and, in particular, the same composition of products under the same brand - a theme that I still promote in the European Parliament.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - It is time for European integration to go beyond the period of paralysis that has characterized the economic and financial crisis, the refugee crisis, Brexit and other developments that have strengthened disintegration in recent years. I therefore welcome the fact that the report by the President of the Commission outlined initiatives for the next period that could be able to dynamize, operate more efficiently and transparently in several important areas. Our urgent tasks - strengthening our international competitiveness; joint and more effective protection of our internal and external security; a new, workable and humane common migration policy; reform of the Community budget; and last but not least, they are making real progress towards a Social Europe - they demand that the EU once again function as a genuine community of solidarity. The selfish, nationalist policies of some governments in recent years, the suppression of the principle and practice of solidarity, must not, in my view, be addressed in two- or multi-speed integration schemes, but in joint and full responsibility for joint decisions that represent the Community interest. Integration and the future of European citizens may also require the enforcement of democratic rule of law and solidarity. In response to the lack of solidarity, political will and action on the part of the governments of the Member States, which is too common at Council level, we look forward to further innovative and forward-looking initiatives that I believe can be a strong ally for most EPs, including the European Socialists. The committee.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - Mr President, the purpose of this directive is to contribute to the proper functioning of the internal market by approximating the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and by removing obstacles to the free movement of goods and services. This will improve supply in the EU market. That is why it is so important to remove the barriers created by different rules. The directive requires a reduction in the burden on small and medium-sized enterprises. Nevertheless, it is important to leave these entities under your application. Innovation is absolutely essential to achieving the objectives of the directive, which is why maintaining the right opportunities for innovative companies is so important. Market access requirements must be based on functionality and not on product technical specifications. The digital market is also important. The Digital Single Market Strategy aims to deliver more sustainable economic and social benefits by facilitating trade and increasing employment in the Union. EU consumers are still unable to take full advantage of the lower prices and more choice that can ensure a single market. There is also a need for joint action to ensure that people with disabilities have full access to new electronic content. It is therefore necessary to harmonize accessibility requirements throughout the digital single market and to ensure that all citizens of the Union, regardless of their effectiveness, can benefit from it.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – President Juncker, you said: “The rule of law is not optional in the European Union. It is a must.” I agree, and I ask: Is it not high time that the EU solves the Copenhagen Dilemma? The EU membership criteria laid down in 1993 in Copenhagen require that any candidate country implements the rule of law, human rights and respect for and protection of minorities. Members of national minorities should be able to maintain their distinctive culture and practices, including their language, without suffering any discrimination. Why the same requirements are not enforced in all Member States by an EU act? The states that joined the EU more recently implemented major changes in their legislation involving the treatment of ethnic and religious minorities. Why not have an EU standard in the matter of the protection of national minorities? President Juncker, in the quest to solve the Copenhagen Dilemma your Commission will be able to build on the Minority Safe Pack European Citizens Initiative, once the 1 million signatures will be presented next March. “In a Union of equals, there can be no second class citizens” you say. Let’s make this true for the members of national minorities, too!

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - The situation in the European Union is improving. The EU economy is gradually recovering from the economic crisis and is slowly gaining momentum, the influx of refugees has been halted, negotiations with the United Kingdom have begun, the aim of which is to work out an agreement that will minimize the negative consequences for citizens of Great Britain's exit from the EU. However, this does not mean that the threats have completely disappeared. The challenges we face are, first of all, ensuring the good condition of the European economy and security for Europeans, including, inter alia, economic security, but also, for example, energy security. We managed to break the tide of populism in Europe, but that does not mean that hybrid threats are gone. Fighting disinformation will be one of the main long-term challenges facing the EU. That is why it is so important to prepare well for them. Above all, we need better diagnosis of situations and anticipation of problems, the ability to respond to threats and effective crisis resolution strategies. Strengthened military cooperation, joint trade actions and the transformation of the European Stability Mechanism into a permanent safety net to protect not only national budgets but also household budgets and the quality of life of Europeans are good proposals to serve this purpose.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. - Juncker's State of the Union speech, in line with others he delivered during his term, conveyed a positive position on the future of the European Union (EU). I highlight the importance given to deepening participatory democracy and transparency, the need to achieve a social pillar appropriate to the new challenges of the global economy, to European leadership in terms of sustainability and clean and intelligent mobility systems, to the achievement of the Energy Union and the Digital Union, the extension of the EURO to all the countries of the Union, completing the Banking Union and the Economic and Financial Union, the development of the Security Union and the Defense Union and the new generation trade policies to reinforce the affirmation the EU. This vision needs, in order to be realized, an internally strong European Union with instruments that foster convergence. The proof of the nine on the importance of this speech will come from the presentation of the financial perspective in spring 2018. If there is the necessary budgetary reinforcement, namely the increase of the Union's own resources, then this State of the Union speech will have been a strong moment of consolidation of the European project.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Giovanni La Via
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the night of 24 August 2016 a series of earthquakes devastated the center of Italy, causing 299 victims and thousands of people injured or evacuated. A year later we are here, in this Chamber, to cast a vote that is needed to rebuild and to help those citizens who, who survived the earthquake, asked for a hand to start again and one day tell their children that they had made it, to be able to say that nothing is impossible. I am proud that Parliament, the Commission and the Council have decided to provide for this unprecedented mobilization for an amount - and we are talking about EUR 1 billion and 200 million - with the fastest possible procedure. Today, on the day of the speech on the state and future of the European Union, this is a concrete sign that Europe is alive and that its heart beats in the center: in the center of Italy, where fathers, mothers and children have today one more reason to feel European and to tell the story of a little big help. This is the Europe we believe in and we want to rebuild, where no one is left behind and where we help each other. This is the Europe of solidarity that our founding fathers wanted.

name: Presidente. –
text: The vote is closed. The La Via report was approved. As an Italian citizen and parliamentarian, I would like to thank the whole Parliament for this gesture of solidarity with the people who have suffered and continue to suffer from thousands and thousands of earthquakes. It is the demonstration that there is a Europe of solidarity. And in this regard, I inform you that, following the request that was addressed to me on Monday, on the occasion of the opening of the session, today I will sign a letter addressed to President Juncker, asking him to seek a solution in order to provide financial aid to the Dutch part of the island of Saint Martin, devastated by Hurricane Irma. The Dutch part of the island has a different legal status than the French part and, consequently, could not receive EU aid. I believe that we must do everything to help these citizens who also contribute to our election, because they vote for the election of the European Parliament. They are citizens who have suffered the same devastation as their French neighbors. (Applause)

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in line with Rule 59(4), sub-paragraph 4, I would like to ask for a referral back to committee to start negotiations.

name: Norbert Lins
text: Rapporteur.- Mister President!I request, pursuant to Rule 59 (4), fourth subparagraph, that the matter be referred back to the ENVI Committee for interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Javi López
text: speaker.- Mr. president;very quickly, I want to thank my colleagues for the work done to have a report that tries to reinforce, promote and give a more coherent framework to our relations with Latin America, in defense of the same values: multilateralism, open societies or human rights;and to share an agenda, which is the agenda of the fight against climate change, gender equality or having inclusive growth that governs globalization.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Rupert Matthews (ECR).
text: – Mr President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to make my first speech here in the main plenary of the European Parliament. I am pleased to see that positive relations with India are continuing to grow. The European Union has much to gain for India is a great country, and I wish the European Union well with those links.  But of course Britain has got its own important links with India. We have both been members of the Commonwealth for decades, and we have cultural, family, and trading links that go back centuries. I am confident that once Britain is again an independent country we will re-establish and grow our historic links with India and to other countries within the Commonwealth, and that is just one reason why I am confident that Brexit is going to be a great success.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I also supported this report on strengthening cooperation with India.After all, it is the world's largest democracy, and it is certainly worth trying to enforce a free trade agreement with this country.For me, as a Member of the Czech Republic, this also has a certain national connotation.The Czech president and part of the Czech left are overwhelmed by relations with China, Russia and some other undemocratic countries, and I think the answer to this is to strengthen cooperation with India, which does not lag behind China as such in terms of size and importance.democratic country.I think we should also take into account who we work with, what political regime works in a given country and whether the state in question is not only economically strong, but whether it respects human rights and whether the principles of democracy apply there.India is at least trying to do this.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I have chosen to support this report because I think we need to further strengthen the European Union's relations with India.I think we need to strengthen strategic partnerships in several areas.Firstly, I welcome cooperation on foreign and security policy.I can also mention, for example, the fight against terrorism, it is Indian information from many countries that helps us to avoid some terrorist attacks.I would also like to highlight the fight against uncontrolled migration and cooperation in the field of maritime and cyber security.These are all things where we should join forces, and that is why I welcome this agreement.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, today we voted to impose strict limits on the ‘stop the clock’ policy on international aviation. For decades now, we have lived in hope that the aviation industry will regulate itself and introduce the limits on emissions our planet so desperately needs. So far, we have allowed the only industry that is rapidly increasing its carbon emissions to continue posing a catastrophic threat to the climate and that at a time when the Caribbean is experiencing the worst ever hurricane season. When I became an MEP, I pledged that I would travel to Brussels by train and that I would only fly once in my mandate. How ironic that this flight will be later this week, and will take me through the hurricane zone itself. Within Europe, we urgently need to stop aviation’s free ride on the climate by ending their tax breaks and introducing a frequent flyer levy. Outside Europe, we need to implement ambitious emissions reduction targets for aviation as soon as possible, because nature is making it very clear that she is not ‘stopping the clock’.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we voted today on the implementation of the aviation emissions trading scheme. As President Juncker said today in his State of the Union address, global issues such as tackling climate change, the refugee crisis and combating tax evasion by large multinationals can only be tackled with greater political integration. That is why I welcome his commitment to end the unanimity in the Council on the adoption of tax legislation. Wealth must be taxed where it is produced. Any windows that allow for tax competition between Member States and legal corporate tax evasion must be closed. Only in this way will we be able to tackle social inequalities, youth unemployment and support health and education. The rule of law and transparency is not a choice but an obligation of all.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that it is a key element in achieving the 2030 climate and energy framework for action and a crucial step towards achieving a truly resilient and endowed energy union. a future-oriented climate change policy. Climate change is one of the greatest environmental, social and economic threats facing the planet and humanity. Every day we see examples of severe and unprecedented weather phenomena that show everyone this truth and this is the time for action. Greenhouse gas emissions from aviation activities are increasing significantly. It is estimated that, in the absence of new measures, carbon dioxide emissions from international aviation will almost quadruple by 2050 compared to 2010 levels. Ladies and gentlemen, this resolution contributes to the fulfillment of the Paris Agreement, as well as to the ambitious goal set by the International Civil Aviation organization, in the sense that global CO2 emissions from international aviation are not higher than the 2020 levels. The European Union continues to lead the fight against climate change and this resolution is an example of this.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD).
text: - Mr Chairman!I voted to exclude aviation from the harmful and mindless ETS - a system that has been a burden on European companies for years, a system that has caused unemployment to rise and companies to flee outside the Union.Let us not give in to the green dictates, let us fight for economic freedom, because only freedom will bring development and new jobs to Europe, only freedom is a response to the thoughtlessness of politicians.Therefore, I will always support her.The authors of the voting report themselves admitted that the ETS was not working and was not achieving the expected results.Including planes in its framework only increases ticket prices and additional costs for companies and citizens.In this report, I also miss the votes on condemning the system as a whole.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I supported the amendments that have strengthened the role of national experts on this regulation, so that the Member States themselves can comment on the process of setting and reviewing reference levels for managed forest land.I have also decided to support Mr Lins' amendments on the content of the national forest accounting plan.In conclusion, I did not vote in favor of the regulation itself, I abstained because I believe that a regulation on the inclusion of greenhouse gas emissions and removals from land use, land use change and forestry in the framework of climate and energy policy until 2030 is not necessarilymust be accepted.I believe that these matters can be regulated outside the legislation and there is no need to expand bureaucracy.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, in the debate we had on Monday regarding this report, I called for the vote in favor. The ENVI Committee's commitment was a balanced one and today I was forced to vote against this report because of the amendments that were introduced and voted in favor. These are changes that, once again, promote the lobbying of the timber industry, which do not take into account the diversity of the territories, which allow flexibility instead of a common reference period, that is, we have put the interests of one or two countries of the European Union because they make the forest their business above the interests of all European citizens of all countries. It is true that fires produce emissions. It is true that we have to promote biodiversity. But it is also true that chopping wood, chopping, chopping and chopping for business also produces emissions. With all this flexibility and no reference period, we were at the mercy of the business, but we lost them all. I had to change my vote.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: - When some of us speak of the need to include agriculture and, therefore, the management of forests and land use in the strategy to combat climate change, we are not referring to including it in the global marketing of rights ofissue.We refer to the need for a change in our relationship with the environment;to change the world agri-food system;for the earth to once again be considered a common good that belongs to all of us and for its care to benefit us all.We mean instituting the right to use instead of the right to property.We are referring precisely to something that is very far from the substance of this report: to avoid measures that commercialize and market with the environment.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - I voted in favor of this proposal because it establishes a binding commitment for each Member State, in order to guarantee that the emissions recorded from the use of the land are offset by an equivalent removal of CO2 from the atmosphere, through the measures of these sectors. Climate change is a transboundary and global problem that cannot be solved by national or local action alone. The Paris Agreement includes a long-term goal and states that the contribution of land use, land use changes and forestry to achieving long-term climate mitigation goals will be critical. Currently, the European Union and the Member States must take into account this sector under the Kyoto Protocol, which imposes limitations on the European Union and each of the Member States to ensure that they do not generate additional emissions. Furthermore, forest management plays a crucial role in the fight against climate change, as all these sectors must contribute to the overall objective of reducing emissions in the European Union.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, the war in Syria, Iraq, is coming to an end, to the greatest sorrow of the for-profit arms dealers.We see touching images on the TV screen in the reports.In Aleppo, for example, reconstruction has begun, bridges, roads and public buildings are being designed and built.So let us stop rejoicing that the Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled in the quota case that everything is fine with this quota regulation.The facts have changed, please!Both in Syria and in Iraq.It is possible to start going home, refugees have the opportunity, and even the duty, to catch themselves during this period, go home and work on rebuilding their country.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: - The arms trade has reached the highest volume since the Cold War, which is very bad, but it is that Europe is the second largest supplier of arms in the world, which should embarrass us. That is why we voted in favor of this report, which urges the Member States to comply with the Common Position and the Arms Trade Treaty. The sale of arms to countries such as Saudi Arabia is contrary to human rights and, in the same vein, the resolution of this Parliament of February 25, 2016 asks the Commission to impose an embargo on the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia. But on March 13, in the port of Bilbao, more than 4,000 tons of weapons were shipped to Saudi Arabia, a scene that, tragically, is constantly repeated. In such action, the corporal of the Fire Department guard alleged reasons of conscience for not participating in this operation. He is now facing a disciplinary process that could end in disqualification. What this firefighter has done is nothing more than defending human rights, which Mr Juncker has talked about so much this morning. That is why he deserves our support and our solidarity.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman!I voted against this act strayed by noble naive people.We have an illustration if we do not want to sell weapons to Turkey: Turkey bought rockets in Russia for 2.5 billion.I don't think the authors of this act are Russian agents.Why would Russia pay fools who vote anyway as the Russians want?However, I am interested in the fact that European industry is losing out, and I was strongly against this act.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: - There are many countries in Latin America that are experiencing an alarming deterioration of human rights;Argentina: we keep wondering where is Santiago Maldonado;Mexico: hundreds of journalists assassinated for denouncing the complicity between the government and drug trafficking;Brazil: a coup government that wants to change the Constitution to attack the rights of indigenous peoples to their lands.I think of all those peoples, just like this report only thinks of interfering in Venezuela.Human rights must be defended throughout Latin America, and the European Union must demand their fulfillment, not take advantage of their absence.When we approve and bet on fair international trade, between equals, that puts people, peoples and the environment before the interests of transnational corporations, then we will vote in favor.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, it has not happened to me for a long time that I would agree so much with my communist speaker, but she is absolutely right in what she said.I am aware of the importance of this partnership and believe that one of the strategic priorities for the European Union in addressing common challenges is, for example, the eradication of poverty, mass migration, organized crime or drug trafficking.Political cooperation is the only instrument by which the European Union can currently help Latin America, which must respect human rights and take measures that are based on the principles of democracy and will contribute to building an effective public administration in the fight against corruption.The recent attacks on democratically elected officials, journalists and human rights activists are unacceptable.The European Union must constantly fight against them.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - If someone from outside this Parliament read the report, they might think that corruption is only a problem in the countries of the South; that there is no corruption here; that there is no corruption in Europe or that, for example, multinational companies, most of them based in Europe, have nothing to do with corruption in the countries of the South. Obvious, for example, that these multinationals are responsible for 70% of tax evasion cases in the world. Obvious, for example, that in my country, the Prime Minister has had to go to testify to the courts for corruption or that his party is currently being prosecuted for illegal financing. I would even like to recall the transnational corruption, that of Mr. Pedro Agramunt, who is the president of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe and is directly linked to a case of corruption in Azerbaijan and money laundering. From here, you have to ask for responsibilities, understand that corruption is an evil that runs through the international elites and their multinationals and ask for the resignation of Mr. Agramunt.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an organic link between human rights violations and corruption, as oppressed people who have violated their human rights are much more forced to endure corruption.It reminds me that in the first week of September, two important things happened in the relationship between the European Union and Ukraine.One is the triumphant proclamation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and its entry into force, and the other is, in a disgraceful way, showing a humanity to the European Union and the European Union, the same week Ukraine passed a law making it impossible to use one's mother tongue.in education for indigenous communities.I call on all well-meaning Members of the European Parliament and all well-meaning states to protest against this brutal violation of human rights.Stop Ukraine!

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Corruption is a drag.It is a drag on the economy, for democracy and for social equity.In that there can be no discrepancies.There are some paragraphs in this report that are pure common sense.However, as a Spaniard and a member of this Parliament, I can only feel ashamed when we intend to give lessons to third countries.The report points to the countries of the South, but forgets that 70% of tax evasion in the world comes from multinationals, those great friends of the European Union's trade policy.By the way, I remember that in this Parliament there is a commissioner involved in one of the biggest corruption cases in the world: the Panama Papers.We are not here to give lessons to anyone and we should be much less hypocritical.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that priority must be given to the fight against corruption. Corruption is a complex global phenomenon that affects both the North and the South and is caused by the inability of political, economic and judicial systems to ensure sound independent oversight and accountability. Corruption costs the European Union between € 179 and € 990 billion in terms of GDP per year and, according to the World Bank, bribes worth approximately one billion dollars are paid annually worldwide. The European Union must show vigorous and relentless opposition. In this context, the European Union must reinforce the transparency and accountability of its public development assistance and develop a solid global risk management system to prevent development aid from contributing to corruption in beneficiary countries. It is about contributing to the direct and explicit fight against impunity through its external policies. That is why I think it is relevant for the European Union to insert an anti-corruption clause together with the human rights clauses in agreements with third countries.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I also supported this report.I am convinced that, at a time when we have the doctrine of the protection of human rights and democracy in third countries, it is good to extend this to the issue of the fight against corruption.I see this report as important on a few points, at least what I consider to be the most important - to talk about where European money goes in countries where corruption is rampant.Whether the money does not end up in the pockets of those who rule in such states and possibly organize corruption themselves very actively.In the future, we should pay much more attention to where European money goes, and rather try to support anti-corruption initiatives, civil society in such states, in third countries where corruption and, say, the protection of human rights are a big problem.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President. We have just heard, colleagues, the speech by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, who devoted 95% of his time to what are the problems in the European Union. And I think that is a very good message, because we need to think first and foremost about the problems here at home with us in the European Union. I voted against this resolution, which was drafted by my colleague Auštrevičius, and I will say why. Because we have two paths: either to continue on this path with resolutions and to condemn dictator Aliyev, dictator Lukashenko, and never to visit third countries and try to develop relations; either put an end to this vocabulary and this manner and continue in a good tone and as friends and neighbors help them. Moreover, I agree with my colleague that corruption is not unique to Azerbaijan or Belarus, or somewhere else. Corruption also exists in my country, Latvia, and we need to think about it.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: - I also voted against this report for one reason only: the amendment concerning corruption allegations concerning Azerbaijan.I am the Parliament's rapporteur for Azerbaijan and, as such, but also as a politician, I find it difficult to accept that we can make a report only motivated by press statements.I think that justice should be about corruption, not the press.If these statements are considered to be false, is there a possibility to correct a reality that you have just enshrined in the vote?I think that is not correct and, from my point of view, this type of approach is one that targets the double standard and has only a political motivation and probably foreign powers behind these statements.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is a debate on topical issues under Rule 153a of the Rules of Procedure: Dieselgate scandal: Strengthening EU standards on the environment, health and consumer rights in line with recent action by States Member States, including Germany and Austria [2017/2835 (RSP)] I would like to inform Members that for this debate there will be no catch the eye procedure and no blue card questions will be accepted as we have an extensive list of registered speakers and we must be able to speak to everyone with the comfort provided.

name: Ska Keller
text: Representative of the Verts / ALE group. - Mister President! The diesel scandal we are talking about today is a triple scandal: it is a health scandal, it is a consumer protection scandal and it is also a political scandal. The diesel scandal is a health scandal because the situation in many cities in Europe is dire. Every year 72,000 people die in the European Union from nitrogen oxide in the air. That is almost three times more people than there are road casualties. Diesel cars are one of the main polluters of the air in our big cities. So they have to be retrofitted consistently. Cheap software updates, as agreed by the federal government with the auto industry, are simply not enough. The auto industry has to get to the hardware and finally clean up its pollutants - that applies to all of Europe. Dirty VWs, Audis or Renaults drive on Austrian, Spanish and everywhere on all roads, just like on German. That is why I would like very much, Mr Katainen and Mrs Bienkoswka, if the European Commission were to present measures for the Europe-wide retrofitting of diesel cars this autumn. Because we finally need uniform standards for retrofitting the diesel fleet so that it is fully in line with European law. Because that's not happening at the moment, the car manufacturers are clearly violating European law, and it is your job to ensure that European law is complied with. So here we have a prime example. I would ask you: make sure that diesel vehicles all over Europe finally comply with the limit values! Second, as I said, the diesel scandal is a massive consumer protection scandal. Because anyone who bought a diesel car, perhaps still assuming that it was a particularly economical car, is now the jerk and must also expect driving bans. The automaker get away with it completely unscathed. There are no fines, no mandatory return actions, no general compensation payments. This is a huge mess, something like that shakes people's belief in the rule of law. It is absolutely correct that the Commission has now started infringement proceedings against Germany and also against other Member States who are completely cuddling with the car industry and have not even provided for effective sanctions. But these infringement procedures are not enough. We finally also need better rights of action for NGOs and class actions. If governments fail, then at least environmental groups and consumers must be able to ensure that they can effectively enforce their rights themselves. Third, the diesel scandal is a political scandal. The German federal government has put a political protective fence around the auto industry here. The German Diesel summit was the summit of chum. The federal government has de facto approved the breach of European law by the German auto industry. She lets the auto industry get away with collusion and trickery. If governments and authorities turn a blind eye to the manipulation, then a European solution is needed. We finally need European tests, the Commission must carry out its own random checks and consistently monitor the auto industry so that there are no more loopholes, so that there are no more fake tests. If the Member States really wanted clean air and the health of their citizens, then they would finally have to accept these strong, independent tests. The cronyism with the auto industry has done enough damage. Now is the time to join forces with European citizens and consumers in Europe. (Applause)

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is now almost two years since it was revealed in September 2015 that, based on the findings of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the vehicle manufacturer Volkswagen had used a hidden software to allow diesel engine cars to pass nitrogen oxide, commonly referred to as NOx, emissions tests by the American regulating authorities, while the same car models were proven to emit up to 40 times the legal limit of nitrogen oxides in real world driving.  The shock wave resulting from this large-scale deception is still felt everywhere. At the same time, we seem to discover more and more repercussions. Doubts persist as to the proper testing of car models of other brands as well.  Many actions have been taken at national, but also at Union, level, first of all to investigate the proceedings. In this regard, let me highlight the meticulous and intensive work of the Committee on Emissions Measurements in the Automotive Sector, which finalised its report in March of this year. The report concluded that the responsibilities of the Member States and the Commission as regards the binding emission limits were not respected. It concluded that the fact that there were large discrepancies between NOx emissions in diesel cars measured in the laboratories and on the road had been known to many stakeholders since at least 2005.  But the Dieselgate scandal is just one aspect of a much wider problem. In Europe, we have 400 000 premature deaths due to bad air quality. That is one of the reasons why we need very ambitious laws and the political will to put them into practice.  In this context, regulatory standards are one important element. Decisive action has been taken here, for instance by reaching an agreement between the two co-legislators on the National Emissions Ceiling Directive, which entered into force on 31 December 2016 and must be transposed by 30 June 2018. This Directive sets stricter national limits for the period 2020-2029, and from 2030 onwards, for the emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds, ammonia and fine particulate matter.  On procedures to test emissions from cars, major steps have been taken by the Commission. Under the provisions that entered into force this month, new car models will have to pass new and more reliable emission tests in real driving conditions before they can be driven on European roads. This test will complement and improve laboratory tests for all emissions, including CO2 and fuel consumption, as well as NOx and other air pollutants. Both tests will be phased in for all new cars between 2018 and 2019.  Furthermore, work on an overhaul of the European vehicle type-approval framework is under way. On the basis of the general approach adopted by the Council on 29 May this year, the Presidency is firmly committed to taking forward negotiations on the proposal on the approval and market surveillance of motor vehicles and their trailers, and we are working constructively with Parliament.  My impression from the first trilogue that took place on 6 September is that both co-legislators are eager to agree in the forthcoming trilogues on a robust legislation that reinforces type-approval procedures, enhances market surveillance and makes the system more transparent. Of similar importance is that the strategies that have been developed to accelerate the effective emission reductions move from the stage of policy incentives to large-scale market activity. This concerns in particular the low emission strategies, including the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure.  One of the openers will be urban bus fleets, which are mostly diesel-based today and have the power to make a difference on the market. The commitments undertaken by European cities and agglomerations during this summer to progressively convert their bus fleets into alternative fuel fleets are more than impressive, as the launch of the Clean Bus Deployment Initiative by the Commission and the Committee of the Regions on 13 July this year clearly shows.  These initiatives are being strongly supported by the European Union institutions, including the Commission, the European Investment Bank and the Committee of the Regions, and the Presidency welcomes all efforts by public transport companies that will join in these actions. In terms of policy action, the most important long-term effort rests with the modal shift, converting road transport into train and waterway transport. For instance, it has to be noted that, under the EU funding sources for implementing the strategy for trans-European networks in transport, around 87% of the Connecting Europe Facility co-funding of EUR 21.4 billion for transport has been thus far dedicated to rail and inland waterways projects. However, these efforts require perseverance, as we cannot deny that certain trends work in favour of road transport, for instance, the increase in deliveries directly to the consumers. More remains to be done. The emissions scandal has shown that we need in particular better car testing and good market surveillance. The Presidency is putting its best efforts forward to achieve progress in these areas. Together with the EU Member States and the EU institutions, we need to decisively pursue EU-wide efforts to foster low emissions mobility.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank honourable Members for this opportunity to provide them with an update on recent developments on the emissions scandal.  When Elżbieta Bieńkowska met you last time in April to discuss this case, she pledged, on behalf of the Commission, that we would fully follow up on the conclusions of the Committee on Emissions in the Automotive Sector in the final report and its recommendations. Today I can assure you that our commitment remains strong and that the Commission is acting simultaneously on three fronts: first, better enforcement, second, better market surveillance, and, third, better rules for the future. Let me first say a few words on better enforcement. In April we informed you that the Commission is pursuing several infringement procedures against Member States. These Member States had either omitted to lay down sanctions for breaches of the obligations on the car manufacturers or had not effectively applied such sanctions, even after the manipulations were discovered. Since then, a further infringement procedure was launched in May 2017 against Italy for failure to take action against Fiat for the use of prohibited defeat devices.  Let me be very clear: we are determined to pursue these infringement procedures so as to ensure proper enforcement of the current type—approval legislation and to avoid additional non—compliant cars entering the European market, which would aggravate the existing air quality problem. Second, regarding better market surveillance, in addition to these enforcement actions the Commission also urges Member States to do their part and ensure compliance of the existing diesel fleet with the type—approval rules. In this context, we are happy to see that, after the first round of national negotiations in the emissions scandal in 2016, a second round was launched in early 2017.  There are some enforcement actions underway. French authorities have been investigating possible irregularities in diesel vehicles from Renault and PSA since January. German authorities have been following up on irregularities in diesel vehicles produced by Daimler, Audi and Porsche since June, and, more recently, by Ford. The Dutch authorities also continue their investigations and notably withdrew two vehicle types from Jeep and Suzuki respectively with the intention of public prosecution.  As for the vehicles of the Volkswagen Group which were at the origin of the emissions scandal and as such were already identified as non—compliant with current emission rules, a recall campaign by the manufacturer is underway across the EU. According to the information available to the Commission, at the end of July 2017, more than half of the 8.4 million vehicles of the VW Group affected across the EU had already been recalled. Together with the Member States, the Commission will continue to monitor the repair of the remaining vehicles of the VW Group so that all affected vehicles will eventually be brought to conformity by autumn 2017. In this context, we welcome the decision of four Member States – Austria, Germany, Finland and Portugal – which have made their recall campaigns mandatory. On 17 July, Elżbieta Bieńkowska sent a letter to all Ministers urging them to follow the mandatory and voluntary measures already taken in Germany, France and the Netherlands. So far 16 of the Member States have replied. We will provide you with a complete overview of Member States’ positions once we have a full picture.  However, concerns have been expressed by consumer associations and individual car owners about the full compliance of the remedial measures with the type—approval legislation and their impact on vehicles’ durability and fuel consumption. In this context, on 7 September 2017, the EU consumer authorities, together with the Commission, urged Volkswagen to properly retrofit all affected cars and to inform consumers in a fully transparent and detailed manner about what has been achieved and what remains to be done. I can assure you that we will continue to monitor VW’s action plan on the affected vehicles.  The Commission also welcomes the initiative of Germany and Austria, which organised national diesel summits on 2 August and 22 August respectively. This is a step forward and others should follow. But we have to keep in mind that the measures proposed by the industry have to lead to an effective reduction of emissions on the road and not only in the laboratory. That is the only way to avoid so-called diesel bans that are being discussed in some Member States as a reaction to the scandal.  Thirdly, regarding better rules, let me start by reminding you that, as from 1 September 2017, improved testing procedures, both in laboratory conditions and in real driving conditions, have become mandatory for all new vehicle types. We are also working to increase the transparency and control of emissions from vehicles by allowing independent parties to test used vehicles. This will come with the new real driving emission regulation foreseen for spring 2018. As foreseen by law, we pursue work to review, and possibly to bring down, the conformity factors used to translate the measurements on the road to those in the lab. We expect to be able to lower them already with the upcoming new real driving emission regulation. Last but not least, we welcome the start of the first trilogue on the revised type—approval framework, which took place on 6 September. We salute the co-legislators’ ambition to finalise this revision by the end of the year. The new framework will reinforce the independence of testing, which will remain a national responsibility, but at the same time reinforce its European oversight. I hope that we can work together and use the political momentum to establish a strong set of rules and control mechanisms in order to regain consumers’ confidence and improve the quality of the air they breathe.  Finally, despite current turbulence, our ambition remains the same: that Europe continues to be a leader in clean, competitive and connected mobility. To put it simply, we want to make sure that it is Europe that produces the best low—emission, connected and automated mobility solutions, equipment and vehicles. To this end, the Commission has already presented the first part of the mobility package. The second part will be delivered later this year.  With this package we will present an integrated and future—oriented approach to mobility. This will be our guide on how to face disruptive developments which are ahead of the transport sector, how to modernise it and how to exploit its potential to modernise the entire EU economy. I trust we have a shared responsibility to make this agenda for a socially fair transition towards clean, competitive and connected mobility a reality.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: - Mr President! In my opinion, this emissions scandal can also be explained and understood as a guide. A guide and reminder not to put all your eggs in one basket. What are you talking about? For years in Europe, we have had one top priority. That is our climate goal - to reduce CO2 emissions. That is a good and correct goal. But as a result of this goal, we have promoted the creation of a diesel industry in Europe through various laws and tax policies. The industry has followed politicians and taxes, consumers have followed the same, and we have created the world's best diesel technology, employing millions of people, a giant industry. Then, unfortunately, it turned out that the same industry had been misleading society as a whole for years about how much their emissions actually were. And it turns out that there are questions not only about CO2, but especially about nitrogen oxides, the so-called bites, which are dangerous to our health. Not maybe for the environment, but for our health. Reactions? One reaction is to say, “Horror! All these diesel cars must be eliminated, this industry must be eliminated! This is something terrible! ” But let's think realistically! It employs millions of people. It is one of Europe's major economic engines, so to speak. It is much wiser, instead of banning these technologies, to encourage the industry itself to change. And we need to remember one thing in the future: when we make policies, we are not in favor of one technology alone, because we do not know what the unexpected and possibly negative side effects might be.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I have to say that I am a little astonished to hear from my good PPE colleague that it is actually climate policy that is responsible for the cheating of the cars in Europe. Unfortunately, that is not the case.  But let me turn to the speech by the Commission, and I hope it is not due to the replacement of Ms Bieńkowska by Mr Katainen that today the Commission is so weak and not serious enough about the reaction that it should give to what is happening. I am sorry to say this; we have had good cooperation with Ms Bieńkowska in the past and I hope that can continue and that we can be very firm because, let us be honest and look at what happened, for instance, with the Volkswagen recall programme.  The Commission expected it to be completed by autumn 2017; well, that is today. Three million cars have not been recalled yet! And it is not only that, it is also the other cars that have been cheating and the differences in the different Member States, such as: some of them are mandatory, others are voluntary, some are only for the national car market and others are different. How will the Commission make sure that all consumers in Europe have the same rights? How will you do that? I have not seen an answer.  Nor is it about the past alone. We also have to look to the future and yes, we have to care about our car industry but a new era is coming. It will be electrified, it will be sharing mobility, and if we do not make sure that we do that for our industry, if we do not make sure that we have a zero emissions mandate, then cars will be imported from China and elsewhere in the world and our car industry will have big problems, as will these millions of people. Let me finish by quoting a former Commissioner, a Liberal Commissioner, who was very good, Mr Potočnik, in our Committee on Emissions Measurements in the Automotive Sector. He said that we must stop killing industry with kindness by giving into the calls for less ambition, a longer time to achieve it, and allowing loopholes. Let us make sure that we have a future for our car industry and that it is sustainable.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it has been two years since this scandal erupted, but for decades before that drivers suspected that the statistics manufacturers advertised were over-ambitious, shall we say. The Volkswagen scandal confirmed those fears were right. In fact things were far worse than most consumers had suspected, so it is fair for people to ask: what are we doing about it?  Two years on, there are concrete changes we can point to, but a lot more work to be done as well. Firstly, real driving emissions testing legislation became mandatory for new car models at the start of this month. That is a huge step forward in ending the golden lab culture, and a big deterrent to cheat. But two years on, there is still a lot more to do. The emission scandal exposed failures well beyond just testing rules. Most fundamentally, it exposed a failure of culture at some carmakers, and a cosy club between manufacturers and governments’ approval authorities and technical services, but also that there was virtually no ongoing market surveillance. Opening up that club to greater transparency and restoring public trust is at the heart of the new type approval and market surveillance regime that we are now negotiating with the Council. The Parliament report proposed a system that would do just that: proper market surveillance obligations on Member States, and the Commission mandated to check for failings in national market surveillance; reviews and audits of all parts of the testing and approval process, to shine a light on weaknesses at every stage.  So I would urge the Council to take on board Parliament’s very sensible views in our negotiations. Once we have new rules in place, all the key components in preventing another scandal will be in place, but until we do that, the broken system remains in place. So two years on, let’s finally close the door on the emission scandal once and for all.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in the two years since the scandal broke, a lot has been done. We must realise that and recognise that. But the core of the problem still remains. Despite legal obligations, EU governments have barely taken any action and that is the core of the problem. I will give a few examples. The German authorities have still not really taken action against Volkswagen. They did not fine Volkswagen. The recall programme is extremely weak and consumers are not at all compensated for the loss. The UK has refused so far to take action against Skoda. They haven’t done anything despite all the evidence that is on the table. The Netherlands has taken some very careful steps towards action, but it is very limited and careful.  The Commission has done a few things. It has launched infringements proceedings, for instance against Italy in May, and other countries before, but a lot of countries are, well, still not really being chased after. So after what President Juncker said this morning that he called upon industry to plead guilty in the Dieselgate scandal, my question is: what is the Commission doing against the Member States further on, because, as the speakers before me said, it is far too weak at the moment. I thank the Commission for its reaction to the EMIS inquiry committee recommendations, but I am still looking forward to their reaction on the conclusions, because we did find some contravention and maladministration. Then finally the Council – a nice statement here; but the real pain, also after the EMIS committee did its work, is in the Member States. When can we expect an official reaction, as there should be in a democracy, from the Member States, from the Council, and when can we expect real enforcement of EU legislation? Do not talk only about what has to be improved for the future, but please, take action now on the cars that are still being driven on the road.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! I come from an automotive supplier region in eastern Germany, where 40% of everything that is produced industrially has something to do with car manufacturing. No matter where you go and who you talk to in terms of employees, there is a fear everywhere that they will eventually have to pay and atone for the stubbornness of the vain cocks of the automotive industry. Two years after the exhaust scandal was uncovered, it is clear that despite evidence of damage to the environment and people caused by exhaust gases, despite billions in lawsuits against exhaust fraudsters, threats of driving bans, highly critical results from the EU committees in Brussels, but also in Berlin, the muddle continues becomes. It just goes on and on. And millions of research funds are even supposed to be spent on a clean diesel, as I recently read, although its death knell has long been heard. The clean diesel - ladies and gentlemen, we all know that - is as clean as coal with CCS. This is an illusion of the yesterday. That is why it is all the more necessary that the Commission does not cuddle up to the German government and take really tough action against the production of polluters. We need more stringent regulations for emissions, we need uniform type approvals - we have discussed this for a long time - the strictest controls and, please, no pardon in cartel agreements, which are essentially nothing more than organized crime. We need market transparency, enforceable property rights for deceived car buyers, across Europe. As leftists, we acknowledge the need to turn to e-mobility, and that is not easy. We call on the unions to do the same, to finally face these normal developments. We need courageous EU programs for renewable energies and electromobility and an infrastructure for them, and we need the expansion of public transport, attractive ones carsharings to protect the environment and people.We have to act now, before it's too late!

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, why are we discussing this again? This is mainly about the existing cars on the roads. We know that there are policies going on to improve the type approval framework; we know that the new testing will be there (by the way, with very strange conformity factors) – we all know that. But the big question is: what are we going to do with the millions of cars driving on the street right now, polluting our streets every day?
