I would like to quote the Commission, when Madam Bieńkowska still had full responsibility, on 17 July, when she said: ‘We have to remove non-compliant cars from the markets and circulation as soon as possible’. I did not hear that now. I would have hoped that we would have heard that kind of language now, in this public arena. We have to do something about the millions of cars that are not complying with European law – and that is the task of the Commission. Sorry, Mr Katainen, but if you say, ‘we heard some diesel summits in Germany and Austria that should be an example for other countries’: sorry, this is the worst example. What came out of that diesel summit was that maybe there might be some software updates that lower the emission results by 25% to 30%. The latest study of ICCT shows that Euro 6 cars are emitting 4.5 more than allowed on average, so reducing by 25% to 30% is nothing. And if the Commission is going to allow that, then those cars will be de facto legalised on the streets. And they will not be sold in Germany; they will be sold in Poland, in Estonia, because there the people will still buy it and it will not be sold in Germany because there the selling is going down, so they will all go to the Central European regions. Is that the solidarity that Mr Juncker was talking about this morning? The Commission needs to step up to the plate, and there is one simple question: when is the Commission going to come forward with guidelines? Guidelines that very clearly show what needs to happen, software and hardware updates to existing cars, and that you know, and that the national authorities know, when they can be satisfied, because if you leave it to the national authorities, you will get results like the diesel summit in Germany, and that is then de facto legalising non-compliant cars and polluting cars for our citizens, and that is not an example in Europe, Mr Katainen. (Applause from the Verts/ALE Group)

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the dieselgate scam continues. Volkswagen recalls the vehicles to update the illegal software and says the repaired car complies with the homologation limits. But is it really so? Nowadays there are more and more tests, scientific reports and news that prove the opposite, that is, that cars continue to pollute beyond limits. Consumers are therefore deceived twice. Not to mention, of course, the compensation that is non-existent. The Commission, in recent days, together with the consumer protection authorities, wrote to Volkswagen to ask it to repair all the affected vehicles by the end of the year, as it had promised. But I have the feeling that this is yet another facade action. I think it is clear to everyone that the problem will not be solved with simple updates of the control units, because the problem - we have now understood it - as well as being quite obvious from a technical point of view, is above all political and does not only concern a car manufacturer, but 35 millions of "dirty" diesel vehicles around Europe. The EMIS commission of inquiry has ascertained that there has been a fraud, i.e. the European Commission and the Member States have allowed the homologation of vehicles that far exceeded the emission limits, despite the fact that there were already technologies suitable for their abatement emissions. So fraud and profit. Furthermore, companies were allowed an unjustified extension of the limits in force since 2015, thus effectively legalizing emissions by 110% more until 2020: another scandal within the scandal. To date we have not achieved concrete results and we are unfortunately used to the inaction of the European institutions in the face of large multinationals. And Volkswagen's sales are growing: they have grown by 16% this year. I am not an expert on economic issues but it seems clear to me that schizophrenia and the inaction of European institutions have paradoxically strengthened Volkswagen.In Europe I don't want to believe that the strongest always wins, I can't believe it.Unfortunately, however, this is what we continue to see.Other than Union of law, to quote Juncker: the dieselgate today is the demonstration that this Europe is the Union of hypocrisy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: - Mister President! Dieselgate - well, I find this naming a bit excessive, because someone in the parliamentary group was over-motivated. And I warn against the fact that all combustion engines are now being demonized, lumped together and saying that the combustion engine is to blame for all the problems we have in connection with traffic. But I already know that the Greens really enjoy doing it. In this context, the Greens like to instigate and stir up fears. But what do you want, dear Greens? What do you want? If I have listened to your colleague beforehand, please make it clear: you want diesel cars to be banned and these diesel cars, which are currently still on the streets, to be taken away from people. This is called expropriation, dear Greens. Say it so clearly! And where should the journey go? The manufacture of electric motors and the manufacture of these batteries is also not particularly sustainable and environmentally friendly. And where does the electricity come from with which these cars are operated? Dear Greens, the electricity comes from the socket - and that may be new for you - but it is not produced there. Dear Greens, it happens that we don't know where this electricity is produced - there is nuclear electricity, there is coal - wherever this electricity may come from. This electric mobility is now also not the green yellow of the egg. There are two reasons why we are in this problem. One is that managers cheated here in the automotive industry. And the other is that emissions standards are applied here that are not even achievable from today's technical point of view. And on the other hand - don't be too naive, because the question arises: Cui bono? What good is it if we harm the European auto industry so badly?

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, my dear colleagues! So let's talk about diesel today. First: Those in the automotive industry who cheated, who manipulated, must be held fully responsible. The President of the Commission underlined it again this morning. Second: For all other measures, the following applies to me: neither the car driver nor the car owner may be charged. I therefore consider retrofitting the affected vehicles to be the right thing to do, but I oppose driving bans in cities, as the Greens in particular are calling for. I think that's wrong, because it punishes precisely those who are dependent on the car, who have to drive into the city centers every day - this is not an intelligent solution. I think we have to think further, and I was pleased that the Council representative also came up with solutions: for example, we could convert urban fleets to electric cars, improve the flow of traffic in cities and also improve mobility through car sharing models promote - these are the right approaches. I should also like to point out that 23 out of 28 Member States do not comply with nitrogen oxide levels. But driving bans and retrofitting are only discussed in Germany, although it is actually not just a German problem. Third: I think it is wrong to declare war on the internal combustion engine, especially diesel. We'll need diesel for decades to come, and I have to say that I can't share the belief in electric cars. I therefore also consider EU quotas for electric cars to be wrong.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you very much. I'd like to start with the positives, if I may. Firstly, the reference in the State of the Union speech this morning by President Juncker was very welcome in that he acknowledged that consumers had been ‘intentionally tricked’ and that the automobile industry must make amends for that. And secondly you snuck in an announcement there on the conformity factor review which is due now in a report. I welcome that, obviously, and wait to see it with bated breath, but let's be clear: we will only accept a conformity factor of one. If we here set the margins, set the rules on the limits on what cars can emit, we can't then have other deals being made that allow cars to emit far more than we here in these institutions agree is legally acceptable.  I have to agree with the comments that have been made. Okay, there are some welcoming comments, but they are really around the margins of what we're talking about here. We do need a comprehensive strategy across the board. We're already seeing a variety of different approaches in different Member States. Some are happy with voluntary recalls, others are perfectly okay with cars still on their streets polluting many, many more times the limits, even over and above the conformity factors after they've been applied.  Where is the Commission's approach on having that unified European standard? Where is the programme in place to ensure that that variety of responses that we're seeing from Member States can be collected in one place? Because my colleague Kathleen van Brempt was absolutely spot on when she made reference to the future of the car industry. We are talking about millions of jobs across this continent, and nobody in their right mind would want to see those jobs go elsewhere. But as we know, there is a first mover disadvantage here. Other parts of the world will innovate far more quickly. They will learn from our mistakes. They will adapt their technology and then they will be the ones that own the future. We cannot allow that mistake to be repeated again and again and again. The car industry is too important. We need trust in it and we need it to be sustainable, and we've got to get ahead of the curve and what I've heard today doesn't indicate that we're anywhere near being in that position. (Applause)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! I also want to start with something positive. Vice-President Katainen has promised better rules for the future, and I think that is also necessary. We heard a lot of criticism here today, for example rightly of the criminal manipulation at Volkswagen or the very - I want to say - demanding interpretations of the existing rules by the other manufacturers. And today the President of the Commission poked fun at the entire German and European automotive industry. But the Commission is making it a little too easy for itself. Because what I noticed during this questioning of your predecessor, Vice-President Verheugen, is that he admitted that the rules that the Commission set at the time were far too vague. And that is what it is about. Because it was the Commission that opened the loopholes through which the automotive industry then slipped. Mr. Vice President Katainen! Make sure that we have clear rules in the future!

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: - Mr President! I think it is important that we do not leave the work that we did in the EMIS committee when we examined dieselgate. Dieselgate is ashamed of an important European industry that we should be proud of, which has made great progress, but which unfortunately shows that it is prepared to use loopholes and the back road to get away from doing things it should have done a long time ago. It also shames the Member States that have failed to maintain control. It also shames both the Commission and this institution, because we have not been able to ensure that the rules we have are actually complied with. The solution to this is not to have a war against the internal combustion engine or to try to look at history, but it is to look ahead. How do we make sure we get the cars that are now on the streets in order? An action plan is needed. How do we ensure that we get good legislation that is actually complied with in the future, with clear controls and with clear agreement that more of our colleagues have requested. Only then can we ensure that in future we get this difficult problem in order, where Europe should actually be ashamed.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: - (FI) Mr President, open questions: who type-approves cars on European roads, what kind of market surveillance is carried out on cars? Useful emission reduction techniques exist. They just haven’t had to be used when there hasn’t been the right kind of approval or oversight. The debate has progressed towards a ban on diesel cars. One sub-sector of industry is not instantly transformed into another without serious employment effects. What about consumers who have bought a diesel car in the belief that they can use it for years to come? And how do we relate to this circular economy principles? Electric automation is the future, but what is being done in Europe with regard to battery minerals? That is a big question. Discussions must also include reducing the need for movement and transport, ie a real zero-emission mode. Unfortunately, traffic was still not in President Juncker's speech outside the port of departure. I would like to see that, from there, we can finally get to the water from the port together, so that transport policy can really improve air quality and reduce emissions.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the "dieselgate" is a triple scandal: a state scandal, a health scandal and a democratic scandal. We have sounded the alarm bells for two years. What have you done? Nothing! Have you sanctioned states that have protected their industry rather than the health of citizens? No! Have you remembered the 35 million “garbage vehicles” that circulate on our roads? No! Have you sanctioned car manufacturers who violate emissions standards? No! Have you compensated European consumers who have been ripped off? No! While in the United States Volkswagen paid $ 22 billion for fraud, in Europe they did not even pay a dime. Look for the error… We collectively owe a debt to the 400,000 premature deaths, victims of air pollution each year, to the automobile workers who are sent into the wall with diesel, to the taxpayers, because Europe has lent 13 million euros to manufacturers to keep their vehicles clean. So, Mr Juncker, I tell you, I am fed up with repeating the same thing in this Chamber. I will not be complicit in a system that protects private interests rather than the general interest. Mr Juncker, you were right this morning: Europe needs clean air and to breathe, but breathing kills! So, we will have to act.

name: Jonathan Bullock (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this has been an awful situation. Volkswagen have deliberately broken the law and deliberately misled both regulators and customers. It obviously was wrong to do so. It should rightly face appropriate and proportionate penalties. But by allowing these emission loopholes to be ruthlessly exploited by Volkswagen, millions of British consumers have been betrayed and misled. But what concerns me as well is that it has been reported that top EU officials were aware of the VW emissions scandal two years before it broke. Why weren’t things raised then, done then, brought here? I think that question needs to be answered. My predecessor, Roger Helmer, who is somewhat of an expert in this issue, always warned that this attack on car owners, the push towards diesel, even though diesels give out only marginally more CO2 emissions than petrol, and this drive was dangerous, and of course it has led to this situation. VW was trying to follow regulatory pressure by moving to diesel power but found that it was unable to meet these emission targets and did the wrong thing. But the EU knew about it, it should have talked about it, and that is a scandal as well.

name: Christelle Lechevalier (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the parliamentary committee of inquiry has established that the European Commission is aware of possible fraud in the automotive industry but has not carried out any investigations into it. This state of affairs raises the question of the weight of the lobbies on the Commission and that of the thresholds and standards set by the European Union. The auto industry has made enormous efforts and investments over the past fifteen years to reduce pollution from vehicles and we are all aware of the need for these changes, especially for health. However, she organized herself to sidestep the standards you set. Let us ask ourselves the question of why. Has the Union not overestimated the ability of manufacturers to adapt to the standards it imposes? The Union must be careful not to impose unachievable binding standards which end up being circumvented with the very consent of the Commission. The objectives, especially environmental ones, must not be utopian and must take into account not only the environment but also the issues of our industries. Let us ensure that incentives are in place rather than constraining, and let us not forget that nation states are often best placed to make decisions and control their involvement.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I am used to the fact that we sometimes have strange discussions in the European Parliament. For me, today's debate is a little part of it, it is one-dimensional and transparent. It was also introduced by the Greens. In order not to be misunderstood: I strongly condemn what car companies have done. It is intolerable and should be punished. But on the other hand, I would like to talk a little about limit values ​​today. We have a limit value of 40 micrograms per cubic meter for NOx on the street, at work it can be 950, and toxicologists say that 8,000 cause slight irritation of the airways. So much for NOx. We come to fine dust, which is extremely hazardous to health. Limit: 50. When I smoke a cigarette in my garage, I emit the same amount of fine dust as when I run the engine of my new diesel car for half an hour. Or: If I light incense sticks in my apartment, it can cause up to 700% more than the limit value. Or: values ​​between 500 and almost 1,200 were measured in the London Underground - allegedly a clean means of transport. I advocate that we look at the limit values. I don't want the limit values ​​for diesel to be raised or something like that, but that we simply find fair access and see that we really create something that is kind to people and the environment.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner, dear colleagues, five months ago, here, we voted for the recommendations of the EMIS committee based on the conclusions of the parliamentary inquiry. This report contains several strong proposals, both to guard against a new diesel scandal and to correct what we had already discovered. Sadly, five months later, we are gathered again to discuss a scandal which, far from being extinguished, has only continued to grow. The European Parliament has not been heard enough and that is regrettable. Consumers are still the big thing, we hear here and there about repairs that malfunction, degrade vehicle performance, or worse, damage engine parts, and additional repairs are at the expense of owners. The builders do not even consider compensating them up to the amount of damage suffered and it is up to consumers to pay for the builders' wrongdoing. President Juncker wants equality in the application of consumer rights across Europe and that is good. We therefore expect a proposal from the Commission to harmonize the reparations and compensation of those who have been harmed by dieselgate, as we have voted. The scandal continues above all because the rules are still not properly enforced and the only way to achieve this is to have dissuasive sanctions. The ball is now in the court of the Member States, as negotiations continue on the new European framework for vehicle approval and market surveillance. Ideally, it will be necessary to have a dedicated European agency. Commissioner Bieńkowska, you told us, you recognized that this is the best way to achieve it. As the trialogues have only just started, there is still time to correct the situation to have strong European supervision.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! We have to look at the "dieselgate" scandal from many angles: first, there was an obvious fraud and misleading consumers who were not properly informed by car companies about the specifications of the vehicles they were selling. The scandal is that the entities responsible for this scam in Europe refuse to cooperate with consumers and make it difficult for them to pursue claims, and even more scandalous is that so far no hair has fallen off anyone's head. Secondly, we must honestly admit that the reasons for such a policy of car manufacturers were growing environmental standards and stringent emission standards, which were far ahead of technological possibilities and generated huge costs. This does not explain the fraud, of course, but it was certainly the reason for the manipulations used. Thirdly, the "dieselgate" is evidence of the enormous gaps in the European vehicle approval and inspection system. However, I do not believe that the creation of another EU agency will solve this problem. Member States have the right tools to conduct effective tests, but need to use them effectively and better coordinate their actions, also with the support of the Commission.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, two years have passed since the outbreak of the dieselgate affair. What happened during that time? The European Union has introduced new testing rules, some of which we have already implemented, others are waiting. The manufacturers apologized and adapted to the new conditions. Unfortunately, in dealing with the consequences of the affair, there have been different approaches to European and American customers. American customers are entitled to compensation, others, not European ones. This is a big topic and I think it should be reconsidered. Just because European consumer confidence has fallen to freezing. Diesel cars are piling up in warehouses that no one wants. At the same time, these are cars that today meet the strictest standards and certainly represent a smaller environmental burden than the fifteen-year-old cars that normally drive on our roads. So a lot of work today lies in products. They must regain our trust. But we, as legislators, should move quickly. There is no reason to delay the tightening of conditions for car testing and all related legislation. For the bono of the customer, manufacturers and the environment.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The diesel scandal is the best example of where clientele politics can lead: to fraud against tens of millions of car buyers, to irresponsible acceptance of health risks, to massive environmental damage and to a loss of confidence in politics. What the German government, which is known for its dubious emissions intervention in Brussels, has done in connection with the diesel affair can only be described as complicity and political failure. The fact that we are not debating much, much more intensively today about appropriate compensation for the car buyers affected in the EU is, for me, proof that the Commission's European automotive policy is directed from the German Chancellery. A free software update for paid cheat software is a slap in the face of those affected and duped. So we would be well advised to recommend an intellectual software update to all those politicians in Brussels and Berlin who are jointly responsible for the diesel affair, because otherwise the diesel scandal will ultimately look like legalized consumer fraud.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! Three facts: First: Euro 5 and Euro 6 cars have four to five times more nitrogen oxides behind the engine than Euro 4 cars because they inject more pure diesel. And then these 1,000 and more NOx would have to be filtered out very laboriously. The automotive industry knew that. It didn't want to spend a lot of time retrofitting, and it tricked - 35 million times. We have 35 million Euro 5 and Euro 6 cars on European roads today. People die in the city centers every day. Second fact: software updates were recognized as fake by the judge in Stuttgart and were recognized as fake by the German Ministry of the Environment. Why do you think VW has to pay a fine of 20 billion in the US? Because the US authorities recognized software updates as fake right from the start. And what do you do as a commission? You accept that KBA and the German government consider what the US authorities have declared to be fake and illegal to be legal, you do nothing against the fact that what VW has done is subsequently legalized in Germany. When Ms. Bieńkowska finally wrote the letter on July 24th, what happened then? Then Ms. Merkel called Brussels, and then Ms. Bieńkowska was pushed aside a bit so that Ms. Merkel couldn't get anything before the general election. This game makes you cry! This will make the citizens of Europe not believe in Europe.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the dieselgate scandal brought out what many citizens already knew, which is the political link between car manufacturers and governments. It brought out the big conflict of interest between the controller, which is the state, and the controlled ones. For two years we have been discussing how to overcome this serious situation, this scandal, this scam against consumers. Today we are discussing, at Commission, Council and Parliament level - we are in the trialogue phase for the type approval regulation - and we are spending words. But today something very important struck me, namely the intervention of President Juncker, who felt the need to talk about the car industry and how shocked he is by what they did, because they betrayed the trust of consumers. Well, in the face of this I expected a position to be taken with respect to those who defrauded consumers. What did Juncker say instead? He kindly asked the car manufacturers to apologize. And this is where the commitment of the Commission translates to me: so I ask the Commissioners. You're kidding? Are we wasting time or will you take note of what happened and punish the wrongdoers?

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: –It has been said several times this afternoon that President Juncker mentioned the car industry in his speech this morning, and if you read those sentences again, you will see many important words there.You are not just mentioned in the speech of the State of the Union and there is apparently reason for that.Let me be clear: the car industry is of great importance to Europe.It creates a lot of employment and provides innovation, exports, but also mobility for millions of Europeans.On the other hand, it has to be neater and cleaner.By cleaner I mean more transparent, also with regard to cartels, and cleaner refers to emissions and recalls.We must also stop deceiving consumers and governments.It's just not professional.If everything has to be traced back to shareholder value, we will not get there.It is a much broader objective and the professionals within the car industry should understand that too.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Sir. Chairman! First of all, thank you for having this debate here today and for the Council being present while we are discussing this, because there is no doubt that it is the Member States that are very much lacking in this area. It is now two years since the scandal was discovered in the United States. And so we are still far from being in the goal of solving the problem. First and foremost, we have to clean up, and we are not there either. There are lots and lots and lots of these polluting cars still driving on European roads, so it is unacceptable, it is going too slowly, and it is the Member States that must act here. Then it is also important that we create a system that allows us to prevent something similar from happening in the future. We are in the process of looking at the legislation, but it is going well slowly! We even need to be presented with legislation that consumers can join forces and sue in the car industry, if that is what is needed. So here we also have to go up in revolutions so that something can happen. The last area, that was actually some of what Jean-Claude Juncker brought up in his speech today. There is no doubt that if we are to avoid similar scandals with our cars in the future, then we will have to invest in getting clean cars in Europe. We must put money into this development, and we must have clean cars, and therefore we must also dare to take a discussion on whether diesel technology has a future at all.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - It's been two years since Dieselgate came to light. A few months ago we here approved by a large majority the recommendations and conclusions of our committee of inquiry and our core message was clear: dieselgate should have been avoided, dieselgate could have been avoided. Irresponsible Member States and a negligent European Commission have pushed public health aside. Especially vulnerable road users and children are affected. There are already some positive signs, such as the new improved emissions tests and the low emission zones in some cities. But are we there yet? No, we are far from there. Reports last summer that various car manufacturers have made price agreements have once again hit consumer confidence. I hope that the Commission and the Presidency of the Council can clearly indicate how they will keep the pressure on, together with all the actors, to eliminate these structural errors. Protecting public health and the environment is a shared responsibility.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Diesel technology was introduced to meet the CO2 targets, that has already been said. One thought of CO2, but not of NOx. In the meantime there has been a law at European level for a long time which also prescribes NOx limit values. It is just simply that nobody bothered about it - neither the auto industry, nor the Commission, nor the respective governments. You just have to record that, and that was also clearly evident in the committee of inquiry. That's why we need Real Driving Emissions as soon as possible - we have to have honest values. Consumers bought diesel cars in good faith and need compensation. Software retrofitting is also easily possible, as is hardware retrofitting. We need to research more into new ways of mobility. We don't need any driving bans or technology bans. Driving bans affect commuters, technology bans are also wrong. When it comes to electromobility, we have batteries where child labor is performed to mine cobalt in Africa - that is also not environmentally friendly. One last thing: the European economy loses a billion euros every day due to traffic jams, and of course there are a lot of emissions that could be trashed. So intelligent traffic solutions are also a solution here.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, representatives of the Commission! What we have seen here is massive, billion-dollar fraud against tens of thousands of consumers - people who have bought new cars believing that they are cleaner. That did not work. It was also a fraud against the health of the people and the next generations, and it is not for nothing that the auto companies in the United States have been fined $ 20 billion. And here in Europe? The Commission - I too must be very clear - has failed here. You represented the interests of the corporations and not the interests of the citizens of this continent. But the German and Austrian federal governments have also failed. You have been content with saying that it is enough for you to make software updates and finance them. My colleague Claude Turmes has already said: These are fakes. It does not work like that. What would be necessary would be consistent retrofitting with hardware and not software, and above all adequate compensation for all those who have been cheated out of a lot of money here in recent years, and those whom the car companies have fooled into thinking that this is now cleaner diesel. There is no such thing as that. This scandal must be used as a signal to phase out fossil fuels. From 2030, new diesel and gasoline vehicles will no longer be permitted. We owe that to the citizens of this continent. We need affordable and environmentally friendly mobility.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: - We can all agree that dieselgate was a historic low for the European car industry. That will take a lot of time and patience before European consumer confidence in the car industry is restored. Fortunately, despite all the negative reports from the past weeks, there are also a few positive elements that we should perhaps dare to mention. The real driving emissions test, a much more robust and stricter emissions test, has been in force for the new models since 1 September, and that is of course positive. In addition, a number of car models prove that it is indeed possible to market diesel cars that remain far below the European standard of 80 mg / km in terms of NOx emissions. So it is possible, so let's keep putting pressure on it. The work is of course not finished. National responsible authorities must also cooperate and adapt their tax systems to these new tests, so that the cars that are the cleanest on the road are also tax-encouraged and the lists updated. Let's also try to streamline all those different regulations around the low emission zones in all those cities in Europe - which are of course good - a bit more. You, Commissioner, can of course play a role in this. Today we are faced with a jungle, a maze of 200 different vignettes and emission standards. It is our task to coordinate these a little better in the interest of all consumer motorists.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: - Mr President, honorable Commission, ladies and gentlemen! Despite the emissions scandal, almost every second car in the European Union runs on diesel. Nevertheless, the share of diesel is decreasing. Dear Commission, precisely because diesel employs hundreds of thousands of people and because diesel emits dangerous nitrogen oxides, which make sick people even sicker, we need a Europe-wide action plan - only you as the Commission can do that. An action plan that first analyzes the changes in the value chain and then makes suggestions for a reorientation of industrial policy. We know we're talking about electromobility, hydrogen, hybrids, power-to-gas and the like. Only if you take this big step and force the Member States to do so will we be able to get out of diesel technology more quickly in future. Then people will no longer get sick or die, they will not become unemployed and we will not lose our leadership position worldwide. But you as the European Commission must first make this big leap and this big step.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, for a year we have been with the Investigation Commission on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automobile Sector. Experts from all over Europe have passed through it and we have been able to clearly know what has happened. At this point we have a clear notion of everything that has happened and the text of the conclusions also gives us guidelines and solutions for the questions raised. The priority must be to preserve the environment and the health of consumers, but also to establish and promote legislation with less polluting fuels and restrict the installation of deactivation devices. What we cannot and must not do is demonize diesel vehicles, or ban them immediately, because we have promoted their development to reduce CO2 emissions and because they are a very important part of our European production. But, yes, perhaps we should reflect on whether we wanted to go too far and adopt environmental legislation that has led to these manipulations too soon to enforce it. The legislation of the European Union, of course, must offer greater protection and reparation to consumers in cases like the one that has happened to us, but it must also be rational and capable of being complied with and, above all, capable of being controlled . The text that we will vote on tomorrow clearly indicates the direction in which we must work.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker, of course, we need apologies from the car manufacturers, but they are not enough: we need facts, coherent choices. First: after many nice words we need a turning point on homologations. We are in the final phase of the negotiation. Let's not fool ourselves: without giving more control powers to the European Union, the nation states will continue in the standardization to be weak and compliant with their national industries. Second: what still needs to happen to define a clear legal framework that gives certainty and rights to scammed consumers? Consumer protection is not a luxury but an urgent necessity. Third: let's not let our guard down. We have read about alleged agreements, cartels between car companies, to keep the costs of components down to the detriment of quality. Warning: we avoid that, while discussing an old scandal, a new one consumes before our eyes. Action must be taken immediately.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE).
text: - Mr President, representatives of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! The current diesel debate sometimes has a similar relevance to reality as the exhaust gas values ​​in the test laboratory: almost none. Because even in 20 years there will still be diesel. It is and will remain a climate-friendly future technology and will secure millions of jobs. These are threatened by the dream of many greens: a diesel ban and mandatory electric quota, as Ska Keller also called them. Unfortunately, after the theater, she left after four minutes; she doesn't seem to have any real interest in the debate. Martin Schulz is now also calling for a Europe-wide quota for electric cars. He just doesn't want to drive one himself. It would fare like the former Green Minister for the Environment of North Rhine-Westphalia, Johannes Remmel. He bought an electric car at the taxpayer's expense for over 100,000 euros and exchanged it for a diesel after driving only 34 times. The battery wasn't enough. We do not need a mandatory quota for clean air, but fair competition between technologies. And at the end of this, the consumer decides whether to drive with a combustion engine, an electric car or innovative fuel technology such as e-fuels. Incidentally, these innovative technologies already comply with exhaust emission limits, however questionable they may be. In offices, the limit value for nitrogen oxide is 50% higher than on the street. How can the limit value at the workplace in industry, at 960 micrograms, be almost 24 times higher than on the street? Perhaps the Commission can answer that question. These limit values ​​seem completely out of thin air. I believe that our debate and the Commission must also come back to reality, just like with the RDE tests.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! It's about health. That, too, is an issue - environmental protection, health - on which most Europeans say that is the job of the European Union. This is a problem that we can only inadequately solve nationally. That is what it is all about today, we need a bundle of measures. One of these measures was also the limitation of exhaust gas values ​​in motor vehicles. People have relied on the fact that when they buy these products they will get what they are promised and promised. We have now found: You have been cheated - not only economically, but also in questions of the future. We know that and have already heard it today that there are 400,000 people in the European Union who die prematurely from respiratory diseases and related diseases. We know that in Austria alone 8,200 people die every year from air pollution, 20 to 30% of which is also caused by diesel vehicles. Denying it is like saying the earth is not round. I hope that - as the President said today - we will be able to have a single market for consumers, just as there is a single market for cars. We need the possibility of a European class action, because only then will European law really be accessible to every citizen on this issue.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this scandal is the outcome of the failure of the car industry, economical, technical and moral, and a failure of our principle of the rule of law, and this is bad. We are talking about if the reaction was adequate. Let me make three comments. First, I believe that the reaction of an individual government is not right. It is not the right response. It is a European problem, European people, European error, so it needs a European fix. Second, still thousands of Europeans are now everyday buying the cars that most likely are not in line with the law, especially diesels without SCR, and that’s not good. These cars will be on the road for the next 15 years and they will be polluting. The only success is that we were able to adjust the type approval rules and introduce the real driving conditions. But at the end of the day, it seems to me nearly impossible to explain to all people that the reaction is adequate, because bad cars are still on the roads and health is suffering. Sometimes the crisis by decisive action can be turned to an opportunity to success. I’m afraid we are not at this stage yet, unfortunately.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: - Mister President! As a reminder: 23 out of 28 member states do not comply with limit values ​​for nitrogen oxide, and almost all European car manufacturers are responsible for ensuring that the limit values ​​are exceeded in almost all European member states. First of all, I think, dear Commissioner, that the Commission must significantly broaden its view of criminal law beyond the German horizon. But I also think that those who oppose diesel should take note that in Germany alone nitrogen oxide emissions have fallen by 60% in the last 30 years, not increased. And now the electric car above all? We get oil and gas from more than 15 regions of the world, the rare earths for batteries only from China and cobalt predominantly from the Congo. Do you really want these new addictions? At least we don't want that. That is why we have to carry out the structural change towards renewable drives in a technology-neutral manner. E-mobility yes, synthetic fuels, including hybrids, and that includes diesel engines, otherwise structural change will not be affordable. And without diesel technology, our CO2 targets will not work either.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! On the one hand, the European Union states incur huge costs to reduce pollutant emissions, and on the other hand, the European Commission does not enforce the imposed standards. How many scandals of this type are needed to find a way to effectively defend against them? Ladies and Gentlemen, thousands of consumers chose diesel cars believing that in this way they protect the environment, and in fact they were deceived. The most outrageous thing about this scandal is that the exhaust emissions were deliberately manipulated to increase profits. It is safe to say that the European Union's efforts to combat climate change and exhaust emission standards to reduce the negative impact of motorization on the environment have been absolutely wasted and violated. Perhaps we should ask ourselves whether the standards that the European Commission imposes on various industries are not too high and the costs of their implementation are not too high? Perhaps this is a topic for the next discussion that should take place in the European Parliament. Nevertheless, the rules apply to everyone and whoever violates them should be strongly punished. At this point, the question of the Commission should be asked: what sanctions has it imposed on Volkswagen two years after the dieselgate scandal went public, and when will consumers receive the same compensation as consumers in the United States? Are we consumers of a worse kind?

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this discussion. I would also like to thank Jyrki Katainen for supporting me in this very challenging issue because I think – and this is also very visible in this room – that there is a basic division in our approach to the problem. Part of our society, part of our governments, part of us in this room, share the opinion that we have to close our eyes, pretend that a transition in not ongoing, and protect and defend old technology. Because this is old technology. The goal is the same. My goal is the same. I want to protect the industry. I want to protect jobs. I do not want to protect the old technology. We have been discussing this for two years and I think that perhaps even more discussion is needed to really understand that we are in the 21st century and the future of the automotive industry is the non-emission car or a low-emission car, not diesel cars. I know that this will not happen – I have said this many times and also in this room – from one day to the next. I know, and I understand, that every other car in Europe is powered with a diesel engine, but this does not mean that we in this room – you as a Parliament and us as a Commission – should close our eyes and say that nothing has changed since two years ago when the emissions scandal broke. The scandal is not over yet because the industry, as many of you repeated, harmed the health of our citizens and our environment and then, afterwards – as many of you also mentioned – it compensated EU consumers less favourably than consumers elsewhere, forgetting that compensation should be for citizens and for consumers, not for CEOs. This is also our role. We are working on this with Commissioner Jourová. I sometimes have a feeling that we have to protect and save the industry from themselves because this is all about a strong European car industry. This is all about the credibility and reputation of the European industry, which is now very weak. Repeating that we love diesel engines will definitely not change that after what many of you have said. For more than two years both we in the Commission and the Parliament – thank you very much for this – have been working very hard to put an end to the scandals and enforce the rules. But of course, as we are also noticing, almost every week new allegations appear. As I have said many times before, Member States are only sharing information at our strong request. Some Member States even claim that they somehow cannot enforce the current law because it is not clear enough. For me it is crystal clear that even our existing rules have been broken and are probably still being broken. On top of that, we already proposed a year and a half ago the new type-approval framework that should help in the future and should prevent such a situation. I have to say that I am disappointed that only this month have we finally managed to open a trialogue. This is much too slow, but we will have it. Now that the trialogues have started, let us agree a high—quality new European framework by the end of this year. Let us do our best, both in the Council – I really count on the Estonian Presidency for this – and of course in the Commission and the Parliament. As we started the discussion in the EMIS Committee, many of you asked for an EU agency. As you also know, I opposed the idea, but I have to admit – and I very much agree with you, Mr Eickhout – that maybe we should be more open on this because the most dangerous and biggest problems now are on—road cars. We will have a type-approval system. It is of course going very slowly, but finally we will have it, but what about the cars that are currently on the road? We really cannot force Member States to take proper action. All the tools – as some of you have also said – are in their hands but they are not using them. They hesitate to do so. Again let me stress that I am open about the European Agency. I have to admit that I might have been wrong about this and that maybe I was too slow in my thinking. So let me stress what needs to be done now. First, I am determined to pursue the infringement procedures. We took a lot of those steps in May and in December, but we need to ensure the proper enforcement of the current type-approval legislation. Second, as we all know, we have to finalise our work on the effective type-approval system as quickly as possible. Some of you asked about the conformity factor. I can commit for now that I will also reduce the conformity factor of the second RDE package by the spring, maybe also after discussing it with you. I will let you know by how much. Many politicians, some in this room, claim to be shocked and disappointed with the industry, but these are empty phrases. In the European Union for now words are not followed by actions and this is our problem. It is very easy to repeat that this is a lack of confidence in the industry, that this was a huge problem and that it was cheating, but we need to do something, as I have said before. Member States themselves can bring down the emissions of the existing diesel fleet. They can properly enforce the existing law and, of course, the measures that are taken by the industry have to actually bring down emissions on the road and not only in laboratories. To do so we have to consider again software and hardware measures. That is why I am not fully satisfied with the results of the diesel summits in Austria and Germany because they are very limited to some parts – differently in Austria and Germany – but I think there is an urgent need to discuss it at the Council. I will ask the Estonian Presidency to put this point on the agenda of one of the upcoming Council meetings. I do not of course want the most polluting cars to end up in Central and Eastern Europe, and you are right that this is the situation right now. For now only Member States can prevent this. Do not allow – this is my appeal to some Member States – non-retrofitted cars to be registered on your territories. This is harmful for your citizens, for your environment and for your future. Finally, let me close with what I think is a very important message because one of the most important things in this very complicated picture is the future of the automotive industry. In November we will present the next mobility package. This will aim to prepare the industry for the future. All of this future work must involve close and very fruitful engagement from the industry side. Without the industry we cannot do it, but they have understood that the way they are going now is not a good way forward. This is not the way to the future. This is the way of the past. That is all from my side. I think both sides and all of us must work to get these changes right. I think we will meet more than once in the future.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me conclude by recalling that improving air quality means reducing a number of factors that are relevant in this respect. I would like to mention for instance CO2 emissions that are of major importance for the protection of the climate, whereas NOx emissions have direct effects on human health, and there is an inverse correlation between the two. As one decreases, the other one increases. We welcome the fact that work on CO2 standards for cars and vans is ongoing to foster zero- and low-emission vehicles in a technology-neutral way.  The infringement procedures recently opened by the Commission against eight Member States for breach of EU-type approval legislation are a testimony of the importance of monitoring whether EU law in this area is being properly enforced. Furthermore, Member States are called on to take all necessary measures to ensure that non-compliant cars are fixed or withdrawn from circulation.  This shows again that we need to work hand in hand if we want to reduce emissions of air quality pollutants from road vehicles and thereby strengthen the health of European citizens and the environment. In this work, we have to consider concrete evidence which, among others, includes the work done by the EMIS committee and the inquiries by the Commission.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mireille D’Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - This scandal shows that EU standards can be unenforceable despite laudable intentions. The EMIS commission was born in early 2016 with the "Volkswagen affair" and aimed to find out whether Brussels or the Member States were aware of the discrepancies between European anti-pollution standards and the reality of emissions from the engines of vehicles of different European brands. The report of the commission of inquiry accuses both Brussels and the Member States of a lack of control over the practices of car manufacturers. However, most manufacturers would abuse the rule which allows them to reduce the efficiency of pollution control systems in the event that the latter risk damaging the engine (Article 5 of Community Regulation No 715/2007). Moreover, while there is free competition between national certification bodies, the report deplores the fact that the EU does not have a supranational certification body. Finally, the report of the commission of inquiry praised the respect by American manufacturers of antipollution standards comparable to European standards. However, the situation in the United States is by no means comparable, since the use of diesel is in the minority among light vehicles. Also, it is advisable to remain cautious about the nature of the strengthening of European standards in this area.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - For the left of southern Europe it is not news that the EU is at the service of the great German industry. And what oligopoly is more powerful than that of the automobile? We saw it in the dieselgate investigation commission, where it was evident that the Commission knew about and allowed the manipulation of NOx emissions, even at the cost of air quality in our cities. And we see it now, when Germany allows these diesel cars to continue circulating without companies paying the cost of repairing the hardware of the manipulated engines. Not Volkswagen, not Daimler, not Audi, not Porsche. No company has the right to determine what the future of the automotive industry should be, and even less by violating current legislation. It is the rapacity and short-termism of big German industry that are delaying the transition to cleaner and more efficient engines. And if we miss that train, it will be the workers who lose their jobs to imports from other countries. And that will be the end of the automotive industry in Europe.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on fire safety in buildings (2017/2764(RSP)).

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, after the tragic accident of the Grenfell Tower in London, many have been asking what the Commission is doing to ensure the fire safety of buildings. I therefore want to use this opportunity and the occasion of this plenary to clarify the responsibilities of the Commission and the Member States in this extremely important matter. Fire safety is, of course, a complex issue, which is not determined only by the choice of the construction products or how those are tested. Factors playing an equally crucial role are, for example, the general design of the building, the effectiveness of the installed fire detection, fire alarm and fire-fighting systems, the location of the building, potential fire accelerators inside or around the buildings, good maintenance – not mentioned here – of the fire-protection system, and of course, human behaviour. What is perhaps even more important, fire safety is crucially dependent on the effective enforcement of fire safety regulations at different levels, national, regional and local. Today, under the subsidiarity principles, fire safety in buildings is regulated at the level of the Member States. This is due to important differences in local conditions between Member States. For example, certain Member States do not allow flammable construction products to be used in buildings, while others have no such requirements. The EU should only undertake actions if the objectives of fire safety cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States. Today, the Commission has no compelling proof that national regulations are not reaching this goal. For this reason we consider that it is not justified for the Commission to regulate at EU level in order to ensure the fire safety of buildings. What are our Commission’s competences? Under the current rules the EU’s role is to make sure that construction products which have the necessary performance requested in given EU Member States are not rejected. To enable this the EU sets common testing methods for specific products, not their safety requirements. Thanks to this, Member States set their own safety requirements for buildings. The Commission is entrusted with the implementation of the Construction Products Regulation. I will call it the CPR. The CPR is based on Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. Under the CPR, the European performance tests include the examination of how construction products behave in fire in terms of reaction to fire, resistance to fire and the fire performance of roofs. Furthermore, the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive requires Member States to set minimum requirements for the thermal energy performance of buildings. This legislation does not limit the responsibility of Member States to define requirements on construction products in the field of fire safety – quite the contrary. The various pieces of EU legislation should be applied coherently. Therefore, Member States may equally have requirements on fire safety regarding, for example, the spread of the flame or the emissions of smoke. Over the last few years, the need for more energy-performing buildings has resulted in a large choice of new construction products being offered in the market for buildings, and their facades, which is equally important. These modern ways of construction like, for example, the external cladding system, creating a modern facade, and the need to renovate older buildings, have changed significantly the exterior of our buildings. They are thus a challenge to the regulatory authorities of the Member States. Moreover, new emerging issues of the fire performance of construction products which are not yet covered by the CPR are the smoke toxicity from construction products in fire and the fire performance of facades. So they are not yet covered by the CPR. For these two items, the Commission already asked for independent studies long before the Grenfell Tower fire, and the results will provide very useful information I hope for the Commission, for the Member State authorities, and the construction industry alike. While fire safety is within Member States’ responsibility, the Commission offers to take a facilitating role and add value by bringing the relevant actors together. Therefore, I can commit that we will set up a fire information exchange platform. This forum will facilitate, I hope, the exchange of information between the national authorities and the stakeholders. The platform is expected to examine the issues regarding the various fire safety practices of Member States, lessons learned from the fire accidents in the EU and abroad, experience obtained from new products and technologies, as well as use of fire engineering principles for setting regulatory requirements. By learning from each other and by sharing information, Member States’ authorities will have the full knowledge of the advantages and disadvantages of the regulatory choices they have to make. For this we need the broad participation of Member States, open discussion of the issues encountered, independence and, of course, objectivity. We are therefore working in close cooperation with the Presidency to organise the first meeting currently scheduled for 16 October, so in one month’s time. To conclude, let me say that the Commission shares everyone’s concerns to ensure that our buildings are fireproof. As I said, the EU Member States remain responsible for setting the level of fire safety in buildings on their territory, and to enforce their building regulations. We have no proof for now that national rules are not achieving this today. The Commission is examining emerging new issues such as smoke toxicity and the fire behaviour of facades, and it evaluates the functioning of the internal market for construction products. We will act if EU intervention is needed, but not more than is necessary to ensure the single market of construction products. We are fully aware of the regulatory challenges posed to the Member States’ authorities, therefore we believe that the exchange of knowledge and experience among authorities and stakeholders is very important, and we consider it a necessity. Under the current framework, I believe that this is the best way to contribute to the protection of European citizens. I see the Commission as a facilitator rather than the regulator in this area.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all, let me express my deep sadness over the horrible tragedy of Grenfell Tower on 14 June in London. I would like to pay tribute to all the victims and their families. We have to bear them in mind while having today this very important discussion on fire safety. I commend Commissioner Bieńkowska for having given a thorough overview of the legislative regulatory arrangements that are in place in the field of fire safety in Europe today. Let me just add that the work of the Commission on fire resistance needs to be continued and possibly intensified. Both the European Parliament and Council, as co-legislators and as bodies controlling the legislative power of the Commission have exercised their responsibilities and we are ready to continue to do so. I am convinced that the Member States can follow up on that and that effective enforcement on product markets is possible, without any new shift in the competences or legal responsibilities. However, should the Commission decide that a new proposal on the performance of construction products as part of harmonisation legislation is appropriate, the Council will of course be examine such a proposal, in collaboration with the Parliament. Finally, outside the legislative work, the Estonian Presidencies supports the forthcoming platform on information exchange on fire safety issues. This is an initiative that had already been prepared by the Commission for some months and that should fit well with other initiatives underway. I am looking forward to the discussion and thank you very much.

name: Ivan Štefanec
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I believe that immediate action should be taken to improve fire safety in buildings for all citizens and prevent a tragedy on the scale of Grenfell Tower from happening again. Firstly, I think that the Commission should urgently change the approach to facade testing and mandate the European Committee for Standardization (CEN) to develop one harmonised, large-scale test for facades. This large-scale test needs to be designed to reflect real fire conditions in order to properly evaluate the performance of facades in fire.  Secondly, I believe that the Commission should propose new requirements to test the toxicity of smoke from construction products under fire, and to label those products with the results, so that the construction industry and consumers can make informed choices.  Thirdly, the Commission should ensure a much deeper cooperation among Member States to improve fire safety in buildings across the EU. This means collecting comparable data on fire incidents in all Member States, using data to identify best practice in national fire-safety regulations, and sharing and spreading best practice to achieve a tangible improvement in fire safety in buildings. The proposed actions are fully in line with the principle of subsidiarity. Testing construction products to be used in the common European market is an integral part of the Construction Products Regulation and no additional EU regulation is required to deepen cooperation among Member States.

name: Neena Gill
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, for far too long we have not debated the issue of fire safety of buildings, so it is high time we did so. That was my rationale behind proposing to have this debate on fire safety. Twenty years ago I worked in social housing. Our ethos was simple: social housing provides homes for the most vulnerable so it needs to be of the best quality. Clearly, over the years, this message has been diluted, especially in the UK. Had it not, we would not have had the tragedies, such as Grenfell Tower in June. My heartfelt condolences to the families of those affected.  The issue of fire safety should always be at the forefront of our minds. It should not take losing 80 people in an inferno that could have been prevented. But it is not just about what has happened, but also about what could happen in the future. Across the EU there are too many buildings – hospitals, student accommodation and office buildings – that are vulnerable, and a key lesson from Grenfell is that it is not always the fire, but also the toxic fumes that kill people. EU regulations already require that construction work is done to limit the spreading of smoke and fire, but what we need to do is ensure there are fire sprinklers in all buildings, residential and commercial. These rules also need to be enforced and expanded to inform consumers about the toxicity of materials through harmonised labelling.  We also need to secure better fire testing methods for façades that reflect the reality. It concerns me that shortly after Grenfell, instead of trying to strengthen these regulations, the UK Government supported the ‘Red Tape Initiative’ that classified it as an ‘expensive and burdensome’ ‘red tape folly’ that should be abandoned after Brexit. I think it is far too easy to dismiss regulation as red tape, but these regulations save lives and should be strengthened.  Finally, this initiative is supported by firefighters across the EU who put their lives at risk, but very rarely get the kind of hearing they deserve. I sincerely hope that this House will continue to put this high on the agenda.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the importance of fire safety in buildings was all too tragically highlighted by the horrific events at Grenfell Tower in my home city of London. Following the grief, the anger and, sadly, the shameful attempts by some British opposition politicians to exploit the tragedy to score cheap political points, our priority should now be to continue to help the survivors, to help rebuild their lives. My hope is that the full public inquiry that the British Prime Minister has rightly ordered will reveal: why did it happen, what can we learn, how do we prevent a repeat of this terrible tragedy? When MEPs met firefighters from across the EU last week, they told us that this tragedy could easily have occurred in any of their cities. A British firefighter told me that in the UK, an apartment in a high-rise building with the door shut should be able to contain a fire for 40 minutes to allow time for evacuation and to put out the fire. But at Grenfell, the initial reports suggest that the door to a flat may have been open and that the fire escaped through the window and spread by the flammable cladding in a matter of minutes. These are, of course, just initial reports and have yet to be verified. A Belgian firefighter explained that plastics containing petroleum release oils and toxic smoke, making their job more dangerous and suffocating victims. They shared concerns over single staircases in some high-rise buildings, which means that those fleeing fires may block emergency services entering the building. They told me that they are now assessing which buildings in their cities contain similar dangerous cladding. So many issues were exposed by this tragedy that I hope that the Commission’s exchange or proposed exchange will address. But whichever city or country you are from, we need to make sure that at best, such a tragedy does not occur again and at worst, emergency services are able to put out the fires and evacuate residents safely. We owe this to all our citizens and the emergency services that keep us safe. And if you will allow me, as a Londoner born and bred, I am proud when I hear stories of individuals and communities from across London and the UK who came together to support those who had suffered the greatest of losses. Let me end by expressing my deepest sympathies for the victims and their loved ones.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, every day there are 5 000 fire incidents in the EU. The horrors of Grenfell Tower have brought this to the media’s attention, but fire is something that affects the lives of EU citizens no matter where they live. For too long, we have said this is an issue of national competence. But while the devastation of fires might be local,  the sources of what is burning is not. Every part of your house, from the walls to the furniture inside, are products of the single market, and therefore national actions alone will not increase fire safety in the EU. Commissioner, the time has come for the creation of a fire safety strategy for Europe. We need an EU-wide action plan which includes a single EU system to collect comparable fire data and statistics among Member States in order to identify recurring issues and risks; a cooperative forum between Member States to share best practices; and reform of how we test products for fire safety, including for toxic smoke. Like with vehicles, now is the time to take the tests out of the laboratory alone and to test against real life situations. Commissioner, I know that the ALDE Group is willing to revise current and on-going legislative work to ensure that we can get this right. My take-away from this debate is that you have the political support of Parliament to act on fire safety, so I encourage you to do so.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, along with my colleagues I also want to express my condolences to all those affected by the Grenfell fire because I am also elected from the region of London, as is my colleague Syed Kamall.  We still do not know the final death toll from that fire, but we do know that the tragedy itself was a result of a number of factors about regulation, or the lack of effective implementation of regulation, about building design, and about smoke and toxicity. Cyanide gas was certainly related to some of the deaths, but also attitudes to social housing tenants. It was certainly felt by many in the community to have been a part of the tragedy that unfolded – not being listened to, procurement priorities, not prioritising safety – and indeed compounded by the poor disaster response.  So we do need to learn from each other. We do need an effective fire prevention strategy at European level. We need to upgrade our Regulation so that it is fit for purpose wherever you may be living in the European Union, and we also need to listen to the experience of those affected by fire to actually input too from their experience in prevention.

name: Peter Lundgren
text: for the EFDD Group. - Mr President! In the light of the tragedy at Grenfell Tower in the UK, we must work intensively on this issue. Fire safety is a major societal and safety issue. Figures indicate that there are at least 5,000 fire incidents daily in the EU. In many, possibly most, of these events, a community, a company or a family is often affected for several years and sometimes, as in Grenfell, for life. Fires have also changed significantly in character in recent decades. This is due to new, more flammable materials. However, most European countries have not updated their fire regulations adequately to keep up with the rapid renewal of building materials flowing into the market. At European level, the harmonized fire testing and classification rules have not been sufficiently updated to handle modern building materials. In this area, the EU must take action to save lives. No one should have to die in a fire.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! Unfortunately, it always takes dire disasters such as the major fire of London's Grenfell Tower to discuss improvements and to try to introduce them. I particularly welcome the “Fire Safe Europe” initiative because I am an active member of a fire brigade myself, and that is why three points are very important to me from my practice: The first aim should be the high standards that we have in Europe - as in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland - should also be taken as a basis or used as best practice. Second: The security requirements for objects must also be based on the size and use of the object. What can or is right and important for an office building with 30 floors does not necessarily have to be smart for a one-story bungalow. Thirdly, it is important to me that there is a balance between security and innovation. I am thinking here of the energy-saving sector, which is also being considered accordingly. There is also a project in Sweden that is already dealing with this issue. I am very happy with all the measures that are being taken in Europe and will therefore actively support it.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the recent incidents in which we have mourned human lives have shown the need for the whole legal framework on fire safety to be reviewed by the Member States of the European Union. Initially, we must push for the use of new materials that will significantly reduce the risk of both fire and its spread in the event of an accident. It is necessary to define a new test methodology that will realistically represent the behavior of the materials in practice and will not be just a sterile or even under ideal conditions laboratory test. We must also keep in mind that the largest percentage of deaths in fires is due to inhalation of toxic fumes, in fact 60%. With regard to this great danger, I believe that we have done virtually nothing and it is imperative that we impose the use of materials that will greatly reduce it. The same does not apply to the risk of fire transmission through the generation of flammable particles where the current regulatory framework lags behind. Finally, I propose the immediate creation of a state fire safety body, in any country that does not already exist, which will control the quality of the materials used in the construction of buildings and will be responsible in case of accident.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is unfortunate that a tragedy was needed at the Grenfell Tower, which claimed the lives of dozens of people, for us to be having this debate for the first time and for the Member States and the European Commission to take problems in the security of our buildings. I have already seen this film with the European Emergency Number and I am not satisfied either. Grenfell's tragedy happened in London, but it could have happened in Lisbon, Paris or Tallinn. This is a European problem and must be addressed at European level. Fire safety standards vary between Member States. Some are better than others, but all are failing. The principle of subsidiarity cannot and should not be a shield for washing our hands and consciences. A Danish firefighter linked to the Fire Safe Europe movement, which is outside this Chamber, drew my attention to the fact that, while he and his colleagues are confident in dealing with fires inside a room, when it comes to facades cannot control the rapid spread of the flames. This is due to the introduction of highly flammable materials into our buildings and the fact that the Member States have not updated the regulations on fires, new materials coming to the market and also the toxicity of the combustion fumes. The BBC an hour ago revealed the high danger of combustion of chemicals found in the London tragedy. Asks the Commission to take a strong and decisive decision on this issue, I urge all colleagues to pledge their support for a single objective: the security of our citizens. Against fire there is no more time to waste, it is time to act.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Grenfell Tower disaster saw 18 known people dead, with dozens more injured in a blaze of which fire-fighters had never seen the like before. I want to put on record our gratitude in this House towards our emergency services staff who day-in, day-out, put their lives at risk to save others across our Member States. We in this House cannot allow a disaster like Grenfell to happen again. The evidence and enquiry into Grenfell had ramifications across the EU and the British Government, while still a Member of the European Union, has a responsibility to work with its European partners and share information to prevent another tragedy like this from happening. The European Commission are to be commended for having the foresight before the Grenfell Tower tragedy to undertake a study on the need to assess the smoke toxicity of construction products. As a standing rapporteur of this House on construction products, I want to emphasise that smoke toxicity from burning construction products and their testing is an important subject, particularly concerning the health and safety of our emergency services personnel, as well as the victims of fires. In the case of Grenfell, as others have acknowledged, it is generally accepted that the material and structure of the facade enabled the fire to spread as it did. My understanding is that there are currently two facade tests, a large one and a small one, with Member States choosing which one. In the UK, it is the large scale that it is chosen. In the light of the differences across Member States in facade testing, will the Commission adopt a harmonised European method to assess the fire performance of facades, which would guarantee a sufficient level of fire safety to EU citizens? Given the complexity and the nature of the question of fire safety, it is important that national authorities communicate and exchange best practice and it is brilliant today that we have seen action about the platform that has been announced by the Commission. But as currently all Member States regulate fire safety individually, one simple way forward where action could make a difference, is if Member States have a common approach towards the collection and sharing of data.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
