text: - The images of the Grenfell tower are etched in the collective memory.Unfortunately, the human suffering caused by fire is a daily reality in the European Union.About 70,000 Europeans are hospitalized with burns every year and there are 5,000 incidents every day.We cannot solve all problems in the European Union, but we can ensure that we tackle the problems in our area of competence.I propose two things that have also been mentioned here.First, we need to improve testing procedures.Building materials must be tested in realistic conditions and we must also focus more on toxicity testing, because it is often the toxic substances released during combustion that pose an additional threat to people's health.Secondly - and I am pleased that the Commission is announcing this - there must be a platform where Member States can exchange best practices.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, as a London MEP, I must also speak about the Grenfell Tower tragedy in which at least 80 people died horrifically. Now the official inquiry must establish exactly what happened, how and why.  When Grenfell Tower was built, the original cladding material was inert. Fire could not pass through or behind. Since then, specification regulation has passed from national governments to the European Union. EU regulations required a 20% reduction in energy consumption in buildings such as Grenfell under the 2020 energy policy. To achieve this, the local authority may have used combustible material in the cladding when the building was refurbished last year.  The questions for the inquiry to answer are: firstly, exactly what regulations were applicable; secondly, were they strictly adhered to; and thirdly, if they were, then how can they be changed quickly in order to prevent any similar future tragedies in the UK or indeed Europe.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, I listened with interest to your speech and I must say that I almost absolutely identify with it. Thank you for him and I am happy for the realistic goals that you have clearly defined here. I think that the scope of the European Commission is precisely in the area of ​​the single market for building materials. In short and well, the European Commission can do a lot of work to increase the safety of building materials used in Europe in terms of their flammability as such, as well as the smoke toxicity of building materials mentioned here several times. I think that the European Commission can have studies carried out here that can increase the safety of materials that are sold in the European Union in the future and then used in construction. On the other hand, I say, I am not in favor of any other regulations that would affect the citizens themselves. Here, we should also respect the already mentioned subsidiarity, which clearly states that the basis of fire protection falls within the competence of individual nation states. But I agree with your thesis, which you have said here, that the European Commission can be a facilitator, a coordinator between national authorities, between control bodies, and the exchange of information between national authorities can significantly increase the security of individual buildings. So I also support this and thank you for your speech.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the number of fires and their size in recent years confirm that we are facing a very serious problem that affects the whole of Europe and that in order to be combated it needs common, converging policies: we cannot leave individual Member States have the task of preventing or intervening when necessary. For this reason, I believe that the starting point is the modification of the regulation on building materials, starting with those concerning the facades and cladding of buildings: the individual materials, but also the effects that are produced by their mixing, from the fact that they are often used together with very serious consequences, as we have seen in more than one circumstance. The second theme is to investigate the toxicity of the fumes of the materials also inside. It is not true that everything that happens inside is produced by what each of us has in the house or by what occupies the rooms and apartments; it also affects the interior trim, and these too need the same strict control.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR).
text: – Mr President, whilst it is very welcome that Parliament is having the debate this afternoon, I personally wish it did not have to happen in the wake of the terrible Grenfell Tower tragedy. I have been raising the need for a greater focus on fire safety in the EU for many years, calling for greater horizontal thinking in the legislative process and I now hope that the issue will become a priority for Member States and for Members right across the EU. But keeping this tragic event in mind, we must think what sensible steps Member States and the Commission can take. It is the responsibility of Member States to ensure fire safety regulations and standards are applied by industry and enforced by public authorities. Prevention must be the priority going forward, which can only happen through the vigorous enforcement of existing rules relating to the design, construction and the maintenance of buildings. I hope that Member States and the Commission are able to work with industry and the necessary organisations and representatives to find a solution that makes the Grenfell tragedy the last.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is absolutely the task of the European Union to guarantee the safety of citizens who move and go to live in a country other than their own. Unfortunately, two Italian boys also died in the fire of the Grenfell Tower in London, a young couple of architects who came from my region. I think they had the right to live in a safe home. Unfortunately, a BBC news agency earlier told us that Grenfell Tower insulation, the one that burns off cyanide, was found in 34 buildings in an east London borough, Havering, including nine residential homes. We have read that the type of fires in the last decades has changed, because the materials have changed. We have not been quick enough, in some countries less than in others, in adapting the legislation to these changes in construction techniques and materials. My country has made many steps forward since the 1990s. But I don't think enough is ever done. My country could already give some good practices because, for example, we could never have clad a building as tall as Grenfell Tower the way it was clad, which, the technicians said, is one of the reasons why the fire has developed so much. So, I agree with what the Commission is proposing, but I think it is only a first step: we need to do much more to ensure the same level of security for all citizens.

name: Arndt Kohn (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues! As we know, facade fires are not a British phenomenon. All over the world, all over Europe, people die of smoke inhalation, many as a result of facade fires, including in Germany. Five dead in a fire in Cologne in 2005, three dead in a fire in Duisburg last year, to name just two cases. One problem is called polystyrene foam. It is cheap, harmful to the environment, is toxic and promotes the spread of the fire to other floors if no fire bar has been installed. At this point we can learn from countries like Austria or France, where fire bars are mandatory on every floor. So we need European rules that put a stop to facade fires throughout the EU - uniform rules, not just a discussion platform. We need a uniform and independent test procedure - not only so that the residents of the houses are protected, but also so that our firefighters, who risk their own lives for us, can survive these missions without damage to their health. We cannot bring the victims back, but we can prevent further victims.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Romania was marked by the tragedy in the Colectiv club, a fire in which 64 people died and we had, and we have 147 injured. It happened in 2015, the socialist government was in power, which is still today. And he is responsible. In Romania, even today, the fire safety standard P118 is 18 years old and is still blocked at the Ministry of Development. In the Union, the toxicity of smoke and construction products is not tested, even though smoke is the biggest killer in fires. 41% of fire victims are killed by gas, smoke and toxic emissions. Existing requirements for testing and labeling of construction products for fire cases do not require an indication of smoke toxicity. The urgent distribution of large burns between European hospitals with special wards must be regulated under the Civil Protection Mechanism. All this must be part of a European strategy, because 5,000 fires kill people every day in Europe. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: - Commissioner! There is something encouraging in action by firefighters from across the European Union to make fire safety a public topic. If the work of firefighters is to be effective, in addition to toughness, training and modern equipment, social awareness of fire hazards is needed and care for all buildings and their facades to meet fire safety standards. In many countries the regulations are either outdated or the buildings do not meet the requirements. In Poland, an analysis of the toxicity of smoke from various building materials that is generated during a fire has been required for years. This and fire resistance testing must be mandatory everywhere to eliminate and label the most toxic elements. It's not enough to appreciate firefighters. It is necessary to invest in their activities and stimulate the change of regulations in different countries in order to improve safety. A European platform for the exchange of data on threats and good practice is crucial in order to learn best solutions from each other.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, fire protection is important for our entire society. Statistics show that at least five thousand fires occur every day in the European Union. That’s two million fires a year, while 90% of them start in buildings. In the last few decades, fires have developed faster than ever and are becoming increasingly dangerous. This is largely due to the greater use of flammable materials in buildings. Most European countries have not updated fire regulations properly to bring them into line with new building materials on the market. At EU level, fire testing and classification standards have also not been updated accordingly. We must insist on the highest level of fire protection for the citizens of the European Union. Anything less than that is not enough. We can and must make the European Union fire-safe. We need to protect our citizens, but also firefighters, whose health is also deteriorating and they are more exposed to the risk of tumors. As a volunteer firefighter, I would like to take this opportunity to thank all firefighters across the European Union for rescuing people and property and for testifying by their example and life what kind of people we should be.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in June we watched in horror the fire that destroyed the Grenfell Tower where 79 people lost their lives. We now know that the tower was built in the seventies and rehabilitated last year. However, the new coating has never been tested for fire and residents' complaints have never been answered. We all know that in fire risk management, prevention is of high importance. Last week, I met with firefighters from all over Europe who were in Parliament urging the European Union institutions to act on behalf of building safety and to prioritize building safety standards that use more effective fire testing methods, on the façades, harmonized labeling and improved information to the consumer, as well as the development of a European strategy aimed at an integrated and coordinated approach in this area. Commissioner, if the responsibility for establishing rules on safety limits in buildings lies with the Member States, the life, health and well-being of European citizens is a collective responsibility of all of us, that no principle or rule subsidiarity can be invoked to remove.

name: Marek Plura (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!After the London tragedy, we all realize that it cannot repeat itself.We need safer building materials, a better fire protection system, comprehensive solutions also at the European level.I want the issue of people with disabilities to emerge clearly in this discussion.Imagine the situation of a man in a wheelchair who, in the chaos of a fire, has to evacuate himself by stairs.Fire alarms and warning systems must also be available in practice, not only in theory, for the blind or deaf.It is therefore necessary to develop an effective aid system and a platform for the exchange of best practices.Commissioner, I would like to pledge all my assistance in this matter.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent Grenfell Tower tragedy must lead us to review our approach to building fire safety. National governments are the first to intervene on this issue, but the European Union can also play an important role. We need to work on prevention. I share the proposal for an EU platform for the exchange of information and best practices to improve fire safety. Comparable data and credible tests on the behavior of building facades in the event of fire are needed. The transparency of the toxicity level of smoke generated by the fire of individual construction products must be ensured. The review of the Construction Products Regulation can be an ideal opportunity to improve the regulation. Each product manufactured with CE marking, in addition to the fire safety values, should have an indication of its toxicity to smoke. This elementary principle of transparency is an indispensable condition to empower builders and consumers, allowing them to make informed choices about construction products.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the shocking pictures of the Grenfell Tower blaze must serve as a wake-up call to all law makers, and we must work towards a common fire safety strategy. I recently met with colleagues from the University of Central Lancashire in my constituency, and they pointed out that while fire toxicity in trains, planes and ships is regulated, there is a real lack of regulation in the construction sector. Renovation works at Grenfell were inspected 16 times by the local authority, showing current rules simply aren’t fit for purpose. So I urge the Commission to do two things: first, to meet with the scientists and experts as part of the DG GROW study, and secondly to incorporate an assessment of the fire toxicity of construction products into the existing regulation. This both benefits and protects consumers because we need a fire strategy that puts people first and it is shameful that it has taken a tragedy like Grenfell to put fire safety back on the agenda.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, what happened at Grenfell is a terrible tragedy and I agree with all the speakers that have said that better regulation must be implemented, but who is going to monitor this? I can say that I am one of a very few, if not the only local councillor, to have spoken in this debate, and I deal week-in, week-out, with local government repairs and maintenance. I know from experience that the current regime of contracting out and tendering out maintenance and repairs of council properties, like the Grenfell Tower, is an absolute disaster. They deal on the profit motive instead of human welfare, and until we bring council maintenance and repairs back in-house, you can say everything you like about repairs and everything you like about maintenance, but unless it is brought under complete democratic control and accountability then all the goodwill will be for nothing.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, a fire that started in the kitchen of an apartment in London and killed dozens of people has led us to refer today to the fire safety of buildings. However, the fire started by Molotov cocktails thrown by anti-authoritarians, caressed children of the ruling party in Greece, at the Marfin branch in 2010 during the riots in Athens due to the memoranda imposed on my country, Greece, and during which three young people were killed and one unborn child was not moved. As, after today's debate, buildings will be improved, fire safety measures will be strengthened and the corresponding building regulations will be tightened, so will Union policy, which has led to the suicide of hundreds of my compatriots and created millions of unemployed on the brink of poverty. , must change, otherwise "we burned".

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this discussion makes it crystal clear: we all know where we are in terms of the regulatory and legal arrangement here. The work of the Commission in assessing the situation must be pursued and, if needed, intensified, and should the Commission come out with a new proposal on it, I can reassure you that the Council is ready to discuss.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable Members, thank you very much for this exchange of views. I think it was very important for all of us to have it today. First things first, of course, I have to say that the Commission and I personally share more of your concerns. I also share your conviction that the tragedy like the one in London must not happen again, and we have to do our best to ensure this. I want to conclude with three points. First, as I said before, for now we have no proof that national rules are not working but, of course, the Commission is examining now the new issues which were mentioned by many of you like smoke toxicity and the fire-behaviour of facades with independent studies. I want the results of this work to be concluded and to have it before 16 October, so before the first meeting of our new fire information exchange platform. Second, we will act when EU intervention is needed. Of course, we treat our fire information exchange platform as a first step, and of course we can re-examine what else we can do after discussion between the Member States and between the stakeholders – because industry will be an important stakeholder and an important partner in the platform. We can think about steps to be taken in the future. But of course, and this is my deepest conviction, we should do no more than is necessary to ensure the single market of construction products. So let’s wait until 16 October, and let’s discuss the issue. We do not have any proof that it’s not working now – there are national regulations that are not working but of course, the first thing is the national regulations and the second thing is enforcement of those regulations, and this also we should examine. These are the three points from my side and of course I am open to any comments and any discussion with you on this important issue.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed, but the issue is not closed. I think it was clear today that we have just embarked on a process which will bring us back to the issue. May I also take this opportunity to extend sympathy and condolences, not just to our British colleagues, but especially to those who were enormously and tragically affected by the fire.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - We have more than 5 000 emergency fires in the European Union every day. Every year, around 70,000 people in Europe have to be hospitalized as a result of fires. Every year, fires in the EU cause more than the entire EU budget. The fire causes not only great human and material damage, but also the destruction of important data, reduces productivity, increases unemployment and bankruptcies. It has implications for carbon emissions and is a major challenge to the sustainability of energy sources and the environment. We do not know how construction products behave in a real fire situation. We also do not know how toxic the fumes of their eventual combustion are. Over the next 30 years, the number of residential buildings in Slovakia will increase by a quarter. Similarly in many other EU countries. It is very important that these millions of new flats and family houses are safe. The vast majority of injuries and deaths from building fires are caused by the effects of smoke and its toxicity. It is therefore crucial that we in Europe have better and harmonized testing methods for construction products that can verify their behavior in the event of a fire. We need to be able to provide consumers with information on the toxicity and hazardous materials of some building structures and insulation systems and to clearly differentiate products according to their degree of toxicity.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. – I call on the Commission and the Council to stop playing the competence alibi game and to agree to assess fire smoke toxicity. We know that fire smoke is not only responsible for half the deaths in building fires, it also represents long-term health risks for those who survive such tragedies, including those risking their lives to save others on a daily basis – firefighters. Today, our health is at risk by failing to address this issue. We test construction materials for smoke opacity, but not toxicity. That’s wrong. Buildings have changed radically since the Construction Products Directive (CPR) introduction 17 years ago. Combustible materials have replaced brick and metal; they burn quickly, releasing different amounts of toxic gases. Conclusion: information about toxicity of burning construction materials must be available to our citizens, architects, traders so everyone can make informed decisions. Why not add fire toxicity to the classification system of the CPR? With fellow MEPs, we proposed this at our conference in Parliament two years ago. The Commission’s response could have been quicker; nevertheless I encourage the Commission during its current assessment of such idea and I ask the Council to cooperate. We have been playing with fire too long.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Morten Løkkegaard, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the accessibility requirements for products and services (COM(2015)0615 – C8-0387/2015 – 2015/0278(COD)) (A8-0188/2017).

name: Morten Løkkegaard
text: spokesperson. - Sir. Chairman! Commissioner! coworkers! We are only a single day away from having to make a very important decision here in this House. A decision that will have far-reaching consequences for 70-80 million of our fellow citizens here in Europe. It is the 70-80 million who are disabled in one way or another, and therefore cannot live their lives to the fullest, because it has been made difficult by this disability, and we must of course help them with that. It is time that we, with hopefully one vote, give the little extra momentum that is needed for these 70-80 million people to have a better life, and so we have the chance for now. Many have missed common rules for accessibility in products and services. It is actually a battle that has been going on for decades, and now the opportunity is there, so it is now we have the chance, but it also requires that we stand together here in the house. A divided Parliament will be a gift to the Council. A united Parliament, a strong mandate will be absolutely crucial for us to get through with just some of the excellent proposals that we intend to make in this report, which the Council - and it is no secret - like many Member States have been very skeptical for one reason or another. That is why we need a strong mandate. The struggle for better conditions for the disabled is, after all, a struggle that is basically a social policy struggle. It is a battle for which the EU therefore has no direct competence, and therefore it can be said that the Commission's proposal in this area is quite smart, in that it enters the area of ​​the internal market and moves into the social policy area. via the internal market. This is a good way to move forward, you can say, when you now do not have the competence in the other area. It also means that, as rapporteur, I, those of us who have been dealing with it for some time now, have to go through a difficult and delicate balancing act. After all, there are suddenly two considerations to take. The one consideration is quite obvious, it is to these many millions of disabled citizens, so they get better opportunities and better accessibility. But on the other hand, we as Parliament must also make sure that we preserve the crown jewel, if I may say so, 'the internal market' unharmed, that we do not, with all these well-meaning and excellent proposals, help to damage an internal market, as we otherwise do everything we can to make it work better. So in other words, it's a balancing act, and I think we have tried - or at least I have tried - to keep that balance. The task is to find a balance, so that companies are not burdened with unnecessary administration, that we do not create even more bureaucratic monsters, while we ensure that we through framework legislation ensure that companies are also encouraged to innovate, are encouraged to create better products that will ultimately benefit these many disabled people. I think that the report that accompanies the accompanying amendments has struck that balance. I think we have a good result and I really hope that there will be great support for it. I am aware - and I hope everyone who has been involved will agree with me - that it has not been easy, it is not easy. It's an area that has great interests at stake and it's also more than interest, it's actually a lot of emotions as well, and I want to emphasize on this occasion that those emotions I understand quite well. I think we all know someone who is affected by disabilities in one way or another and therefore has to live their lives in a different way, so I fully understand that we just need to strike the balance. I think, as I said, it succeeded, and I would like to thank the groups that have contributed to us actually getting a vote tomorrow, because it was actually becoming a problem, too, because this report has become so long with all these amendments so that we start to have a problem getting through tomorrow, but then we succeeded in the end.Thanks for the help.And, of course, thanks to all the rapporteurs who have struggled along the way and who have also had struggles with the undersigned.I think we have reached a good result.Also thanks to the IMCO Secretariat with Thierry, who has fought well, and not least to my tireless assistant Anne.I hope for a good result tomorrow.Thank you.

name: Ádám Kósa
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, the legislative report before us is very important, because we all know that there is a close link between mobility, disability and social inclusion. Without freedom of communication, movement and access to services, people with disabilities will not be able to fully integrate into society. In order to move towards full accessibility, compatible and efficient solutions need to be created and facilitated in the single market. At the same time, we need to safeguard and protect the fragile drivers of innovation. Otherwise, legislation may be enacted that only prescribes but does not serve development. There are a lot of innovations in my life that can be attributed to the market, not legislation. This is why it is important to find a healthy balance. As rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I am of the opinion that what helps to achieve these goals must be supported by the Council, so all ... (The President cut off the floor)

name: Keith Taylor
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, I was rapporteur for this Transport and Tourism Committee opinion on the report by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and I heard from the European Disability Forum that their number one priority was improved access of transport services for their members, especially in terms of the built environment. There are currently 80 million people with reduced mobility in the EU for whom any regular journey by bus or underground or rail can be a daily nightmare. The Transport Committee adopted my report, which included mandatory improvements to the built environment, but I was disappointed when the Internal Market Committee, the lead committee, did not adopt any of those ideas so, under Rule 54, plenary is now being asked to vote on the amendments that the Internal Market Committee ruled out. The vote is tomorrow. These provisions ensure barrier—free journeys for everyone and would fundamentally improve the lives of disabled people. So please, fellow Members, vote for the Transport Committee and the Green amendments tomorrow. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, and the rapporteurs from the other committees. The Commission has been working hard to foster social inclusion in Europe and this Parliament has been one of our strongest supporters. But we will never achieve our goals as long as everyday life remains as inaccessible as it is today for 80 million Europeans with a disability.  The solutions exist to make accessibility happen and demand for accessible products and services will only increase as Europe’s population is ageing. But the gap between what is possible and what has actually been achieved in reality remains large.  The European Union is committed to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and its obligations on accessibility. We celebrated the Convention’s 10th anniversary last year. People with a disability are expecting us to act – now. Last year’s adoption of the Web Accessibility Directive constituted an important step forward and I welcome that Parliament is now ready to set out its position on the Commission proposal for a European Accessibility Act.  The Accessibility Act aims at using the full potential of our single market to trigger real change in people’s lives. It puts forward a common European approach to accessibility, instead of having 28 national ones. This common approach will maximise opportunities and minimise costs for European businesses and consumers. The experience from the US has shown very well how accessibility policies can be a catalyst for economic growth and inclusion. I welcome the fact that Parliament’s report supports the Commission’s objective to improve accessibility. It brings a number of useful clarifications, also concerning the relation with existing EU legislation. But I would like to take this opportunity to highlight the Commission’s position on some of the main points under debate.  First, preservation of the integrity of the internal market. About 95% of EU companies are either microenterprises or SMEs. Many of them have to deal with new accessibility requirements, for instance due to the new ‘buy accessible’ obligations in public procurement legislation. But, they do not have the same resources or capacities to deal with changing regulatory requirements. The Commission has therefore introduced strong safeguard clauses and light rules in terms of conformity assessment, in particular for microenterprises.  However, a blanket exclusion of microenterprises would not only put at risk the objective of the proposal, it would seriously distort the functioning of the internal market. For instance, a microenterprise might be allowed to import non-accessible products from third countries, such as smartphones, while EU producers have to comply with accessibility requirements.  Secondly, public procurement and EU funds. We want public money to be invested in accessible products, services and buildings. Buying accessible is already a general obligation in the EU Public Procurement Directives, but more is needed to ensure a proper internal market in this area. The Accessibility Act puts forward a list of functional requirements so that industry knows what to deliver, users know what to expect and public authorities know what to ask for.  This brings me to the last point. The accessibility requirements will determine the level of accessibility of our products and services in the internal market for the coming decades. So, indeed, we need to be flexible as technological possibilities are constantly changing. That is why the Accessibility Act puts forward functional accessibility requirements instead of prescribing the detailed technical solutions to achieve them. But we also need to ensure that our laws are effective and enforceable, and provide legal certainty both for industry and consumers.  In light of the still ongoing work in the Council, the Commission will stand ready to support the co-legislators in clarifying and further detailing the accessibility requirements. We have a chance here to make a real difference, both for citizens and for business. The Commission counts on your support.

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mister President! The report on audiovisual media presented by the rapporteur offers a good compromise which a majority should support. The scope of this guideline therefore includes web offers and mobile offers with regard to audiovisual media, while the audiovisual media service as such remains comprehensively and conclusively regulated in the AVMSD, including with regard to accessibility. We are well on the way here in the negotiations with the Council. In this respect, I am grateful to Mr Løkkegaard for the clarifications in both the article and the recital. We need clear boundaries in order to create legal certainty for everyone involved. I would also have liked to see reading devices standardized in relation to e-books, but not the reading software, because I am convinced that the software would then follow the existing standard in the devices. I also see that the European Accessibility Act is a compromise that was difficult to balance. You can ask for more, I personally do that too. At the same time, however, one also has to recognize which majorities we have. Let us agree to the compromise and yet let us not tire of fighting on and on for better accessibility. Then we are a big step further, but certainly not there yet.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr. President, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the European Strategy on Disability 2010-2020 itself, and so many instruments appeal to freedom, the rule of law and equality. Our President Juncker said it today in the debate on the state of the European Union. We are, in essence, the defense of freedom, equality and the rule of law. We have the opportunity, with the approval of this European Accessibility Act, to show that Europe has a soul and to show that Europe believes in equality. Accessibility is participation; accessibility is equality; accessibility is removing obstacles to free movement; accessibility is to support the right to integrity of people; It is to support the right to dignity of the people, the right to education, to work, to free movement and residence. That is why tomorrow's vote is important. We have to be more ambitious than the text that has been approved in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and we have to bet on the line proposed by the Commission: support the amendments of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Commission of Transport and Tourism so that all micro-companies and SMEs also make a bet. The dignity of the people is at stake, democracy is at stake. Human values ​​have to be above economic values.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. - Mr President, we have been calling for years for the implementation of the European Accessibility Act to improve the lives of people with disabilities - our 80 million fellow human beings with problems - and the elderly in a rapidly aging Europe. Unfortunately, the report we are discussing is even further back than the Commission text that proposed the minimum. Why did this happen; Because the report examines only the views expressed by market lobbyists and not the demands of the disabled. Colleagues, this may change now, it is not too late. Dear colleagues, make a difference. Vote for amendments that support improving the lives of people with disabilities. Do not allow, because of the demands of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, a disabled European accessibility act to be initiated with the barriers posed by the report.

name: Sabine Verheyen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Well over 80 million people with disabilities and many more people with functional limitations and the elderly are affected by this legislation and will benefit from it. It is therefore urgent that we finally act and fulfill the promise made by the Member States in 2008 to implement essential steps towards accessibility. The Internal Market Committee has drawn up a good and balanced text for this. On the one hand, we are expanding the scope of the Commission proposal to include payment terminals. On the other hand, in contrast to the Commission, we provide for a mandatory inclusion of the built environment, which means that in the future, accessibility must be planned for new buildings and fundamental renovations. But we also need rules that are realistic, feasible and future-proof and that do not create unnecessary bureaucracy. That is why we advocate less bureaucratic solutions for SMEs and an exception for micro enterprises. We want to give space to new technologies and developments, which is why we are committed to an innovation-friendly approach in the annex. The Accessibility Act is thus another big and important step towards complete accessibility, and I very much hope that we can work out an agreement with the Council and the Commission as soon as possible so that the situation for people with disabilities finally continues and in a timely manner improved. I would therefore like to call on you all to vote tomorrow in the interests of the Internal Market Committee and thereby enable us to achieve a good and quick result in the interests of people with disabilities. Because concrete, real results are always better than pure full-bodied promises.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: for the group S & amp; D. - Mr President, the aim of the European Accessibility Act is to make a significant contribution to the deepening and fairer functioning of the internal market. This proposal can significantly improve the quality of life not only for people with disabilities, but also, for example, senior citizens, and contribute to their full participation in society. As part of the digitalisation of European society, which we actively support through a number of measures, it is particularly important to set up a non-discriminatory environment vis-à-vis vulnerable groups from the outset. In view of the aging population, one hundred and twenty million people to whom this legislation is addressed are expected to live in Europe in just a few years. I would like to remind you that it is the European Parliament that has in the past called on the Commission to come up with an ambitious proposal and called for it to cover all policy areas concerning the accessibility of goods and services for all citizens of the European Union. It is therefore necessary to ask whether the text presented by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection is sufficiently ambitious. For us Social Democrats, no. Weakening the Commission's original proposal in its current form is unacceptable to us and it would be a defeat for the European Parliament to enter into negotiations with Member States with a weakened mandate. We are therefore proposing a number of amendments. For the public, the act of accessibility should be a regulation that will facilitate the use of ordinary services and goods not only by people with disabilities, but also, for example, by the already mentioned elderly people or pregnant women. The proposed measures should therefore take into account the needs of persons with disabilities. We see great potential in setting common requirements for making the built environment accessible. Our aim is to help the Member States and the European Union as a whole to meet their obligations under the United Nations Convention on Accessibility. I also consider it essential to clarify the relationship between the act and other legislation that addresses the issue of accessibility by sector. It is important to avoid overlapping or even duplication requirements.However, even existing legislation, for example in the field of transport, does not contain a number of accessibility requirements, and here the act should play its irreplaceable role.I will also comment on the proposed exceptions, taking into account the interests of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.Please keep in mind that the Commission's proposal has already allowed entrepreneurs to opt out of accessibility requirements on the basis of meeting the defined criteria, and we have still specified these criteria.In my view, the principle of better regulation does not consist in granting a number of general exceptions, thanks to which the act will remain only a wish on paper.We are facing a vote on legislation that will allow European citizens to use everyday services and goods without distinction, on an equal footing.Please take this unique opportunity.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - It is now or never: it is imperative that we send out a clear signal from Europe. People with disabilities must be able to participate smoothly in daily life. I therefore call on anyone who shares that opinion to vote in favor of the Løkkegaard report tomorrow. A well-defined forward-looking list of products and services should put an end to products and services that are not accessible. I am thinking of e-books, televisions, telephones and so much more. The new rules also leave sufficient flexibility for manufacturers and producers. They will be able to choose how they want to make their products more accessible. And that approach goes hand in hand with innovation. Colleagues, let us not run the risk of creating unrealistic expectations that we cannot meet. After all, we will ultimately have no results and we will disappoint a lot of people. We can take important steps forward here. So let's do that.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as a member of the Disability Intergroup for the last 12 years, I and many colleagues in this House warmly welcome the publication of the accessibility act. I want to take this opportunity to thank our rapporteur, Morten Løkkegaard, for his commitment reaching a balanced text and ask colleagues to support ALDE amendments tomorrow. Where we state that, first of all, Member States should be obliged to include the built environment under the scope of the directive; where we include people with functional limitations when assessing the burden on businesses; and where we propose to delete Amendment 78 to ensure the accessibility act will apply to other union acts such as public procurement and EU funds; we also wish to include SMEs within the scope of the act. Is this proposal perfect? No it is not. But we have addressed the significant majority of the concerns of the Disability Forum. We also know that there will be resistance in Council to these proposals, so we need to give Parliament the strongest possible mandate tomorrow when they enter into negotiations.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, as has already been said, there are currently over 80 million people with disabilities in Europe. This number will continue to increase as the population ages. Even as a doctor, I know that people with disabilities often have problems accessing many key products and services. What seems obvious to us is a major problem for them in everyday life. However, the report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection will not help them much, the resulting text is, in my view, weaker than the Commission came up with. For example: What good will an ATM in a wheelchair have if a person does not get to a bank that will not be accessible? Or how is it possible to talk about the accessibility of the metro, for example, when many stations lack lifts for the disabled? I therefore want to appeal to all those who care about the situation of people with disabilities, the long-term sick or the elderly and are not indifferent to their situation to support those proposals tomorrow which aim for real improvement and not just cosmetic treatment on paper. Commission President Juncker said here today that it is not permissible to create different categories of citizens in Europe. I fully agree with that. It would be shameful for people with disabilities to be second-class citizens.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - So this directive, which we will be voting on tomorrow, is an extremely important document, as it concerns more than 80 million Europeans, representing almost 15% of the total population, but this number will increase over the years as Europe becomes an old lady and older there will be more from year to year. That is why we need a document that is ambitious enough and will be valid for a large number of years. Unfortunately, however, I find that this document is not ambitious enough to disregard everything that has been communicated to us even by those most affected by this document. They said that they were missing quite a few important things that would make their daily lives easier, so we have tabled a number of amendments that have taken into account their calls, the calls of people with disabilities to improve this document, and we want to contribute to making this document document for a longer period of time. Let us also consider, of course, offering with this document a hand, the hand of an inclusive society, to which Europe naturally swears through its documents and its fundamental principles, which President Juncker also spoke about today, and vote for our amendments and many will be grateful. Europeans.

name: Marco Zullo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Accessibility Act is a legislation of historical significance and we, with tomorrow's vote, can significantly improve the quality of life, not only of European citizens with disabilities, but also of citizens with functional limitations, such as those due to age or pregnancy. So when the rapporteur opened his speech today by saying that there are many interests at stake, I can confirm that this is true: the interests of some 120 million European citizens are at stake. This is the impact of this legislation. So, we must have the courage to dare, to draw a road towards the future that today scares someone but that opens the door to accessibility, opens the door to services, the job market, education, transport, entertainment. , including the use of smartphones. And so, as a 5 Star Movement, we too have presented amendments to improve this legislation and to make it more ambitious. First of all, is the one on the accessibility of the built environment: we cannot accept the fact, in some way, of making fun of the citizen, telling him that we offer him a service, for example an accessible ATM, but then to this ATM you can't get there, because the building that contains it is not accessible. We must go beyond what these limitations are also of the locals. We want to dare because we want to extend this legislation to those who have functional limitations, as we have said before, therefore an injury, pregnancy, age, because it will affect everyone a little. So we have to design a welcoming world, also for the future. And we are surprised that this accessibility legislation does not strongly include compliance with these requirements when it comes to public tenders. This is also why we presented an amendment, because for us of the 5 Star Movement, no one must stay behind.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the solidarity I am going to tell you about today is not Mr Juncker's. Mr Juncker's solidarity - and the speech this morning did not reassure me on this matter - comes down to this: the others before our own. I see solidarity very differently: ours before others. And among our people, whom we must defend as a priority, there are the weakest and the most vulnerable, including the disabled. Mr Juncker's largesse and generosity to migrants should make those who support him blush with shame, when we see the little attention our elites pay to the suffering of our people. The issue of accessibility in the broad sense must be a civilizational leap of solidarity towards our weakest and most vulnerable citizens: our children, our elders, the disabled. This issue must therefore not be used for the benefit of the political and financial objectives of the Commission, which attempts by the text to force the Member States a little more to adopt the single market in full. Harmonization of the 28 Member States is a utopia. Only a strong and sovereign state can and should take care of its weakest citizens.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President, and I am pleased that we have managed to reach an agreement here in the European Parliament which raises the requirements for access by people with various restrictions to products and services in our common market. Of course, many of us would prefer these requirements to go even further, but already during the discussions in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, where I sit, we clearly saw that we must be realistic, that not everything is possible at once and that we must take taking into account the costs and changes for entrepreneurs (I am thinking mainly about the smallest ones). This does not mean, of course, that no further efforts should be made, but we must do so step by step, prudently and judiciously. On the one hand, we must make our market more and more open to people not only with various disabilities, but also for the elderly, as many colleagues and many female colleagues have already mentioned. On the other hand, we must ensure that these requirements are rational, support innovation, and do not lead our entrepreneurs to collapse. Adapting products and services to the needs of all of us, as we are, also translates into expanding the base of our common market, which is a huge benefit for entrepreneurs. We are still a long way from implementing these changes, because the Council has not yet adopted a general approach, but I hope it will happen soon so that our citizens can feel the positive effects of this directive as soon as possible. I expect, among other things, the Polish government to be very positive in this matter at the Council forum. Thank you colleagues, thank you Morten Løkkegaard for his hard work to break down barriers for all EU citizens.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two years ago we welcomed with great satisfaction the fact that the European Commission had prepared this act on accessibility, which for the first time designed an overall regulatory framework to make Europe more accessible and more inclusive. . I must say it honestly: we are not satisfied and cannot show the same satisfaction with the result that will come out of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, which was approved, however, by a small majority. We cannot hide a strong disappointment in the fact that this is one of the very rare times in which Parliament is not, among the European institutions, the one that is at the head of battles in favor of the rights of citizens, especially those who have greater fragility. We regret that the rapporteur did not have the will to find a more ambitious summary point than the one he presented to us. I regret that the rapporteur did not adopt at least some of the amendment proposals, not to satisfy the requests of our shadow rapporteur Olga Sehnalová or the S & amp; D group, but to respond to the requests that have come and are coming, also in these hours, from all over Europe, from the representatives of citizens who experience different degrees of disability. I believe, dear colleagues, that we still have time to improve this text and not to disappoint citizens' expectations, as well as to honor this House.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this is a very important file and will open up many more goods and services to ensure that everyone can benefit from them. Accessibility is key to that: making everyday products and services that many of us take for granted easier to use for people with different needs, but a balance has to be achieved to make sure that everyone can adapt in a reasonable timeframe and without undue cost. But I believe we have got a very good balance and we will support Mr Løkkegaard’s report. It is also worth remembering that this act will help more than 150 million elderly people in Europe, making their lives easier. Allowing more independent living for longer is critical as our population continues to age. So I very much welcome this report and the real and tangible improvements that it will make to everyday lives. We debated this at length in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. When people say that they want to be more ambitious, I struggle to understand what they mean. A proposal has to be realistic. Otherwise it is not ambitious at all, just virtue seeking. This is a realistic proposal and it will advance accessibility for disabled people. Let’s get behind it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I want to congratulate the rapporteur for this report, Mr Løkkegaard, because this text brings anticipation and prudence, and I sincerely thank him for the effort made to integrate proposals. They better balance the needs of people with disabilities and the possibilities of responding to them from the public and private sectors. In addition, the way is being opened to turn innovation into the best tool in favor of the integration of disability, and measures are anticipated so that this elimination of barriers benefits other types of functional diversity, although an exact definition of it has yet to be finalized. that term. Finally, this text is a sample of how to solve problems of legislative collision before they occur and fill some gaps that are not covered by sectoral and national legislation. For this reason, I am going to support some amendments that try to solve some black holes that must be solved urgently. For example, that of obliging reforms and new works in the areas and complementary infrastructures of basic services, such as transport, to necessarily incorporate accessibility.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I was the shadow for both the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ and the Committee on Petitions’ opinions on Parliament’s report on the Accessibility Act and we worked hard for these opinions. We are very disappointed with the text adopted by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO). For us in the Greens-EFA Group there are a number of red lines in this text. First of all, regarding the scope: persons with functional limitations, which includes not only disabled persons, as the scope mentions in IMCO report, but also persons with reduced mobility, older people and people carrying strollers. We also insist on including built environment related to the provision of goods and services. We also stand for accessibility obligations, also from micro-enterprises. I hope that voting on appropriate amendments will improve the report, otherwise we cannot support it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF).
text: - Mr President, to complement on a technical level the remarks of my colleague Mylène Troszczynski on the accessibility directive, I would add that it is important to stress that the harmonization, a priori legitimate, desired by the Union European Union to facilitate the daily life of a disabled person when traveling in their own country or in Europe, may well, according to the proposed text, lead to the opposite of the desired goal. By creating criteria that are too technical, too precise, too coercive, this text would become a permanent obstacle for all innovative companies, often start-ups developed in countries which, like France, have largely anticipated the development of IT tools and accessibility services for the benefit of all kinds of disabilities. Conversely, other countries less advanced in the field will find it very difficult to align. All in all, as always, behind a laudable idea, undoubtedly hides an economic trap of market capture, that of the 100 million more or less severe handicapped people expected in 2020. Be careful therefore to the instrumentalization of the handicap.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I think it's great that the life expectancy of our citizens is increasing all the time. This, too, means that as many as 120 million people in the EU will soon be living with more or less pronounced impairments. We pay special attention to them - but not only to them. It's not about part of society, it's about all of us. We must give all citizens independent access to services and products. As a co-founder of our Disability Intergroup, I have been committed to this goal for years. In bus, rail, air and ship traffic, there are already numerous special regulations for people with restricted mobility. This already stipulates that assistance services must be offered to them and that they must not be impaired. Now, with the text that is to be voted on tomorrow, we should not undermine existing legislation, but rather supplement it. As far as the built environment is concerned, I think that we need to extend the standard we have in rail transport to other types of transport. That is why I support the compromise that was found in the IMCO. It is good that we go well beyond what the Commission originally proposed and that we are not leaving the choice to the Member States, but rather that we are obliged to make the built environment - such as the platform and bus stop - accessible. That would be another good step towards increasing accessibility in a coherent way.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President. Today, more than one hundred and twenty million disabled people in Europe are waiting for our ambitious decision. Everyone is waiting for European accessibility acts - disabled people and the elderly, parents with small children in wheelchairs, and people who have suffered temporary injuries and are therefore unable to move freely. That is why we must identify both the community of people with disabilities and people with disabilities as the beneficiaries of this legislation, as this is the only way to identify and assess each time the wide range of beneficiaries of the Accessibility Act. Our day-to-day helpers based on smart technologies - telephones, computers, televisions, as well as self-service terminals - have already made the lives of people with disabilities a little easier. But we must go further. A person with a disability does not have to incur additional costs due to the fact that he or she needs adapted telephones, televisions, computers. The additional cost of a disability that has not been voluntarily chosen is simply discrimination. That is why all these devices must be made from the outset to suit a person with a disability. That is why I am addressing the rapporteur, Mr Lokkegaard, and other Liberal and Conservative Members today: do not make a mistake in tomorrow's vote, we cannot adopt such a report without the additional amendments tabled, because then we will not improve the lives of people with disabilities and people with temporary disabilities.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: - There are about 80 million people with a disability and about 150 million elderly people in Europe. Any legislation that improves the accessibility of products and services is a step forward that benefits millions of people in Europe. I therefore welcome the Løkkegaard report, although I think it could have been a bit more. I like to stand up for more ambition. Inspiration for this can be found in the United States, for example. There, the Americans with disabilities Act caused a true cultural change. Not only the government, but also private companies of all kinds regard accessibility as an opportunity rather than an obligation. I am thinking of Apple, for example, which launched its latest iPhone yesterday. Apple understands that responding to the needs of people with disabilities can be a competitive advantage in a hyper-competitive market. And there are many more examples to give. Hopefully, tomorrow's mood will provide a meaningful step forward, a step towards a world where people with disabilities and the elderly can participate smoothly in daily life without being confronted with obstacles that hinder participation.

name: Marek Plura (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! In the course of discussions on the accessibility act, the issue of costs and burdens resulting from adjustments is often raised. Meanwhile, in my opinion, focusing on the availability of goods and services is primarily an investment. Disabled people and the elderly are a huge group of consumers interested in spending money on available services and goods. It is also a group with serious social and economic potential. We should also remember that the act of accessibility is a natural consequence of our EU international obligations, and the consequence of the civilization development of Europe is the creation of an accessible environment in which everyone can lead an active life and contribute to common social and economic development. That is why I am calling for the adoption of the ambitious draft Accessibility Act that millions of Europeans are waiting for. Tomorrow we will take the first step in this direction, I hope. Maybe not as big as we would like, but definitely not the last one.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D).
text: - Mr President! Finally, we would then have an act of accessibility in the EU. Many of us have worked for it for a long time. But oh how wrong it can be! For once, Parliament has succeeded in weakening the Commission's proposal. The data that is now on the table puts companies ahead of people. It is up to the companies to decide whether they want to make their products and services available to everyone or not. Perhaps most outrageous is the view of the built environment and how demands for it to be made accessible to people with disabilities have now been removed. An embarrassment - yes, in fact an abuse of all people with disabilities! This shows a clear difference between left-wing and right-wing politics. However, I hope we will win this battle tomorrow. However, I am amazed at the total inability of the right-wing groups to realize the consequences of their actions. If companies are constantly meeting, more and more people will be excluded from the internal market. That people with disabilities, for example, are not allowed to take part in transport, withdraw money from an ATM - if anything, one should understand that it threatens the entire core of the internal market where citizens should be in focus. The key to a better Europe is a social Europe that stands up for the equal value of all human beings.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, people with disabilities are one of the most vulnerable social groups. It is our duty to create a socio-economic atmosphere that will include them in every sense and offer them the opportunity to achieve maximum life in both personal and business terms. The accessibility of different products and services to people with disabilities throughout the European Union is important, not only from the perspective of the actual functioning of the single market, but primarily to meet their living needs. Such regulation is therefore extremely necessary, but we must not forget that it is quite expensive and burdensome for entrepreneurs, as recognized by the rapporteur. I welcome the solution according to which micro-enterprises would be completely exempted from this Directive, and a lighter regime would be applied to small and medium-sized enterprises. This solution is proof that a balance between market demands and social policies, on the one hand, and the real possibilities of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, on the other, can still be achieved. They are the bearers of European economic prosperity, they employ the vast majority of employees in the private sector and therefore we must always keep them in mind when adopting new regulations.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome the publication of the Accessibility Act. We have been hearing from many speakers today about the 80 million citizens that are not able or have limited abilities, and of course 120 million ageing people, and who knows which of us will not be able tomorrow, or may be disabled and requiring the very services and accessibility that we are discussing today.  So now is the time to put in place a society that is accessible. We need to be bold and we need to be ambitious and recognise that citizens do need products and services and public spaces that are accessible to them, and that if we want to have an inclusive society, this is what we need to put in place. I am of the opinion that we need to send a strong message to the Council and to the Commission of what we want. We represent the citizens of Europe here and the cost of accessibility should not be looked upon as a burden but rather, in my view, as an investment; an investment towards an inclusive and caring society.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: - Sur President, ħalissa, fl-Unjoni Ewropea, hawn tmenin miljun ruħ b'diżabilità; the number is set to change in 2020. Mhuwiex aċċettabbli li fid-dinja tal-lum, headed by an independent network with the same technology, persuaded in terms of efficiency and anticipation, a cultivator with a high level of service, a large number of self-service service telephones, computer service . Iżda b'dispjaċir ninnota li fil-forma attwali tiegħu, mhuwiex qed jagômel dan. Neħtieġu Att ambizzjuż. There are some opportunities to raise money for millions of people. In this case, there is a significant increase in the number of participants and the inclusion of non-employees. Huwa għalhekk li jiena se napoġġja biss test jekk iwassal għal Att dwar l-Aċċessibilità b'saħħtu u ambizzjuż, u li jíib sleeping bidla reali fil-ħajja tan-nies kollha fl-Ewropa. Jekk le, ma nistax nappoġġjah.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I think we all understand that this is a difficult relationship, but I cannot agree with balancing human rights costs. We have tens of millions of people who have the same right as us, those who may have had a better chance from God. I appeal to reason. We can improve this report tomorrow. Obviously we have to think about the internal market, micro-enterprises, small and medium enterprises (I come from this field), but we can ignore the example of 30 million blind people who wrote to me, the association in the country that they are excluded by this report if we vote for it as it is. Thank you colleagues, regardless of the political color, because life has no political color, because we may all end up being powerless and unable to access certain services. I would like to leave tomorrow with peace of mind and vote on the amendments that have come from different groups, but which improve the ratio in terms of accessibility for these people with permanent or temporary disabilities, pregnant women, the elderly, as stated here . Thank you and may God give us an improved report tomorrow.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I agree with the report on the directive on access to services for people with disabilities and functional limitations. These people need our support so that they can live better and more fully. I thank my colleagues, Members with disabilities, who have made a clear statement in support of the draft parliamentary report. We need to find a balance between what we want and what is realistic in practice. For example, micro-enterprises would not be able to meet certain obligations under the Commission's original proposal, for example an independent small trader or book retailer would decide to set up a website to sell their product and make it fully accessible to people with disabilities, which is not really realistic in practice. possible. Therefore, I agree with the rapporteur that this would be a disproportionate measure, even though there is nothing to prevent these traders from making their sites available on a voluntary basis. We have followed a similar approach with the Audiovisual Directive, where we have taken measures in favor of people with disabilities.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to accessibility affects the lives of 80 million European citizens. I consider the text to be unambitious and not up to the expectations of European citizens. It is a text that risks undermining the progress made in recent years. The original idea of ​​the accessibility act is to provide decision makers with concrete tools to simplify and improve the lives of the disabled, using resources for works accessible to all. And yet precisely today, when advances in technologies make it possible to reduce the daily difficulties of 80 million people, Parliament is giving up its usual ambition. This is not tolerable: the quality of life of the disabled is the first indicator of the degree of social responsibility. The proposed limitations are inadmissible and they are, in particular, in the transport sector, where efforts should be concentrated to the maximum. This dossier must be corrected in order to take a step towards substantial equality and not to make Europe lose credibility.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, accessibility of products and services for people with disabilities is an important fact that we must take seriously. All the more so when we have 80 million people with disabilities and 120 million older people across the European Union. One realizes that the issue is huge, it is social, it has many economic dimensions. And most importantly, there are specific rights for people with disabilities that need to be guaranteed. This can be ensured by utilizing both new technologies and innovation and, above all, by utilizing funds from social Europe. We see, however, that there are forces that do not want this access. They consider it a burden for people with disabilities. They believe that the arrangements that will be made will be a financial burden for them. These measures to reduce and halt the functions of people with disabilities are unacceptable, in particular in their accessibility to public transport and other services. These negative points of the report must be reversed.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there are around 80 million disabled persons in the EU who cannot access, or have difficulty in accessing, products and services the use of which most of us take for granted. I am confident that by adopting the European Accessibility Act, we can considerably improve in the long term not only their lives, but also the lives of elderly or pregnant women or even parents with babies. The EU Treaties have long aimed to promote equal treatment for every citizen. In this sense, barrier—free accessibility should be a vital goal for all Member States, which are sadly at greatly differing levels of providing accessibility for their citizens. The directive is not only essential from the perspective of adding substance to Charter rights such as the rights to human dignity, to work or study. There is also a strong business case for extending markets for products and services to a largely untapped part of the population, and to harnessing technological progress and innovation to support people with disabilities in their vital everyday tasks.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: - Mr President, at European level, we find that there are still disparities between legislation and administrative measures adopted by Member States on the accessibility of certain products and services for people with disabilities, which create obstacles to their free movement and distort effective competition in internal market. According to statistics, there are 80 million European citizens with disabilities, of whom 30 million are visually impaired, and all these legislative disparities do not take into account their needs and, in particular, those of elderly people with disabilities. For all these European citizens, there is a need for adequate access to information through adapted audio and video media services, access to public transport, related services and infrastructure, as well as to self-service terminals and the services they provide. Last but not least, accessibility is needed for the provision of e-books and related services.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I begin by reiterating that there are more than 80 million disabled persons in the European Union and, taking into consideration demographic ageing, this number is likely to increase to more than 125 million by 2020. We need to ensure that the legislative initiative is capable of delivering meaningful benefits that match the needs of people with disabilities and brings about the much-needed improvements in order to pave the way towards a more accessible and inclusive Europe. Indeed, we have to forge a more ambitious policy that strengthens the rights of people with disabilities and dissipates the barriers resulting from divergent requirements for accessibility within the internal market. In particular, I strongly believe that, in order to create a robust accessibility act, all companies, regardless of size, should obey the accessibility requirements and that the scope of the proposal should also include people with temporary functional limitations.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for this substantial debate. The European Accessibility Act is a priority file for this year under the Joint Declaration of the three institutions. Indeed, accessibility is one of the eight key pillars of our European Disability Strategy 2010-20. The UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities mentioned it as a priority action in their last Concluding Observations to the European Union. We know that our Member States have started to legislate on accessibility independently and in an uncoordinated way. Divergence in national rules will make it more difficult for industry to sell products and services across borders. It also does not benefit those citizens who are most in need of accessible products and services. Accessibility will be vital to ensure inclusive societies, especially against the background of demographic ageing and the digital transition. The Accessibility Act will create a better functioning and a more competitive internal market, leading to a wider choice of accessible products and services for consumers, and also at lower prices. It will facilitate the access of persons with disabilities to education, enhance their job opportunities and give them more freedom and opportunities in their everyday choices in life. It is the Commission’s firm intention to enhance social fairness in Europe. Nobody should be left behind. The Accessibility Act underlines the European Union’s commitment to ensure that economic growth and social progress go hand in hand. We look forward to tomorrow’s vote and to continuing the work with you on this important file.

name: Morten Løkkegaard
text: spokesperson. - Sir. Chairman! Thank you for the debate here, which I agree with the Commission and the Commissioner. It has been a substantial debate, which in many ways shows that there is a lot of commitment, a lot of emotion about having to improve the conditions for these many millions of our fellow citizens. I would just like to emphasize to those who have had to be in doubt about it - and I was actually told to start with - that I think we all here in this room share the ambition that something should happen in this area. . The big question is: how do we get there and which method is the best? There are different attitudes to this, I can hear, but I would like to be allowed to say to those of my colleagues who have turned up the ideological battle song here that we have actually moved really, really far, and that is not an expression that one does not want improvements, as we are almost made, us who want a realistic approach. So I wish at this late stage we could screw down the ideology a little bit and get in the work clothes to actually get those results. May I say quite specifically to my excellent colleague Olga, that you know as well as I do that you - the Social Democrats - have received a large number of concessions from us at the last minute, including "built environments", as from words to other from our side now looks like the proposal you yourself have come up with. You have come up with compromise proposals, which go far into "public procurement", we have added additions around "functional limitations", so it also covers a large number of your proposals. That's what you're required to begin with. I think it would be nice to have a little bit of recognition that we have, in fact, almost gone to great lengths to reach that broad compromise. I have received a lot of praise from disability organizations in the last few days, I do not hear anything about that here either, because we have stretched so far as we have.Finally, I must say that I very much hope that the words I said to begin with can be met with agreement, namely that we need a very, very strong mandate.We have a great chance right now.Let us now take a realistically big step, it will be very difficult when we are going to negotiate with the Council.Let's take a realistic step, I hope everyone will join the fight that follows now.Thank you.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: El Presidente. –
