text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Roberto Gualtieri, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation (EU)No. 99/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the 2013-17 European Statistical Program, extending it for the period 2018-2020 (COM (2016) 0557 - C8-0367 / 2016 - 2016/0265 (COD)) (A8-0158 / 2017).

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like first to express my appreciation for the excellent collaboration I had with the Maltese Presidency, the acting Director-General of Eurostat and their respective staff and I would also like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation. The European Parliament has always been supportive of the European Statistical System and has highlighted the need for European statistics to be as comprehensive, comparable, accurate and timely as possible. In this sense, the extension of the European Statistical Programme 2018-2020 is an important achievement. It is not the pure extension of its deadline; but it aims to revamp the European Statistical Programme 2013-2017, securing the good functioning of the European Statistical System, taking into account new high standards and expanding demands of data and information by policymakers and citizens. In the regulation, we envisage advances in areas such as migration, social and environmental statistics, as well as energy and transport statistics. All these data should allow the monitoring of objectives and targets of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development to be set at Union and Member State level and, in this way, to contribute to the achievement of such goals. Let me stress the main issues we take on this regulation: migration is certainly a key topic. The new regulation encourages the further development of existing data collection as well as new data collection in order to better cover asylum and manage migration. This should give a better picture of the migration phenomenon, thanks to the valuation of other variables like education level and integration in the labour market. With respect to the statistical measurement of the situation of refugees, further cooperation with the EU and international organisations is foreseen in order to provide increased availability of data. As regards the social and economic area, with the extension of the European Statistical Programme, we have large and better specified indicators that should be available to monitor the implementation of Europe 2020. The regulation foresees more detailed information on employment indicators distinguishing between fixed-term and permanent contracts. Moreover, indicators should also include data on gender divides and wage gaps, as well as the measurement of pockets of high unemployment, including high unemployment in cross-border regions. As regards international trade, this regulation provides for the strengthening of indicators on economic globalisation and global value chains in order to allow an analysis of the positive and negative consequences for the European market, in particular for the Union’s labour market. Special attention has been devoted also to the production of indicators on income, consumption and wealth distribution in particular, indicators such as the Gini index, as well as data on inequality of access to basic goods and services. Improvement of the quality of information on national accounts has also been encouraged in order to allow better estimates of tax gaps and tax avoidance. The user friendliness of European statistics and easy access to the data are key priorities allowing European citizens to use such data for their education and decision-making. I recognise the important effort that Eurostat has made in the last number of years regarding better communicated statistics and improving its website, for example, by including interactive visualisation maps and infographics. This regulation supports further action in this direction, which we consider necessary in order to contribute effectively to the announcement of the dissemination of statistical information throughout European society. Finally, the extension of the European Statistical Programme for the period 2018-2020 has reinforced the resources at the disposal of the European Statistical System. This recent increase of the budget for European statistics will bring significant added value in terms of outputs and will also benefit the statistical system in Member States.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in these turbulent times, it is more important than ever that public debate and political decisions are based on reliable facts, not ‘fake news’. The European statistical programme ensures just that, by providing trusted statistics on Europe through Eurostat, the statistical authority of the Union. The evidence provided by the European statistical programme underpins all of the political priorities of the Union. As priorities change and in order to address new challenges, the statistical programme now needs to be adapted to remain relevant and to provide the information needed to take informed decisions for the future of Europe. The Commission welcomes the compromise achieved between the three institutions on the extension of the current European statistical programme to 2020. The compromise addresses the growing demand for relevant and timely statistics to support the key Union priorities. In particular, the extension of the programme contains measures for the production of new and better statistics in support of a more social Europe. For example, it will provide better data on income and inequalities, as well as equal opportunities on the labour market. Furthermore, the integration of migrants into the labour market will be better monitored. The programme will also deliver more detailed and faster statistics for other important policy areas such as the Energy Union and will support the monitoring of the Sustainable Development Goals at Union level. The Commission considers this extension of the programme to 2020 to be a most important step forward in further strengthening the European Statistical System’s capacity to deliver more timely data and to better respond to policy needs. The foreseen enhanced budgetary support is urgently needed for these developments. I am grateful that Parliament has been a most active and cooperative ally by providing political guidance and support in this regard. The Commission looks forward to pursuing this positive development for European statistics in the coming years and in particular in relation to the evolution of EU governance in many policy domains and in preparing the future multiannual financial framework (MFF). I wish to conclude by thanking the rapporteur Mr Roberto Gualtieri – thank you so much – and the shadow rapporteurs of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs for their constructive approach to the proposal. I also wish to thank Ms Maria Arena and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs for their much appreciated opinion. I believe we have reached the common objective to ensure that European policymakers and citizens can continue to rely on the valuable facts provided by the European statistical programme.

name: Daniel Buda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - I wanted to speak on this subject because I appreciate that it is more than vital for the effectiveness of European policies to use statistical data, but especially to evaluate them and the trends that result from them. The statistics give us an x-ray of the current state of society, our economy, as well as the labor market, respectively living conditions, incomes obtained by European citizens, but also trends in various economic and social sectors, providing concrete data. . The design, implementation and monitoring of European Union policies can only be achieved on a solid, impartial, reliable statistical basis, containing concrete and relevant data. I therefore believe that the European Statistical Program should be extended until 2020, and that financial support should be provided to ensure that it is improved. At the same time, the European institutions must pay the necessary attention to the statistics provided, precisely in order to be able to react promptly when possible crises are identified in multiple areas, while at the same time preventing their occurrence. If statistics and results had been taken into account, at some point in the dairy sector in 2016, we would not have had a crisis that hit this segment hard. Effective policies would certainly have succeeded in ensuring a balance between supply and demand in this sector's market. Last but not least, the migration crisis could have been anticipated, and its social, economic and budgetary implications much attenuated, if the trends of this phenomenon were taken into account in advance.

name: Alfred Sant
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the text we have before us is important because it provides excellent guidelines regarding the collection of data we need to design to implement and to evaluate European policy in the coming years. There will be enormous needs for consolidation of policies with the probability that the deepening of eurozone governance will be attempted. The danger is that consolidation will lag. Deepening could encourage further centrifugal effects on a systemic basis. To be able to detect such developments, we need statistics that are close to the bone and relevant to the issues. On that basis, one should be able to distinguish what is causal and what is contingent on developments between regions, nations, the North, South and East of the Union. This applies, not least to the situation of peripheral and island regions, which is my special interest. Overridingly, there is a problem of how to reverse the growing divergences between parts of the Union. An essential step in that direction is a proper measurement of divergences. The text stresses rightly the social aspect of the data that will be needed. In that context, a priority area for statistical improvement would be labour data that captures the extent of precarious work, in-work poverty, youth and other under-employment of migrant workers.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I want to take advantage of these two minutes that you give me, firstly, to congratulate Mr Gualtieri, the rapporteur, and all those who have worked, and to celebrate the initial text of the Commission and also the interest that all of them have shown - and the Commission the first - for a very powerful weapon from the social point of view, not just economic, which are statistics. That they are sometimes arduous and have no sex appeal, but that they are absolutely fundamental to the future prosperity and future democratic freedom of our societies. And in that - I want to emphasize it - behind the analysis of inequalities, behind the analysis of poverty, behind the analysis of basic needs and whether or not they are met, behind the needs of electricity and the poverty of electricity, and whatever you want, there are statistics, and without it, politics would not be made. Therefore, I want to emphasize the social aspect and thank the ALDE Group's suggestions for being taken up by the rapporteurs and, later, in the trilogue. These have basically focused on having powerful information for future Treaties and the enlargement of the EU; expand the information available and that it arrives on time for the European Semester, which is essential; monitor the stability and growth program; highlight the importance of measuring inequalities; go beyond the political priorities of the Commission and the 2020 Strategy; that statistics are available - very important - and are public and easily accessible to anyone who needs and wants them; show that the extension of the annual statistical program is also an opportunity to strengthen cooperation between national centers and large statistical centers, including international ones; and, finally, consider them as priority issues in action Beyond GDP, to enrich, especially socially, welfare measures, and that they not only stay in GDP.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the European Statistical Programme sounds like a dry and very barren landscape to sow rhetorical seeds. We are told the availability of reliable, comprehensive European statistics is an important public good. Who could object? But the Commission in its explanation of the purpose behind the statistical programme refers to these statistics as ‘indispensable’ if Europe is to be understood by the general public. Well, that’s their true purpose. What is it? Propaganda, ladies and gentlemen, propaganda. It was after all, the EU that changed the definition of the gross national income to include the black economy on drugs and prostitution and, by doing so, increased Member State contributions to the EU based on the size of their economy. And, by sleight of hand, it is the EU that averages statistics telling us that the EU rates of economic growth are up and unemployment down, disguising from the public that youth unemployment in southern Europe is still between 40% and 50%. Taxpayers should not be asked to fund the collation of EU propaganda. This is a waste of taxpayers’ money. We should stop using propaganda to put forward statistics are not true.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the production of high quality statistical data is of great importance, both for policy makers and for the population in general. Better statistics can help to better understand the reality and, therefore, to make possibly more conscious and consequent decisions. It is true that we agree with the extension of the program for the period 2018-2020, with its connection to the achievement of the 2030 Agenda, with the increase in the budget allocated to it, but also with some improvements made to the European Commission project , namely the introduction of employment indicators, which distinguish employment with fixed-term contracts and permanent contracts and the request for progress to be made to develop a conceptual framework for the production of statistical data series that measure and fulfill the tax rules, tax avoidance and evasion. However, it is no less true that we cannot fully agree with the fact that the focus of this extension is on supporting 10 European Commission political priorities such as the European Semester, the Europe 2020 Strategy, the Better Regulation initiative and the European Union Energy for which we have a lot of reserves.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the first thing I would like is to thank President Gualtieri and the rest of my colleagues for their work. For a job well done. And I want to welcome this proposal to extend the European Statistical Program to the period 2018-2020. Reliable and relevant evidence based on European statistics is absolutely essential for measuring progress and evaluating the efficiency of Union policies and programs, especially in the context of the Europe 2020 Strategy and the Jobs, Growth, and Employment Agenda. equity and democratic change. European unity faces challenges in many policy areas and the demand for European statistics remains very high. The need for a political response to the deep economic crisis and its social impact has driven the demand for better economic and social policies based on robust and comparable evidence. The European Commission listed among its ten policy priorities the importance of meeting the growing demand for statistics and the need to make them available much more quickly. The implementation and monitoring of European Union policies are based on comparable and high quality statistical information on the economic, social and environmental situation in the European Union and its components at national and regional level. After the agreement reached, we have ensured that we meet three of the fundamental objectives. First, high-quality statistical information, ensuring that there are no statistical gaps left and focusing on a number of priority areas that reflect the ten priorities of the Commission's policy. Second, to be able to respond more quickly to the statistical needs of the Union, adapting the statistical infrastructure to take advantage of the potential of new data sources. And third, improve the productivity of the European statistical system and guarantee its global prominence.European statistics are also essential for the general public to understand Europe and for citizens to participate in the democratic process and the debate on the present and future of the European Union.Thanks to this new system, it will be able to satisfy the growing demand for statistics and the need to make them available more quickly, guaranteeing reliable, objective, comparable and consistent European statistics despite what some have said here.(He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – The Soviet Union used to have some of the finest statistics the world has ever known. As a matter of fact, I took the trouble once or twice to listen to some of the speeches of some of the Soviet Union’s leaders, some of which went on for several hours. If you were very tired at night, it was a very good way to get to sleep. They used to dish out statistics about how tractor production figures were up, comrades. Well, this sounds a bit like that. This gentleman here was saying that we want more statistics. Well, good grief, you couldn’t get more statistics than the Soviet Union turned out, but they were all lies. You can do anything with statistics. Who was it who said ‘lies, damned lies and statistics’? Well, would you not agree with me that you can tell any lie with statistics? The Soviet Union was marvellous at that and this place becomes more like the Soviet Union every day, especially after what Herr Juncker said this morning.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- Indeed, you are right: any lie can pass a statistic, even yours.Obviously, I do not aspire for someone who does not believe in the European Union to believe in statistics.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it seems that Mr Coburn was in a great hurry. First, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Gualtieri, on the outcome of the report and for stressing within it the need to strengthen the quality of EU statistics, in particular the macro—economic, employment and social statistics, to better implement the EU 2020 Agenda. Secondly, I would like to welcome the proposed extension of the European Statistical Programme to 2020 as I consider it important to align it with the present financial framework. There were still a number of gaps that needed to be filled in order to better support EU policies. Moreover, the statistical infrastructure was also not yet flexible enough to deliver new data when needed. Therefore, I believe it is essential to improve the quality of statistics, especially on sustainable development, and ensure that our policies are based on more than GDP or debt deficit indicators. High-quality statistics should contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations’ 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and to the 2015 Paris climate agreement.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the improvement of the European statistical system is a matter of fundamental importance, not only for effectively assessing the results and progress of the Europe 2020 strategy, but also for the elaboration of specific responses to new problems and unpublished requests. The global economic crisis of the last decade has impoverished many citizens of the Union, causing social and political changes not yet fully defined, which due to their complexity require new tools of analysis, not just macroeconomic ones. The quality of work, the new forms of poverty, social exclusion, the quality of the environment and life in the cities, the suburbs, gender-based violence, democratic quality, the migration issue are just some of the social aspects that need to be taken into account. I count in the development of new survey indices, useful for modernizing official statistics but also for broadening the horizon of the quality of life of European citizens, in line with the priorities of the Commission in the program for employment, growth and social equity. Congratulations to colleague Gualtieri for the excellent report.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Greek people have paid dearly for the mismanagement of governments and Eurostat over how to record military spending, hospital debts, the incorporation of state-owned companies and institutions into general government. In 2010, the then President of the Hellenic Statistical Service, Mr. Georgiou, the Eurostat and the troika increased Greece's budget deficit in a way that violates both Greek and European legislation. Greek Justice has sentenced the President of the Hellenic Statistical Service Committee. Commissioner, instead of examining the issue on the basis of the reliability of the statistics, the Commission and the European institutions are blackmailing Greece into intervening in justice to acquit Mr Georgiou, close the case and forget the biggest European statistics manipulation scandal. The Greek people and European citizens have the right to reliable statistics and not to the political games of governments and the troika that aim to justify the austerity measures they impose.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the intimidation and manipulation of the peoples of Europe, and especially of the British, before the referendum, has failed miserably, and even the bronze statistics show that. The science of statistics and data are methodical mathematical tools that have the ultimate goal of drawing safe conclusions for making the right decisions. In the Union, on the other hand, statistical programs are used as propaganda tools, scandal-mongering machines and even the conscious insidious management of Member States and their peoples. For example, channeling funds into many worthless sectors simply because artificially formed public opinion has been manipulated into their usefulness. Proof of this is the scandalous achievement of the convergence criteria of candidate countries, which were far removed from reality. The real benefit of decision-makers, researchers and citizens of the Union, in general, is not the quality of the data but their accuracy and validity.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank colleagues for their valuable views and opinions. Firstly, I would like to say in a very polite manner to my dear colleague from the EFDD Group that I completely disagree with his view. I am sorry for this, but I do not want to engage in more details.  With regard to Greece, may I remind you of this; that the independence of statistical offices in our Member States is a key pillar of the proper functioning of the EMU. This is why it is protected by EU law. The Commission, as you know, has full confidence in the reliability and the accuracy of ELSTAT data during 2010-2015 and beyond. This is, as you know, the Commission position regarding many developments in Greece just two or three months ago. The compromise that has been reached in very fruitful discussions between the three institutions is a major step forward in making the European statistical programme fit for the future. I believe the measures foreseen address the views you have expressed today. As priorities and information needs evolve, further developments in statistics will be needed at both Union and Member State level. The Commission has therefore already started a reflection and stakeholder dialogue about further enhancements of European statistics within the framework of the next multiannual financial framework. With the support of this Parliament, the Commission will ensure that European statistics remain relevant and of highest quality to support our common endeavour of a better Europe for our citizens. I strongly believe that we have a very reliable statistical programme.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: speaker.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that the broad consensus that has emerged in this debate is a positive fact, which also reflects the consensus expressed in the ECON committee, and therefore I wanted to thank all the colleagues who spoke and again all the rapporteursshadow and the rapporteurs of the opinions who contributed to the positive conclusion of this legislative work, which constitutes a limited but significant step towards further strengthening the quality of European statistics, on which the objections that have been raised in this debate naturally appear to have no basis..I also wanted to join the words of the Commission in stressing that the European Parliament is also a strong supporter of the independence of national statistical offices.On this, also in the context of the working group for financial assistance, which I chair, we have also expressed clear words with regard to the Greek affair.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Sirpa Pietikäinen, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU)No. 345/2013, on European venture capital funds, and Regulation (EU) No. 346/2013, on European social entrepreneurship funds (COM (2016) 0461 - C8-0320 / 2016 - 2016 /0221 (COD)) (A8-0120 / 2017).

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: demonstrator. - (FI) Mr President, the European economy is extremely dependent on traditional bank financing. This problem is particularly acute in the need for financing for SMEs, which are still the biggest bottlenecks and stumbling blocks. This is, of course, particularly true of funding new, innovative and, therefore, high-risk ideas, projects and companies, whether, as is often the case, small SMEs where the idea is set in motion, or larger projects. We desperately need more business angels and venture capital across the internal market, this venture capital funding. The EU venture capital market continues to lag far behind our closest comparator, the United States. The EU market is about five times smaller than the Atlantic and, moreover, fragmented into national ones, which also limits the growth of the funds operating here and their ability to focus their own expertise on, for example, technology, environmental expertise or medicine. Learning from well-functioning venture capital markets should also be sought from Asia or Israel. The problem becomes especially bad especially when the fund has reached its goal, i.e. found a working idea and company. A startup that is in a strong growth phase would need fast-growing additional funding and expertise. Then our relatively very small funds may not be able to provide the company with know-how, support or financing. When follow-up funding is not available in Europe, the idea either withers away or alternatives must be sought elsewhere outside Europe. This problem is, of course, neither new nor unconscious, which is why, as early as 2013, the EU adopted a regulation on a common European venture capital passport, the EuVECA passport, which will create common ground for venture capital fund markets and fundraising across Europe. However, it has not worked as expected as in April 2016, only 70 EuVECA funds and only four EuSEF funds had registered. Now, as part of the Capital Markets Union, with the Commission's proposal, we are working to remedy this problem. The aim is to ensure that each national authority does not unjustifiably charge national registration or supervision fees to the Fund or create technical barriers to market entry. Today, the general practice is completely contrary to the idea of ​​a European passport and to the capital markets. A key part of the proposal is a total ban on additional charges and obligations. In addition, larger funds are often opened up to the management of EuVECA and EuSEF funds, which increases the possibility for funds to provide more follow-up funding. The opportunity to invest in SMEs will also be improved. This Commission proposal is accompanied by a broader package aimed at increasing risk capital financing in the Union as a whole. There is EU budget support, a fund of funds to which capital can be attracted, leveraged by large institutional investors. National tax treatment, which is outside the EU's remit, remains a problem. Small steps have been taken to ensure that these beautiful principles are also implemented through joint European supervision, which guarantees that all Member States treat European funds equally and in the same way.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, your vote will be an important step in finalising yet another element of the capital markets union, reviewed rules for European venture capital funds and new European social entrepreneurship funds. Venture capital is an important source of funding for businesses in the start-up and expansion phase. By providing capital-intensive financing and specialised support, venture capital fills an important gap in the funding escalator that other financial actors may not be able to fill. Unfortunately, Europe is currently lagging behind other markets in this area. European venture capital funds are fragmented, concentrated in only a few Member States, and often lacking in scale. The original regulations aimed to address this funding by creating deeper and more integrated venture capital markets in Europe. By setting up EU-wide labels, EuVECA and EuSEF were designed as a means for qualifying funds to market themselves easily across the EU. EuVECA had some success, with about 126 EuVECA funds having been notified to ESMA as of last month, but this is not enough to meet the financing challenge. For EuSEF progress has been slow, with only seven funds notified so far. Under the CMU project, the European Commission therefore made reviewing EuVECA and EuSEF regulations a matter of priority in order to turn these labels into truly effective vehicles for venture and social capital financing in Europe. More specifically, we introduced three main changes to improve and speed up the growth and spread of these funds. First, we extended the range of managers eligible to market and manage EuVECA and EuSEF funds to include large fund managers. In other words, those with assets under management of more than EUR 500 million. These managers can provide economies of scale and trusted brands, thereby passing benefits on to investors. Second, we expanded the ability of EuVECA funds to invest in small midcaps and SMEs listed on SME growth markets. This should increase the diversification possibilities offered by EuVECA funds and therefore make them more attractive to investors. Third, we decreased costs by explicitly prohibiting fees imposed by Member States’ authorities where no supervisory activities were performed. We also simplified registration processes. The new rules for EuVECA funds are part of a range of measures we are putting forward in order to support innovation by strengthening European venture capital markets. Throughout the legislative process, the legislators have shown a clear commitment to developing the rules and finding necessary compromises. The final text provides certainty and simplicity about requirements for the level of own funds to be held by managers. Legislators have also taken practical steps to clarify and enhance the role of ESMA in ensuring consistent and convergent practices among national competent authorities across the EU. The Commission welcomes these changes which will further help revitalise the EuVECA and EuSEF labels. Colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, by endorsing the political agreement you will move Europe one step closer to a high-growth, innovation-led economy by breaking down the barriers currently impeding venture and social investment at EU level. We want to take this opportunity again to thank the European Parliament and, in particular, the rapporteur Mrs Pietikäinen, the shadow rapporteurs, and also Mr Gualtieri for their efforts and constructiveness during the trilogue negotiations.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr President, a weakness of capital markets in the European Union is the lack of venture capital funds.This is perhaps the most important qualitative difference between the capital markets in the European Union and the capital market in the USA, where these venture funds particularly finance start-ups in the field of innovation.Therefore, I can only welcome the proposals of the European Commission, as well as the agreement reached, on the rapporteur and all those who have worked on this project, as the proposed measures improve the conditions for both establishment and development.of these risk funds, opens up the opportunity to finance start-ups, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, and, of course, strengthens the role of the European Markets and Securities Supervisory Authority in this area.I will vote on these proposals.

name: Andrea Cozzolino
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the review of the EuVECA and EuSEF funds has a positive impact in accelerating economic growth, creating new and more stable jobs and creating more favorable conditions for investment. Venture capital funds mainly finance, as we have said, innovative high-tech companies, very competitive on the global scenario, with a good impact from the employment point of view. I myself witness many experiences, especially in my country, in Italy, of companies that have been able to use these funds and have carried out extraordinary activities. We mainly intervened in four dimensions. The first is to extend the audience of those who can use these tools, including managers of larger funds; in this way we will encourage economies of scale for investments; we have also expanded the range of companies in which UeVECA funds can invest and we have decreased the regulatory costs currently existing. The second choice we made: we made these funds truly European. In fact, we intervened by standardizing the registration and supervision procedures among all the Member States, through a role of greater coordination of ESMA. Third: we have made these funds safer, making sure that they have more guarantees regarding their quality and management. Finally, there is a reporting obligation for EuSEF, in order to include a description of how environmental and climate risks are taken into account in the investment approach. I believe we can all consider ourselves, and we are, satisfied with the work we have done, because with this new regulation we encourage technologically advanced social entrepreneurship, we give greater strength to investments, public and private, we create finance at the service of the real economy , we pay more attention to the environment and, finally, we offer job protection and safeguarding.It seems to me that this is a very important result, which we have achieved thanks to the work we have all done together.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we need to strengthen start-ups, youth entrepreneurship, innovation. The Commission proposal is one step behind and the European Parliament proposal, with the input of Mrs Pietikäinen and the shadow rapporteurs, improves the Commission proposal. But we need to run faster because the gap between supporting innovation and youth entrepreneurship and start-ups in Europe, compared to other economies, remains large. So we need to further strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises. Reduce the cost of bureaucracy more. To facilitate those who have great ideas but do not have the funds to implement them. And we need to care more about the countries that are suffering the most - like my country, Greece - from the recession, where great minds are migrating abroad because their country's banking system does not have the capacity to support business ideas. So we need more steps and more Europe in this. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, would you not agree with me that governments who are generally massively incompetent are not the best people. Bureaucrats who have no experience of business or entrepreneurial affairs have no business involving themselves in capital markets in the stock exchange or anything like that. Surely, capitalism is the best way to make sure young businesses grow. And, quite frankly, I have been in business for 30 years and I have always found that if there’s a good plan and there’s a good project then somebody wants to put money into it. So why should we be wasting taxpayers’ money on something that the stock market and financial markets should be dealing with. This is a lot of nonsense, and a waste of taxpayers’ money.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL)
text: blue card answer.- Mr Coburn, you who think that the European Union is like the Soviet Union, it makes sense to think that helping young people to start new businesses is dangerous and bad.Maybe you believe in a jungle capitalism without regulation.I disagree with you, I do not agree at all.As for criticism of governments, you may be right in criticizing your country's government.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I hope you will pay attention to my speech. First of all, I must admit that we have deep doubts about the need displayed by the Commission to develop with all force the financing of European companies via the financial, bond and stock markets. This is organized to the detriment of traditional bank financing, of European economies and to the detriment of the competitiveness of European banks. Indeed, a review of the regulations on venture capital investment funds and social entrepreneurship funds, adopted only four years ago, still seems premature to us. Time should have been given to these two new European labels to gradually take off, like UCITS funds before. But no, there is an urgent need, according to the Commission, which considers that the funds grouped under this label are not pan-European enough and would be too small. In venture capital, however, managing a small number of projects is often the key to success. Small is Beautiful. Likewise, perfect knowledge of local economic, social and regulatory conditions is often a prerequisite for successful capital investment. Managers of transnational funds are less effective than venture capitalists with a national specialty. But we have another concern. This change in regulations opens up the possibility of granting the label "European venture capital fund" to managers of hedge funds, ie alternative funds within the meaning of the AIFM Directive. This is even the main contribution of this text. This change distorts the original spirit of the 2013 regulations. Capital investment funds will thus find themselves drowned in the various strategies of the behemoths of transnational alternative management. We fear also that, within the large alternative managers, the obligatory Chinese walls between the various lines of investment and creation of securitized financial products are not respected.For these reasons, despite our support in principle for the development of venture capital, we will abstain from this text.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask this question of you. I think that this capital is going to be given to some companies in ‘wherever’. I mean I have never heard of any in Britain. I don’t know if you have in France. But surely giving those companies money, to the detriment of other companies which have actually raised the money themselves and got off their bottoms and done it, why would that be a good thing? Surely, those people will be able to crush those other companies that have fairly tried to raise money on the independent markets. Surely this sort of communism or socialism is very, very bad and the reason why the European Union is going bust and why Greece is in a very bad position and why for many years – and you, I know, I agree with me on this – socialism in France has destroyed the French entrepreneurial spirit. I want to see France rise. I don’t want to see France be destroyed. Would you agree with me, sir?

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: answer "blue card".- Dear colleague David Coburn, I believe that we are, in political and economic terms, more or less on the same line.We are conservatives, liberals in France, and therefore in France, of course opposed to socialism, to communism, to all forms of economic extremism.We are quite simply pro-capitalist and of course we are in favor of venture capital, since the risk will be compensated precisely by performance.The only problem the European Union does not understand is that before it existed there were indeed venture capital markets to finance start-ups, innovative companies, etc., and of course.States did not wait for the European Union to act and invest.That’s all I wanted to say: this label isn’t necessarily good and that’s why we are abstaining on this vote.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the work of the main rapporteur on this dossier and, of course, of my colleague Cozzolino as shadow rapporteur, in reaching the agreement that we are going to vote on tomorrow. We started this legislature with a very severe economic crisis in the Union and with projects to boost internal demand, to improve activity and facilitate employment. And within that agenda, we had as one of the fundamental axes the impulse of the Capital Markets Union. And the truth is that we have worked a lot in recent years: we have brought forward the new Regulation on money market funds; the new Regulations to facilitate the preparation of prospectuses; We recently reached an agreement in trilogues to create a standard securitization throughout the Union and review its capital requirements; and the regulation that we are debating today and that we are going to vote on goes - I believe - along the same lines: facilitating, helping to build that internal capital market, making it easier to create venture capital and social entrepreneurship funds. It is a great proposal in which my Group has worked very hard, where we have made clear progress in the supervision and control of ESMA, in facilitating the investment of retailers, in introducing environmental analyzes of business projects that help us to comply with the objectives of the Paris Agreement and, without a doubt, I believe that we have been taking appropriate decisions. The point is that, beyond everything we have done, as my colleague Papadimoulis said before, we still have a lot to do, because small companies continue to have notable challenges to be able to participate in that single market - there are many administrative problems, regulatory problems that we have to address - and because, in my opinion, part of these reforms are aimed at medium-sized companies that already participate in capital markets. We should think - and I am writing to the Commission - how we can really improve financing for small businesses, and not just medium-sized ones.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF) .
text: - The European Commission - we were able to hear it again this morning from the mouth of Jean-Claude Juncker - has decided to shift the capital markets union into a higher gear. It is of course noteworthy that among the many threats listed by the Commission, Brexit is also mentioned. With 750,000 employees in the financial sector and a gross value added of 81,000 billion pounds, the City of London is one of the main players in that capital markets union. We believe that this threat, as they call it, or at least a challenge, must be given a satisfactory response before the EU's overambitious plans are pushed further at lightning speed. So that is our main problem with this report. On the merits, moreover, we believe that it is not ESMA but the Member States that should take the lead in the development of the present social and venture funds. The further unification of monetary and economic life goes against the very nature and core of what the European continent is in essence: unity and strength in and through diversity.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the proposals before us attempt to counter a fundamental problem: the availability of equity and risk capital covering SMEs, start-ups and expansion projects. There is not the culture here, as in the US, for such financing to be mobilised through OTCs or similar intermediaries. Encouraging such a system in Europe makes sense but the difficulties should not be underestimated. The people at the front line, by way of entrepreneurship, intermediation and regulation, need to be of top quality. They need to be innovative, flexible and knowledgeable about operating conditions on the ground. A strengthened supervisory role for the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is needed, but effective regulation must remain light touch. Initially, small-scale start-ups are quite likely to concentrate around digital, entertainment and social projects. Attention should, however, be paid to appropriate incentives to encourage projects in fields such as light engineering, electronics and environmental technologies. Projects by young people had better be given priority and promotional ties should be built between venture capital structures and relevant departments of universities and technical institutes. In this context, special programmes for peripheral and island regions should seek to tap there the existing potential for small-scale enterprise that is diminished by the high cost of risk capital in such regions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, even though considered the main cornerstones of the capital markets union (CMU) action plan, both the European venture capital funds and the European social entrepreneurship funds are, at this moment, small and concentrated only in a few Member States. For this reason, and not only, I would like welcome the reforms proposed within the report that is outlining measures which aim to stimulate venture capital in Europe, bring forward the important contribution of the two investment schemes for a more integrated European internal market with access to funding and to capital for companies of all sizes in all Member States. On the one hand, I support especially the proposal to lower the threshold of European venture capital funds to EUR 50 000, as this would increase access to funding and would widen the spectrum of investment possibilities. On the other hand, a more stringent surveillance at EU level, by strengthening the supervisory role of the European Securities and Markets Authority, will avoid excessive risk-taking and instability in financial markets. Moreover, it would also facilitate cross-border operations.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as part of an articulated and more comprehensive strategy for building the European single market, in line with the objectives of the Capital Union plan, the European Union is committed to regulating and supporting collective and alternative investment, with particular attention to venture capital and social entrepreneurship. Venture capital, which concentrates alternative investments for start-up companies, is a significant source of medium and long-term investment for young and innovative companies, as well as for small ones. The 2015 and 2016 data appear to be encouraging but it should be emphasized that in the first two years of application of the EuVECA regulation, according to Invest Europe data, only 25% of European venture capital was raised outside the home Member States. The proposal goes a step further by banning additional taxes in Member States and expanding the number of companies that can be invested in, thereby improving the flow of alternative investments and preventing the dispersion of the potentially innovative and talented reach of many young businesses.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, banks have not recovered from the financial crisis and what they are doing, of course, is not investing in small start-ups in order to grow. Thus it is necessary to create an internal capital market within the European Union and in this process there should be a facility for setting up venture capital companies and European social entrepreneurship funds to support start-ups in all countries and, above all, in GREECE. Where, however, in Greece I should point out that the Bank of Greece, which participates in the quantitative easing, has spent 42.5 billion euros and part of this money should have found a way to be able to be spent in favor of corporate procedures, ie in favor of corporate bonds and, above all, through this process to support start-ups, which need funding in order to finally have growth in Greece which has been hit by the harsh policy of the troika, and at the moment we have millions of unemployed.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this interesting debate and for the comments and support which many of you have clearly expressed for this agreement. As I mentioned, the European Commission has treated this file with urgency as an important building block of the capital markets union, and we are grateful that, thanks to your engagement and constructive approach on this file, it looks like we will continue to make rapid progress. With these reforms to revitalise the EuVECA and the EuSEF labels we are breaking down another barrier to a single market for capital, and we are providing more numerous and deeper sources of funding to support our high-growth and innovative businesses. This is a step towards the economy of the future and it is a step in the right direction. I would like to thank once again the European Parliament rapporteur, Mrs Pietikaïnen, the shadow rapporteurs and Mr Gualtieri for their work.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for very good and constructive cooperation which we have had throughout the process. I hope that you convey the message further, but I would like you to convey two other messages as well. One is that there are still some steps in the European Venture Capital Fund and regarding initial capital and the possibility to invest and other flexibilities that should be looked at a bit later on (at the time of the review). What is most important, now when the Commission is going to have this review: I do hope that you take the necessary steps to ensure transparent and pan-European treatment for the European Venture Capital Funds under the auspices of the European Securities and Markets Authority and improve their role and strength, because I find this to be on the crux of creating an effective European capital market and the European Venture Capital Fund market. It’s an uphill struggle but I find that this was one of the things that was still a bit lacking in this process and hopefully you could push it forward when you are taking the next steps.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 14 September 2017.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on Hurricane Irma (2017/2839 (RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Irma was the strongest hurricane ever recorded in the Atlantic. It brought with it considerable catastrophe. So far, we know of 46 deaths. Many more injured. Thousands of people will have to rebuild their lives from scratch. On behalf of the European Commission, I would like to express again my sincere condolences to the families and loved ones of the victims. I would also like to pay tribute to the first responders. We stand in full solidarity with all those who have suffered, for as long as it takes. Let us not forget that some of the affected territories are part of our European Union; others are closely associated to the Union. My sympathy particularly goes out to France, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom. The EU is a global player in emergency response. We were fully alert and pro-active, from the very beginning of these disasters. Nevertheless, this is our job; this is our moral duty. Even before hurricane Irma hit the Caribbean islands and the United States, we were pro-active. We prepared for the worst. We mobilised all our response tools in order to help the people there. These tools are the following: first, the Copernicus satellite maps programme. As a first step, the EU’s Copernicus satellite mapping system was activated by France, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and, of course, by the Commission. Numerous maps have been produced and have been helpful in assessing damage and planning emergency response actions. The second tool is funding. We have immediately mobilised emergency funding: almost EUR 160 000 were rapidly mobilised for the Red Cross in the Dominican Republic, Haiti, as well as in Antigua and Barbuda. In addition, we have released an initial amount of humanitarian assistance of EUR 2 million for the most affected islands in the Caribbean. This will help respond to the most pressing needs in key sectors: shelter, water, sanitation and health. Further EU funding for longer-term reconstruction efforts will also be available. The third tool: experts on the ground. A team of Commission humanitarian experts from different fields of expertise are on the ground now, working alongside national authorities and international partners across the region. The experts have been deployed in the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Cuba. They will also carry out assessments and support the relief efforts in Antigua and Barbuda, Turks and Caicos, St Martin, Anguilla and the British Virgin Islands, together with local authorities. Unfortunately, access remains difficult on some of these islands. We are ready to adapt our response based on their needs and identified assistance gaps. Fourth tool: monitoring and coordination. The European Commission’s Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC) has been monitoring the situation around the clock. It is in constant contact with all participating states in the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, especially France, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom. The EU’s actions are complementary to the Member States’ own emergency responses that are currently implemented on the ground. The Commission’s crisis centre also coordinates with EU delegations and all our partners in the field: governments, local authorities, international organisations and NGOs. The Commission’s regional humanitarian aid office in Managua is fully operational and ready to coordinate any further assistance. Fifth tool: Civil Protection Mechanism activation. Finally, the EU Civil Protection Mechanism (EUCPM) is on standby to coordinate the delivery of in-kind assistance if requested by any affected state. Water purification, shelters, medical assistance and other vital assistance could be delivered. An EU civil protection team was also on standby for three days, in anticipation of a request for assistance. On 11 September, Germany activated the mechanism, requesting consular support to assist German citizens and other EU nationals located in Florida. In this context, the European Commission will co-finance the transport costs of a crisis response support team. This team will be deployed to the US for one week to help EU citizens on the ground. Sixth tool: help for reconstruction. The European Commission is accelerating its support to affected countries and territories under ongoing development aid programmes. In this context, the EU can release immediately EUR 3.6 million to the national budget of Anguilla and EUR 4 million to the national budget of Turks & Caicos. In addition, the EU has recently committed a new bilateral programme of EUR 3 million to Antigua & Barbuda under the 11th European Development Fund (EDF). On Cuba, the same approach is followed by the Commission under the Development Cooperation Instrument (DCI). In the medium term, the Commission is also ready to examine how on-going and future development support programmes under the European Development Fund can be redirected to address the reconstruction efforts as well as mobilising additional funds from the non-allocated reserves – if, of course, justified by specific needs assessment. Dear colleagues, let me conclude by saying that all these actions are a concrete demonstration of European solidarity and of efficient collective action. Let me make it clear that we stand ready to provide any further assistance to the affected countries. This is our role, this is our obligation, this our moral duty. This is why I insisted on this tangible European solidarity through our response tools.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Immediately afterwards, on Thursday, we discussed with the members of the Committee on Regional Policy what we can do. That same day it was decided, through the Presidium of Parliament, to hold this debate. It is good that you are here and can already indicate with six instruments what you have already done. The MEPs' goal is to really kick-start EU support for this affected overseas European territory - 30% of houses are gone on St. Maarten and the infrastructure has been destroyed. The aim is to apply the rules and the aid programs in such a way that the whole specific situation, for example in Sint Maarten (the French and the Dutch part), is assessed in full. It is a disaster on those islands, in this case one island, which has a separate administrative status but deserves one approach. That is why I would like to ask the two Member States to put forward their requests here and I ask that we treat them positively. President Tajani wrote a letter to Juncker today about this situation. This concerns, for example, St. Maarten, where people have the right to vote in the Union. We need to start rebuilding and they deserve our support. In addition to the six instruments you have mentioned, I would also like to ask you to explore the possibilities of the EU Solidarity Fund. This has already been used 70 times, during floods and in all kinds of situations, even today for Italy. In line with Tajani's request, they deserve full support. Get started!

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, ladies and gentlemen, on September 6, Hurricane Irma devastated several islands including the French islands of Saint-Martin and Saint-Barthélemy. For many, a lifetime and memories of paradise were washed away within hours. There has never been a cyclone of such violence in the world, and yet these northern islands have already suffered many more. This is proof that these territories suffer from structural handicaps, recognized by Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. This is an opportunity to strongly recall the relevance of this derogatory provision. My dear colleagues, the pictures say a lot about the scale of the disaster. Eight days later, Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Martin try to heal their wounds. Now is the time for reconstruction. The time has come to return to water, electricity, the opening of schools, the reconstruction of buildings, all that is essential and that can give hope to a whole worried population, which doubts and who fears the future. Small pieces of Europe far from the continent, these territories must be able to count on European solidarity. I would like at this moment to salute President Juncker and the European Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid for the speed with which they have released aid worth two million euros. The French government has just requested the activation of the Solidarity Fund. Commissioner, this emergency fund amounting to two million euros for the period 2014-2020 has been halved compared to the previous budgetary programming. However, it is feared that climate change will increase the intensity, if not the frequency, of disasters that could trigger recourse to this fund. Hurricane Irma is just a case in point. Hence the absolute need to sanctify this Solidarity Fund and to increase funding in the future.It would be tragic if yet another disaster struck and the European Union was unable to help one of its regions in distress.As the elected representative of these territories, I thank you for your listening and your attention.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Hurricane Irma was actually a hurricane in the hors category, you could say category 6. Unfortunately human lives have been lost and on St. Maarten the damage is worse than expected: 90% of the buildings are damaged, one third of the buildings are even completely destroyed. Immediately the Member States concerned, the Netherlands and France, started to provide emergency aid and the European Commission joined in, quite rightly and I think it is also possible under Article 198 of the Treaty. But more is needed than emergency aid alone. We have many relationships with the Caribbean and we also know that the climate is becoming more unpredictable and erratic. So we have to make residents more resilient and that can be achieved through better planning, better buildings, building emergency supplies and the like. As the European Union, we must help with this, we must show solidarity. Some say the rules prevent that, but necessity breaks the law. We must act now, together.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Hurricane Irma has wreaked havoc in the Caribbean. We regret the fatalities and the many injuries. The images of the enormous trail of destruction make a deep impression. Roads, ports, airports, hospitals and schools: they are destroyed or badly damaged. The upheaval is great. People are struggling with a shortage of food and drinking water. Often nothing is left of their houses. I would like to let the residents of the affected areas know that the ALDE Group is deeply sympathetic to them. First and foremost, acute emergency aid must now be provided. But very soon we have to start thinking about the recovery and reconstruction of the islands. Together with my French colleague Thierry Cornillet, I wrote a letter to Commission President Juncker and we call on the Commission to clarify what financial support the European Commission can provide for reconstruction. It is in addition to what the Commissioner has reported and I think it is good to make that more precise. Because whether it concerns the French Saint-Martin on the one hand, or on the other hand St. Martin, St. Eustatius, Saba or, for example, Anguilla and the other affected areas, whether it concerns the outermost region of Saint-Martin or the other countries and regions overseas, the legal status of the affected areas is different but the great need for reconstruction aid is the same. Commission, so make smart use of the funds within the existing rules or submit proposals here to the European Parliament to enable reconstruction. In conclusion, while Europe and the Caribbean are separated by thousands of miles of water, we are united and united in our determination to get the reconstruction off the ground.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, in Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Martin, Irma swept away decades of efforts in just a few hours and plunged the populations into the greatest disarray, populations to whom we express our full compassion. In front of this unleashed force of nature, we must show humility and dignity, but we must also be lucid about the time lost since the first reports of the IPCC for the adaptation of the islands to extreme climatic phenomena which - we know it - will increase with the climate changes which are already underway. If the question for us today is indeed that of European solidarity, of the humanitarian emergency, and - you have said it, Commissioner - this was very quickly engaged and it was expressed , we must also situate ourselves in the next time: that of the reconstruction for these devastated islands. Not to rebuild by reproducing the mistakes of the past, but to rebuild differently, differently, sustainably. Revive the islands by helping them to reinvent themselves even in their development model, otherwise these islands will be reborn to come back to life.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first it was Harvey, the wettest hurricane ever recorded that flooded Houston in hours, then Irma, with record-breaking winds of 185mph. Yet as the eye of the storm moved through the Caribbean and Florida, politicians, the media and others closed their eyes in order to protect their interests. Their priority: maintaining the status quo of turbo-capitalism, a system that requires perpetual growth and, in varying degrees, climate change denial. Indeed, when my colleague, Caroline Lucas MP made the link between Hurricane Irma and climate change to UK minister Alan Duncan, he said she lacked humanity. When we learned that Mr Duncan had previously pocketed thousands of pounds working for an oil company, it all of a sudden became clear why he had made such an absurd snipe. After all, Caroline Lucas was simply respecting the science that a warmer world with warmer oceans leads to greater evaporation, which in turn fuels more destructive storms. That’s no more than others have done from Gaston Brown, leader of the devastated Antigua and Barbuda, through to President Macron of France and Pope Francis. I say it is politicians, who defend the interests of fossil fuel industries, who lack humanity. Equally inhumane is the fact that 5 trillion dollars is thrown at the fossil fuel industry each year in subsidies; that’s 6.5% of global GDP supporting the dirty economy of the past when we should be investing it in the clean, green economy of the future. The humane thing to do is to act in the interests of those whose lives are now being torn apart by climate breakdown, especially those living in low-lying territories and in the path of storms; as well as millions of others across the globe, especially those from the poorest communities. This demands a new ethics politics and a new economic model.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, last week the West Indies were devastated by Hurricane Irma. All our thoughts are with the bereaved families affected by this disaster of an exceptional magnitude. It will obviously be necessary to take stock of this tragedy in the Member States concerned, in particular in France, where the French government has failed. It will also be necessary to think about the financing of habitats, public buildings and infrastructures that are safer, able to withstand ever more powerful cyclones. But the time is not yet to take stock, it is time for an emergency. Emergency because the inhabitants are currently facing a shortage of drinking water, electricity and even food. But also urgent because the inhabitants were delivered during several days to the looting by armed bands. This is why our group has tabled a motion for a resolution aimed at mobilizing as soon as possible the European Union Solidarity Fund in favor of the islands affected by Hurricane Irma.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims of Hurricane Irma and to express my solidarity and compassion to those affected. For the French islands of Saint-Martin and Saint-Barthélemy, the damage is already considerable and it will take time to rebuild everything. Due to the urgency and having regard to the close links which unite the European Union with these regions of the Caribbean, regardless of their status as outermost regions or as overseas countries and territories, I invite the European Union to continue and even strengthen its action in the region, the needs are so colossal. The European Union, through the Solidarity Fund for the French region of Saint-Martin and via reserve B of the 11th EDF for the community of Saint-Barthélemy, or for the Dutch OCTs of Sint Maarten and English of Anguilla, must help the victims of this hurricane, the violence of which is unprecedented in the region. It is crucial that all the Directorates-General concerned - I am thinking in particular of DGs REGIO, DEVCO and ECHO - mobilize and coordinate their actions so that the European Union's response is as effective as possible in areas which, like Saint -Martin, have a dual status: RUP on the French side and OCT on the Dutch side. These different statutes should in no way influence the response of the European Union. We have a duty to rescue and help our fellow citizens.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D) .
text: - Four dead, many injured and missing and residents who will be dependent on emergency aid for weeks to come and enormous material damage: that is the devastating effect of hurricane Irma on 34 km2, namely the Dutch part of St. Maarten. It is appropriate from this place to bear witness to our condolences to all the relatives and victims, and in this House I, of course, also address my French and British colleagues. Because the French and the British part of the Caribbean have also been hit hard. May I also call from this place to all donate personally to the Red Cross? Europe should never turn its back on its inhabitants in an emergency and fortunately that is often not the case. This morning, in the votes on the Solidarity Fund, we showed that Europe is side by side with the people affected by the devastating earthquakes in Italy. Yet even this week it is unclear whether all EU citizens can expect support from Europe when it comes to reconstruction. As you know, the island of Sint Maarten consists of a Dutch and a French part and both have different legal status within the EU. Both parts could therefore receive different forms of aid for reconstruction, while all residents of both parts simply have EU citizenship. I find it incomprehensible that on an island of only 87 km2, the EU may use various forms of financial support, especially when you know that many of the facilities on the island are also shared. That is why I want a commitment from the Commission that both parts of Sint Maarten will be treated equally in terms of financial support. In my opinion there should be no distinction. The island should not be torn apart by EU statuses. As far as I am concerned, all residents of Sint Maarten and therefore our solidarity are paramount. (The speaker answered a "blue card" question (Rule 162, paragraph 8 of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Thierry Cornillet (ALDE)
text: question "blue card".- Mr President, things will go very quickly.I have indeed co-signed with my colleague Mr van Miltenburg a letter to Mr Juncker with a proposal, Commissioner, which interests you.This morning we voted 1.2 billion euros to unlock the earthquake in Italy on August 24.This vote was taken with general indifference.You have a unique opportunity to give an idea of the envelope that the European Union will develop for Saint-Martin and Saint-Barthélemy, in such a way that our fellow citizens realize that the European Union knows how to be united andsay it when it's interesting.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for this question.The extent of the damage and what is needed for reconstruction are currently being mapped out on both Sint-Maarten and Saint-Martin.And indeed, the Solidarity Fund offers an opportunity to help people on the islands on their way again.For me, it doesn't even matter that much with which budget line we pay for this.I am just saying that there cannot be a distinction between the French and the Dutch part when it comes to aid in reconstruction.

name: President. –
text: Mr Cornillet, I respect your freedom of expression, but it was catch-the-eye rather than a question. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for coming. We witnessed a trail of destruction left by Hurricane Irma that, in a historic rage, devastated homes, claimed a high number of victims and caused serious damage to infrastructure. The estimated years are about 100 billion dollars, which is equivalent to half a percentage point of the United States' GDP. Climate change is one of the greatest environmental, social, economic threats facing the planet and humanity. Every day we see examples of severe climatic phenomena that show everyone this truth: hurricanes of greater intensity, cyclones of maximum degree, which are more and more frequent, and the warming of the oceans, with results that will provoke about 200 million refugees in the coming years. For the President of the United States, this is an inconvenient truth. The Nobel Prize in Economics Stiglitz wrote that, under the leadership of President Trump, the United States has taken another important step towards its confirmation as a delinquent state by abandoning the Paris Agreement. Climate change is a challenge and the European Union must be prepared for this challenge.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Hurricane Irma was really devastating. To express our condolences to the relatives of the victims, who have suffered these irreparable damages, and to say that these catastrophes are due to global warming. The planet is taking revenge and is taking revenge, above all, on those who are the world's polluters. We cannot forget the great catastrophes in the United States where they must realize that they must join and remain in the Paris Treaty for the protection of the environment. The second issue is, of course, that we have major disasters in both St. Martin and St. Bartholomew and, of course, the Solidarity Fund can clearly be mobilized. The Solidarity Fund is mobilized when there are huge disasters. Unfortunately, we had very big disasters here. But the Solidarity Fund can mobilize and support our fellow citizens there. Of course, this also applies to the Dutch side of St. Martin, although, formally, it is not part of the whole system. However, I think that solidarity must be mutual and continuous on all sides of those affected.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to express my condolences to the families of people who have lost their lives and to people who have lost their homes.The infrastructure of those islands is really very affected.I think it is important to keep up with the principle: He who gives quickly gives twice.I have noticed that President Trump, whom we very often criticize here, with the exception of me, has decided to help very quickly to help the affected areas.This should be a challenge for the Commission's work.I know that the Commission is trying to provide aid, but the Solidarity Fund should, in my opinion, be more flexible.Within our Committee on Regional Development, we have sought to ensure that guarantees of greater flexibility are included in the legislation.Perhaps it would be good to strengthen this flexibility even better, and we should strengthen the possibilities for urgent intervention.Article 198 does not seem to me to be entirely sufficient.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I come from an outermost region, the Canary Islands, and that is why I want to take advantage of and not miss this opportunity to show my support and solidarity with these wonderful islands that deserve immediate special support from the European Union in the face of the tragedy thatthey are living.The Solidarity Fund requires too many requirements to be mobilized, impossible to meet in regions like this.Many times we have defended that, as established by the Treaty itself, these regions should have special treatment, also and even more so in catastrophic situations such as the one they are experiencing.We must not allow these islands physically remote from Europe but tremendously European to feel unprotected.The European Union has to give an urgent response.Europe will be stronger and more credible the more effective its solidarity is.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you all for your interventions, it was a fruitful exchange of views. I truly share your sadness and your concerns. We are indeed confronted with an extraordinary disaster and definitely, our thoughts are with the people in the affected areas. Of course, I completely agree with you regarding the climate change role in this new phenomenon with devastating situations, hurricanes, many other completely new phenomena of the world’s conditions. We have to learn from this large-scale emergency and to respond in the best way possible. So prevention, preparedness and response are all essential and reinforce each other. I would also like to thank everyone who has cooperated in preparing for this unprecedented natural disaster and responding to it, inside the Commission, but also in Member States, in other European institutions and in the field on the ground. The European Union is working on a continuous basis, 24/7, through our emergency response coordination centre in Brussels. To help the countries affected by hurricane Irma. Our solidarity, in this emergency phase, very critical phase, starts from Brussels. I am really proud – as a European citizen, not only as a Commissioner – of this centre. I take this opportunity to extend an invitation to all of you – some colleagues have done so already – to visit this centre. It is very critical and good to see the people there deal with this devastating situation. Going back to Irma: once more information from the field becomes available, further action will be taken. For the moment, we have mobilised all available instruments for immediate relief, humanitarian assistance, but also civil protection assistance. But definitely, we also look to the future: to reconstruction efforts. The European Union is also mobilised to assist affected countries on the longer-term. We have funding and expertise available. EU regions are eligible for EU solidarity funds based on damage assessments and their economic impact.  It is difficult for me to say something more, but I believe that in our Union, many times we realise that the rules are going through a way and are going to reflect the real conditions. Let us not forget that natural disasters have no national borders.
