As Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management I would like to focus on this – working together, we are better able to assist affected populations. Europe is about solidarity. I am proud that it is able to collectively help at the time of great need. It is our job, it is our moral duty and when we achieve this, it is good to say it in order to persuade our people that European Union is not only a bureaucratic machine, but also can provide tangible solidarity on the ground.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Ulrike Rodust, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the multiannual plan for North Sea demersal stocks and fisheries exploiting them (COM (2016) 0493 - C8-0336 / 2016 - 2016/0238 (COD)) (A8-0263 / 2017).

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner Vella, ladies and gentlemen! Tomorrow we shall vote in plenary on the North Sea multiannual plan for demersal stocks. After the Baltic Sea Plan, this is the second multi-year plan that we want to adopt. First of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all staff for the good cooperation so far. The matter is not an easy thing. It's about a lot. And it's about now. We want to advance the plan as quickly as possible, because “Brexit” is hovering over the North Sea. In the PECH vote in July, a clear majority voted in favor of my report but against the mandate for negotiations. The reasons for this are reflected in the amendments tabled for plenary. I can see the following primary lines of conflict here: Firstly, the question of whether and how recreational fishing is included in the plan. Secondly, which demersal stocks are covered by the plan and, thirdly, in which area and under what conditions fishing opportunities may be set. In the previous discussion of these subject areas, I never tire of referring to the basic regulation as the basis for all provisions. And even today I would not like to do without this reference, for example with regard to the precautionary approach. The precautionary approach from the basic regulation must apply here. In the Baltic Sea Plan, I see a blueprint for the further multi-year plans, including this North Sea plan. However, I am aware that certain special features of the sea basin must be addressed. I think that the PECH report agreed in July is a good basis for a multi-year plan in the North Sea. The amendments that have now been tabled on the role of recreational fishing aim at the following: Firstly, a condition for consideration recreational fishing should be an impact assessment. Any measures should be proportionate to the objectives. Second: The legislator should be able to enact measures for recreational fishing, should these be necessary for the sustainability of stocks. And in my opinion, the PECH report already contains a few good, because they are targeted and clear, precautions with regard to recreational fishing. Amendment 66 is based on the experience we had in the Baltic Sea last year. Which stocks should the multi-year plan include? Do we really want to reduce the plan to a few demersal stocks, as envisaged by some of the amendments? In my opinion, the plan should include clear targets and targets for all demersal stocks. In order to be able to comply with the requirements and target values, clear conditions for fishing opportunities must exist. Here we have value ranges in the appendices for certain stocks. Amendments were also made to these value ranges. I therefore ask my colleagues to support the PECH report's approach to recreational fishing. I also ask for your support for the possibility of starting negotiations with the Council as soon as possible.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Rodust, and her team, and also the shadow rapporteurs, for the excellent work done to achieve, in my opinion, a well-balanced report on our proposal for a North Sea plan.  The multi-annual plans are a cornerstone in implementing the objectives of the common fisheries policy at sea basin level, in order to ensure fit-for-purpose fisheries management in our mixed fisheries. They are also important because they pave the way for the direct involvement of stakeholders in fisheries management. This is the second multi-annual plan that the Commission has proposed after the Baltic plan which was adopted last year, in 2016, but it will certainly not be the last. The Adriatic plan has already been presented to you and I aim to propose a multi-annual plan for the mixed demersal fisheries in western waters by the end of the year.  We all have to work together in order to ensure that multi-annual plans are in place for our key mixed fisheries when the landing obligation comes fully into force in the year 2019. I hope that trilogues can start as soon as possible. This is very important. Multi-annual plans will give us the tools to manage these fisheries in a modern and sustainable way. I have read your amendments with great interest and welcome the amendments that further align this plan to the Baltic Sea plan. Following the Baltic plan helps to avoid having to negotiate once again those points that were already discussed in detail and settled during the trilogue negotiations back in 2016, such as the use of maximum sustainable yield (MSY) ranges.  There are also elements that were not dealt with to the extent needed in the Baltic plan and where we need to find a way forward. Specifically, we have to find a way to deal with mixed demersal fisheries. Such an approach must ensure that we continue to fish sustainably, while also ensuring a flexible management approach. Whatever the political context may be, we will need to have a multi-annual plan in any case, to enable us to put in place a modern management framework for sustainable fisheries.  The Council adopted a general approach in April as a starting point for the negotiations with Parliament. There is a lot of support on the Council side for reaching a mutually acceptable outcome on the North Sea plan before the end of the year. We need the North Sea plan, as it will give us the flexibility to make the management of these fisheries fit for the 21st Century.

name: Jens Gieseke
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Vella, ladies and gentlemen, dear rapporteur Rodust! In the new North Sea Plan, the stocks of the various fish species are summarized in a management plan for the first time, with the aim of sustainably managing the fish stocks in the North Sea and ensuring constant fishing opportunities for fishermen. The theory sounds good, but I see two problems. First: Imagine you are a hobby angler - that is, recreational fisherman. If some colleagues here have plans, you would have to register your catches in the future. The hobby anglers would therefore be burdened with bureaucratic hurdles, even though recreational fishing in the North Sea has hardly any impact on the fish stocks. That is excessive and unnecessary. I therefore think it is wrong to include recreational fishing in the North Sea plan as a matter of principle. In the event that the fish stocks in the North Sea are poor, recreational fishing can be restricted by regulations that are already in place, and I think that makes sense. We as the EPP have tabled amendments here to the plenary tomorrow, the ECR too, I think that these compromises or these proposals are entirely acceptable. In addition, the legal basis for including recreational fishing is questionable. Neither the basic ordinance - the fishing bible, so to speak - nor the Baltic Sea plan and thus the blueprint for the North Sea plan expressly stipulate this. There is no impact assessment by the Commission and therefore no basis for proper legislation. We shouldn't overshoot here. Second, commercial fishing in the North Sea must not be subject to stricter regulations than fishing in the Baltic Sea. Many families close to the coast have jobs and their livelihoods there. We must not restrict fishing in an ideological way, we have to Find realistic and unbureaucratic solutions that do not burden the mostly small businesses unduly.Here we need a right balance between protecting marine resources on the one hand and protecting an entire profession on the other.I think we can come to a good solution here.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, dear Commissioner, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Ulrike Rodust, on the work she has done and, thanks to the good work she has done, there are few amendments to vote on, but most of them are still very important. In this plenary we hear about sustainability many times. It is almost an indispensable word for any politically correct speech, especially when it comes to environmental issues or those related to the exploitation of natural resources. However, when the time comes to decide, we can see that the votes now have to please voters, forgetting that sustainability, not even for tomorrow, is for the day after tomorrow, or another day, should be forever . We have to end this vicious, populist cycle and become consistent. The Common Fisheries Policy approved in this House in 2013 is very clear. Overfishing should have become part of the European Union's past by now. For the springs for which it was not possible to end overfishing by 2015, it must be done at the latest by 2020. And how is it done? It's easy: sustainable fishing limits apply. Multi-annual plans and, in this case, the multi-annual plan for the North Sea, must include operating limits that do not exceed the maximum sustainable yield. If we want to be truly sustainable, this is the way. If we do not follow this path then, in support of the truth, let us stop saying that we want sustainability. It is now essential that this report be approved and that the trialogue proceed. Fishermen operating in the North Sea need a stable and functional legal framework that will serve as a foundation for negotiations for the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, that is, in this process, time is really an essential part.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - If there is a sea on this planet with a successful fisheries policy, it is the North Sea. If there is a sea on this planet where there are numerous regulations in force, it is the North Sea. As a result, all fish stocks in the North Sea are well maintained. All major fish stocks show positive trends. Great sacrifices have been made by the fishermen themselves. The size of all North Sea fleets has shrunk in recent decades. Many fishermen were forced to stop and end their life's work, which was particularly painful in family businesses. But the fishermen have also made a significant contribution to making the North Sea stocks more sustainable and to restore them. We see most clearly that in the development of the innovative pulse technique, a fishing method that saves fuel, that does not break up the seabed and that above all brings up the fish that one wants to catch, selection in optimum form. Unfortunately, there are still groups and NGOs that claim that the North Sea is overfished. Even stricter rules and unacceptably high standards are demanded. That makes the situation really unworkable. And unfortunately there are also colleagues who do not want pulse fishing. I find it incomprehensible and irresponsible. Because it is innovation, but would people want to go back to the time of the beam trawl? Please don't! On the basis of these considerations, we support the plan that is on the table, provided the vote does not go too bad tomorrow. And then we give both the North Sea and the tax authorities a good chance for sustainable fishing, and especially sustainable mixed fishing.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to make four or five points here. The first is, of course, for Ulrike Rodust. It is a pleasure to work with a rapporteur who has ‘Ordnung’. ‘Ordnung muss sein’, as the Germans say. That was a very good start and it guarantees a good result. The second point is recreational fisheries. That is going to be a bigger and bigger problem in all fisheries and it is coming up also in technical measures. If we do not do something, then it will grow and grow, and overgrow our possibilities. The third issue is the FMSY. There is pressure to accept FMSY upper. I do not think that is an acceptable way of handling this issue. The common fisheries policy (CFP) was clear on this issue and therefore, I hope for support for my amendment on FMSY as a limit. The fourth problem comes up also in very many files. We are for regionalisation, but we need a backstop. If the regions do not understand how to make their decisions, then we will run into a very problematic situation. This is coming up in several files and therefore, even if you do not like the Commission to step in, we think it is necessary to have a backstop for the future.  The fifth thing concerns the question of order. When this debate started after lunch, my speaking time was at around 19.30; we have lost one and a half hours because of bad handling of the discussion. This thing here is called a wristwatch and I recommend that the presidency has one so that they can count the seconds and the minutes in the future.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - This European Parliament likes to look ahead. I will give a few examples. Global deforestation will have ended by 2030. By 2050, CO2 emissions will have decreased by 95% and by 2020 overfishing will have stopped. But the closer we get to a deadline, the more looking ahead turns into moving forward. The fishing plan for the North Sea threatens to become a symbol of advancement. If this plan goes ahead, overfishing will continue to be possible, even after 2020. That can be done differently and it must be done differently. Let us use the maximum sustainable yield as the absolute upper limit when setting the quotas. This leaves no room for differences of interpretation or flexibility. We agreed on this a long time ago, when 2020 still seemed far away. 2048: that is a year that still seems a long way away, but it is the year in which the world's seas will be empty if we do not take measures quickly. I therefore call on all MEPs not to allow quotas above the maximum sustainable yield and to take protective measures that apply to all species. It remains for me to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Rodust, for her efforts. She has committed herself to a sustainable North Sea plan and I hope that we can count on her and her group for the vote tomorrow. I also believe that European agricultural and fishing subsidies should be abolished.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! First of all, I would like to start by thanking Ulrike Rodust for her work with this management plan. She also led the work on the reform of the EU's new fisheries policy. The most central issue in the whole reform is how we can fish sustainably. Together with the Council of Ministers, we decided in the basic regulation that fish stocks should be restored and preserved above levels that ensure a maximum sustainable return. This is the only solution for us to have sustainable stocks in the long term. Then it is not enough to fish at a level that allows a mortality rate well above that which is maximally sustainable. Then we will never reach our goal. It goes without saying that it is impossible. The common fisheries policy set a limit, and that limit is called FMSY. We can not fish more than that. I therefore support the amendment tabled by the ALDE Group to remove intervals that exceed FMSY and call on everyone else to do the same. That is what we all decided jointly in the common fisheries policy. We all have an interest in sustainable fish stocks. It is a prerequisite for healthy seas, for employment and income in commercial fishing but also for recreational fishing. We are many to use the resource, and in some cases it is the case that recreational fishing has a very large impact on fish stocks. We have a common interest in conserving the stocks so that they continue to provide returns for future generations as well. Therefore, recreational fishing must also take responsibility in cases where it has a major impact on our fish stocks. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries adopted a point that says just that. It is important to support that point if we are to be able to guarantee long-term sustainability.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, look at a map, any of you. Much of the North Sea is British, and much of the rest is Norwegian. For the European Union to have a plan past 2019 is sheer effrontery. Worse, having stolen commercial fisheries, they are now trying to steal recreational fisheries by adding them to the plan too. It is entirely straightforward and simple: we reject this plan. Brexit must mean that this never happens. Instead, there must be a United Kingdom fisheries plan. This should encourage proper conservation and allow fish stocks to grow. Keep out all foreign boats, make fishing flags of convenience impossible, be properly policed by the Royal Navy: this is a real North Sea plan, and we hope for the sake of British fishermen that David Davis is not stupid enough to be taken in or gulled by yours. Ruth Davidson in Scotland is not backing Brexit, so that is not going to help our fisheries, and neither is Nicola Sturgeon’s SNP, who want to give our fisheries away to the European Union. That is unacceptable to Scottish fisheries and the reason why Alex Salmond lost his position, as did various other Scottish nationalists, and the rest of them will too.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, in my opinion this plan for the North Sea has two advantages. The first is, of course, the multiannual nature, which will make it possible to give more visibility to fishermen. It is important, in fact, that the variation in fishing possibilities for a particular stock is not sudden from one year to the next. The second advantage is that the purpose of this plan is to remedy the problems caused by stocks with limiting quotas. Indeed, demersal stocks, that is to say stocks of species living on the seabed, are often exploited in mixed fisheries. Concretely, this means that, when the fillets are raised, there may be different species caught: cod, haddock, saithe, whiting, sole, plaice or even langoustine. For fishermen, the problem is that they should in principle stop their campaign as soon as they have reached their quota on one species, even if they still have quotas on other species. Indeed, the landing obligation now makes it illegal to reject any catch exceeding a quota. This plan should therefore remedy this problem by introducing the possibility of trading quotas between Member States, but also with third countries. Likewise, the fishing possibilities will be allocated by range in order to be more flexible. All these measures therefore converge towards greater flexibility and greater visibility for the benefit of fishermen. This is the reason why we will vote in favor of this plan.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: - Mr President, dear Commissioner, I remember well what we approved together with the Council in 2013: the reform of the CFP, which today some want to ignore. And when that happens, we politicians lose all credibility with society, and operators do not have legal security, an essential requirement for any company. So we bet on multi-year plans and regionalization, and we work with fishermen, convincing them that regionalized measures through multi-year plans would bring them very close to decision-making. However, when enthusiasm turns to frustration, it is very difficult to restore confidence. The fishermen are frustrated today, just like me. They expected something else from this plan. They hoped that the ranges within which the Council can set the total allowable catches would be set on sound scientific grounds. This is precisely what the basic Regulation establishes in its Article 9 (1), but, in this plan, ranges have been proposed without any scientific basis. The fishermen were also confident that the measures would take into account their socio-economic impact, as provided for in the CFP in Article 9 (4). Here again they were misled. I am not going to refer to the capture possibilities, which in this case have also been deceived. I sincerely hope that these points will be modified tomorrow. I would not in any way wish to associate myself with a mandate from Parliament that misleads those who must implement what we decide here, since the operators themselves would have no motivation to comply with these requirements. (He agreed to answer a question raised under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Patrick O'Flynn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to ask the Member what he proposes to do on behalf of the rest of the European fleet when the United Kingdom takes back control of its exclusive maritime economic zone stretching up to 200 miles from the British coast, as it is entitled to under international law.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- When that happens, we will see, as we will also see what happens with access to European markets by the United Kingdom.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the excellent work of rapporteur Ulrike Rodust and, as I underlined during the debate on the multi-annual plan in the Baltic Sea, a multi-year plan is a good tool for fishermen. It responds to the urgent need for visibility and stability, which is certainly insufficient but necessary for the economic and social viability of any economic activity. Another condition for this viability of fishing activity is the sustainable management of the resource. The implementation of the maximum sustainable yield (MSY) in line with the level of TACs (total allowable catches) has already produced spectacular results on fish stocks, since 52% of the North Sea stocks are managed from sustainably and have achieved MSY - and we do not say this enough, Commissioner - and the results are even better in the North East Atlantic. This is why I do not understand, in addition to the question of legality which Mr Mato has just mentioned, in addition to the question of the principle of equality which would be affected in relation to the Baltic plan, I do not understand the overbidding of the last few hours on the RMD. I am talking about Amendments 80 and 85, tabled by the ALDE Group, and I say this sincerely, really, I do not understand you. We have an ambitious common fisheries policy based on MSY which makes it possible to overcome overfishing in Europe and it is when we should be satisfied that you choose to distill doubt among Europeans, by asking to add more again and again. On the other hand, I would like to welcome the initiative of the rapporteur, who has taken recreational fishing into account, and I support her position, on the condition, however, that the future quotas allocated to recreational fishing are correctly calculated on the historical catches of this fishery and not on the fishing quotas professional, who would thus suffer a double penalty.Finally, these fishing areas in the North Sea are particularly sensitive in the perspective of Brexit - we have just heard.They are in fact adjacent to or integrated into the United Kingdom.This plan must also serve as a roadmap for future friendly cooperation between the Union and third countries in the sustainable management of fishery resources.

name: Czesław Hoc (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! The essence of Mrs Ulrike Rodust's good report is the implementation in the North Sea of ​​the key aspects of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy. Thus, the multiannual plan should ensure that the management objectives and targets and management standards are the same and cover all demersal stocks in the North Sea. Also, orders to restore caught species to healthy levels should apply to all benthic stocks. The multi-annual plan is designed to operate them sustainably in accordance with MSY principles. This report will also facilitate the introduction of the landing obligation, and regional cooperation will provide solutions for the so-called blocking species in mixed fisheries. It should also be emphasized that the sea basins of the European Union are a symbolic system of connected vessels. Disregarding the ecosystem and any deviation from sustainable fishing in the North Sea will sooner or later have disastrous consequences in other seas surrounding the European Union.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I believe that the best way to balance the objective of conserving fish stocks in these waters of the North Sea and keeping our fishing industry active is to continue to support these multi-year plans and align the maximum sustainable yield within the parameters of the common fisheries policy. That is why I will not support rank modifications. I am pleased that the plan incorporates recreational fishing: it is an urgent necessity. I will vote in favor of the Commission's delegated acts to prevent a possible inaction of some Member States, in the framework of the so-called regionalization of the CFP, from unprotecting populations and, in the same vein, I am committed to maintaining control measures, which they were eliminated in the Commission. And I agree to maintain the precautionary principle when there are not enough studies to determine the status of populations and there is a clear risk. I also hope that Brexit does not detract from the effectiveness of a plan focused on protecting life and the marine environment, a task that, above all, interests those who live in it.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, representing the fishing nation of Scotland I believe that fisheries management should lie in the hands of the fishing nations themselves, cooperating necessarily with each other on a regional basis, such as around the North Sea. This belief holds true whether within the EU or outwith. Scotland should have the power to work with its neighbours to manage its fisheries within the principles set out in international law.  The old CFP was an over-centralised disaster. The reformed policy at least provides a foundation for a more regional system of management. Indeed, the Commission states that Member States having direct management interest may submit joint recommendations for fisheries management in the North Sea. This is not before time.  While supporting the basic principle of multiannual planning, and in particular the devolved nature of decision-making, I do have concerns about the inclusion of recreational fisheries by this Parliament. That goes in the opposite direction, and I cannot support such an idea. Surely the fishing nations of the North Sea can decide for themselves whether that is a problem and, if so, how to deal with it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Ian, for taking my question. I always have great respect for you and know a fair bit about fish with being on the Committee on Fisheries. I just want to ask you: do you now recognise that we are leaving – and Scotland is leaving – the European Union and that fishing will be managed by Britain and not by the European Union, and that, because of all that we have been telling you forever, that we need to get out of the European Union to protect Scottish fish and protect Scottish fishermen and their fleets, that now in the north-east of Scotland, people are building boats, training young lads to go fishing and there is now a boom in this thing. Will you now agree that you were wrong in the SNP, and that UKIP was right, sir?

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Many times in this place I have said on the record that the CFP has been a disaster for Scotland, and many times I have said in this place on the record that one of the principal reasons for that has been the failure of the UK government – successive UK governments – to do anything useful for Scotland’s fishing communities in EU negotiations. I do not trust the UK government in EU negotiations. I do not trust a UK government to sensibly and effectively manage Scotland’s fisheries itself either. That’s why I said earlier that Scotland should have the power: Scotland, a fishing nation, should have the power to manage its fisheries along with its neighbours around the North Sea and in the other areas where we have an active interest.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Vella! Mrs Rodust as rapporteur: Thank you for your extensive work. But we should always keep an eye on one principle in this regard, and that means: Quality has to come before speed, whether Brexit is on our backs or other speed-increasing criteria, we owe it to our fishermen. And if the plan does not keep what it promises, then the sector and the population will be more dissatisfied with the EU. That is why we as the EPP are in favor of having very clear and simple definitions here. In the North Sea Plan we need a simple application for grouping. That means: only those species that are actually quoted, that have totally allowed catch. And we need applicable corridors for the quotas on a scientific basis. When I keep hearing “Well, there must be no overfishing, etc.”…: When a stock is in such good shape that it threatens others, so to speak - we have this, for example, with the interaction between whiting and the crab - you have to take more out of the stock so that the crabs can recover. With a flexible corridor solution, the area for the regulation of the limiting species, the choke species, is also very, very important. Just think of cod and plaice. If the quota for the plaice has been intercepted, so to speak, then I have to be careful and have a clear understanding of how I can continue to deal with the cod. I just want to say one more thing in a nutshell: For 50 years, the number of edible fish in the North Sea has not been better than it is now. We have a million tons more biomass for the herring. Because it is always said here: Yes, everything that is being done here in the European Union is impossible. We did have management plans for the cod plan! He was in a very difficult situation, now has it recovers, it is beyond the trigger point, we can fish it again.And that has to be said again here in this round: The management plans that we had up to now have also had an effect!

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague Ulrike for the good work he has done on this plan, as in any work he faces. It must be said that the introduction of multi-annual plans is one of the key instruments in the common fisheries policy to manage resources in a sustainable way. It is essential not to lose sight of the fact that these multiannual plans, both for the North Sea and the Baltic one, already approved, set a precedent for future management proposals in the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. And, as we move towards more southern waters, the fisheries are mixed, that is, the interaction of species is greater, so it is essential to provide these areas with reasonable management plans in the future. Multi-year plans also have to be endowed with flexibility, and that flexibility has to allow moving within the ranges established by fishing mortality, both to make decisions when stocks are in danger and implement the necessary corrective measures, and to increase the possibilities fishing when stocks are in good condition. It is essential to note that, through this plan, waters that belong to the United Kingdom will be managed, and it is very important to note here that, despite Brexit - the United Kingdom leaving the European Union - it is essential to make a responsible management of fisheries, because fish do not understand borders, gentlemen. And I say it to those in front, especially.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: - "It is also kerremesse in Ostdunkerke, it is also true kerremesse in d'helle".Fair in hell: that's what the fishermen say to us when the weather is bad.And when I see what is on the table here in this European Parliament, I am not completely at ease.I live by the sea on the Flemish coast.When I see the fishermen with us in Nieuwpoort, Ostend, Zeebrugge, Blankenberge, I see that they are having a hard time.They are having a hard time, also because of the matters that are being decided here in Europe and also because of the Brexit that is coming.At the same time, just as farmers like to see their land and their animals, fishermen like to see the sea and fish.They also realize all too well that they must cherish them and that they will have to make the transition to more sustainable fishing.But that can also be done without overly complex plans.Let us do it that way.Let us develop a fair, flexible and simple system and please let us also allow recreational fishermen their fish.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, from what I see, we may have a repeat of the 'cod war', which happened in the late 1970s, when Great Britain was now coming to the European Union in transition. We are already seeing contradictions between representatives, MPs from Scotland, and those who supported Brexit. Secondly, this plan essentially follows the Baltic plan. The conditions have been set there and if we do not discuss these plans, these plans will now be implemented in other areas as well. Thirdly, there is a serious issue with recreational fishing. It must be addressed. Several concerns were raised. There can be no such huge administrative burden for amateur fishermen. The socio-economic impact has also not been taken into account. There are too many problems with this proposal. I hope that by tomorrow most of them will be settled.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for their interventions and valuable views and I promise that I have taken due note of this very interesting debate. I would like to make some comments and let me start with leisure fisheries because this was mentioned by a number of speakers. I think that recreational fishing must be taken into account when setting fishing opportunities, without unnecessary intervention. The way that we do this is: we always ask the Institute for Systems, Informatics and Safety (ISIS) to provide us with information on recreational angling when it plays a significant role. With regard to Brexit – a number of Members spoke about Brexit – I agree and it has already been said that stocks have no boundaries. As long as we have shared stocks, we also have a shared responsibility. We have to have the best management framework to work for sustainable fisheries, with or without Brexit. Others spoke about the issue of choke and this is indeed one of the main purposes of the plan. The ranges of fishing mortality will provide us with an additional instrument for addressing choke situations as well. Our colleague, Mr Serrão Santos, spoke about sustainability and I totally agree with him that we have to be serious about sustainability and to do away, phase out and stop overfishing because overfishing could be as harmful as illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU).  Mr Torvalds and Mr Mato spoke about regionalisation. It is true that some serious regions have taken regionalisation on board and it is working very well for them. It is also true that in some cases, the Commission has to come in and take decisions to act. But everyone is recognising that regionalisation is in the best interest of the stakeholders, and especially of the fishermen themselves. I do not agree with Ms Hazekamp when it was said that overfishing is continuing and we are not getting results. On the contrary, the common fisheries policy (CFP) is providing us with some positive results and as has already been mentioned, the number of stocks at maximum sustainable yield (MSY) has increased from 9 up to 36 and that is, for me, a very good result. I also agree with Linnéa Engström that with healthy stocks everyone benefits, whether this is the leisure or the commercial industries, so both have to take on responsibilities when it comes to sustainable management. Mr Mato knows that the worst thing that could impact negatively on fishermen is a lack of sustainable management and this is exactly what we do not want to have and is exactly what the multi-annual plan is giving us. I agree with Ms Thomas about the essentials of the plan, especially the sustainable management of resources not only to reach but to maintain the stocks at maximum sustainable yield (MSY). Mr Hudghton also reminded us that apart from the CFP, there are also international obligations to be complied with by everyone, including the UK after Brexit. I also agree with Mr Kuhn when he mentioned as well that we need to start looking at the interaction and the impact of one species over other species and we will be moving in that direction when we start taking into consideration and taking the ecosystem approach, because I agree that this is a very important remark. I also agree with Ms Aguilera García that we have to make multi-annual plans (MAPs) work so we can then move to other areas and to other stocks, especially in the South. Let me reiterate that it is of utmost importance that the multi-annual plans are made fit for purpose and to ensure this, they must focus on the tools to ensure a practical and a sustainable management framework for our mixed demersal fisheries. Multi-annual plans should be adopted as a matter of priority as well, and the Commission will make every effort to assist the co-legislators in the coming trilogues. Thank you once again for all your cooperation, remarks and comments.

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We have now heard some arguments in the debate on the subject of recreational fishing, value ranges and grouping. In this context I would like to remind you of the situation in the Baltic Sea. Recreational fishing has a major impact on the cod stocks there. In Amendment No 66 on recreational fishing in the PECH report, we therefore take up the structure of the ICES advice, which distinguishes between total catches, commercial catches and recreational fishing. The difference between total catch and recreational fishing gives the recommendation for commercial fishing. The total catch is limited by the value ranges of the multi-year plans. In my opinion, if recreational fishing is not taken into account when setting fishing opportunities, the CFP objectives cannot be met. The way in which the demersal fish stocks covered by the plan are dealt with has become very clear in the debate. A majority in plenary will have to decide that tomorrow. The same applies to the value ranges. I said earlier that I still hope that we will act quickly. The Brexit negotiations are not waiting for us, but we have to give the negotiators a stable foundation with the North Sea Management Plan as soon as possible. Thank you for the lively debate and I wish you all a good evening too.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, 14 September 2017.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on the future of the Erasmus + program by Petra Kammerevert, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education (2017/2740 (RSP)) (O-000062/ 2017 - B8-0326 / 2017).

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very honored Commissioner! This year Erasmus, one of the most successful programs in the EU, celebrates its 30th birthday. Over the course of these 30 years, the program has expanded significantly and has had a decisive impact on the personal and professional lives of around 9 million students, trainees, volunteers, teachers, educators and youth workers. Erasmus +, as it is called today, offers the ideal opportunity to experience Europe first hand and thus to consistently counteract the persistent Euroscepticism. This is because young people - be it as students, trainees or schoolchildren or adult specialists and teachers from different educational areas - see Europe as an opportunity through international exchange. Through Erasmus, Europe is made tangible for the individual. It offers the opportunity to participate directly in Europe. As a European citizen-oriented program, Erasmus promotes values ​​such as tolerance and freedom, understanding of other cultures and awareness of democracy. However, too few people still benefit from Erasmus +. According to the Commission, only around 5% of young EU citizens have participated in the program so far. The 30th anniversary of Erasmus + should therefore be used as an opportunity to improve and significantly expand the program. The Culture Committee put a question to the Commission for an oral answer and submitted a resolution in order to start the discussion on a follow-up program after 2020. In the context of the parliamentary resolution on the future of Erasmus +, the committee emphasizes the importance of the program as a flagship of the European Union and as an essential instrument to support activities in the fields of education, youth, training and sport. Nevertheless, it must be evaluated for the successor program how to make the access more open and can make it more inclusive so that disadvantaged young people also get the chance to have such an experience abroad. A large majority of the Committee has always viewed Erasmus as an important investment in the future of Europe and has therefore always advocated strong funding. In my opinion, the medium-term goal must be to give everyone under the age of 27 the opportunity to participate in at least one of the program parts. This requires a multiplication of the financial means already in the next program period. I very much welcome the fact that the Italian government, for example, has called for a tenfold increase in funds in the context of the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework and that many other political actors are already sympathizing with a specific figure as a factor in the multiplication. You can all be sure that you will run open doors at least in the Committee on Culture and Education and hopefully in the whole house. The overall budget of Erasmus + was increased significantly for the current funding period and was celebrated as a great success by the Commission and the European Parliament. This had aroused many expectations among applicants for better equipment for their projects. However, this increase took a long time to arrive. Many projects that were definitely eligible for funding had to and still have to be rejected. As a result, sponsors and institutions with no experience of European projects and programs in particular refrain from submitting an application or, if they are rejected, sit back in frustration and say: “I'll never do that again.” There is still a lack of clarity and a general one Determine the user unfriendliness of the guide. The application procedures are far too complex and the application forms, with almost 40 pages, far too extensive. We must also ensure that, for the future, in particular young people from disadvantaged backgrounds experience better support through Erasmus +. Mobility and education must not remain a privilege for the few. Particularly in the case of individual stays abroad as part of studies and training, there is a clear need for improvement, and everyone who has ever lived abroad knows that this is associated with many costs that can only be partially covered by the Erasmus funding. Erasmus is and was not an employment policy instrument, even if stays abroad naturally look good on your CV and so-called soft skills are acquired, which every employer would like to see. A follow-up program should focus on the principle of lifelong learning, lifelong mobility, and promote formal and non-formal learning equally. We have to be careful not to overload Erasmus + with labor market policy. With Erasmus + we achieve a high funding effect with little money and make a real contribution to strengthening the feeling of togetherness among people in the EU. Erasmus is a good investment in the future of our children and, like no other European Union program, it represents the success of the European idea. Let's set out together to make this program even more successful! I am counting on the support of the Commission and I hope that the Council will understand that the money is really well spent here.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Erasmus+ is the European Union’s most powerful tool to connect with citizens and create a community of values, knowledge, skills and competences. It brings people together in ways that no other programme can. Since its launch in 1987, Erasmus and its successor programmes have given nine million people the chance to study, train, volunteer or gain professional experience abroad. In 2014 the Erasmus+ programme integrated all previous initiatives in the fields of education, training, youth and sport. Since then, in less than three years, two million citizens from 33 European countries have experienced the positive impact of Erasmus+. This year we are proudly celebrating the programme’s 30th anniversary, involving European citizens – and especially young Europeans – through social media, conferences, debates and exhibitions across Europe. Thank you all for your support in celebrating the 30th anniversary on 13 June in this very hemicycle. Erasmus+ is undoubtedly a success story. It also enjoys support outside the political world across countries and institutions, with more and more calls for considerable budgetary increases for the next programme in order to reach even more Europeans. I would like to thank you for your oral questions and today’s debate, which underlines the two most crucial issues regarding the future programme, the programme’s structure and the money we will invest in it. The feedback we have received from national authorities and various stakeholders in the context of the mid—term evaluation indicates that there is a strong call for stability in the structure of the programme to meet the unmet demand and for further simplification to reduce the administrative burden for all. In particular, preliminary results of the Erasmus+ mid—term evaluation show the high level of appreciation by national authorities, stakeholders and project participants, notably of the integrated nature of the programme, covering learning in all its contexts, whether formal or non-formal, and at all levels of the lifelong learning continuum, from early childhood education and schools, vocational education and training through to higher education and adult learning; the adaptability of the programme, able to re-adjust priorities to EU-level emerging challenges and needs, for example the much-reinforced emphasis on social inclusion and prevention of violent radicalisation, following the Paris Declaration of March 2015, and the mobility experiences with high levels of satisfaction expressed both by learners and staff and across all fields and types of mobility. I strongly believe that Erasmus+ should be available to all young Europeans, and I share your ambition in this respect. We also need to focus on where the programme adds value. For example, the programme should support young people going into forward—looking study fields where Europe needs expertise and must have the ambition to be a world leader, such as climate change, clean energy, robotics, digitalisation, etc. The Commission will continue to put forward two sorts of action to support innovation and development. On the one hand, we focus on skills for life from an early age and with regard to all forms of learning. On the other hand, we encourage stronger links between schools, including vocational education and training schools and higher education institutions, as well as between education and the world of work. This will help young people develop a broad set of competences to do well in life and at work in increasingly multicultural societies. We must also respond to the calls for a more inclusive and outreaching programme. Thus we need to significantly increase the number of opportunities offered to school pupils, vocational education and training students and apprentices. The programme needs to help young people access high-quality education, irrespective of their social background. Mobility should therefore be common practice in school education and vocational education and training, similar to what has become the norm in higher education over the last decades. It is of paramount importance to the development of most-needed transfers of skills. Moreover, we should be more inclusive and better-suited to young people’s needs, and for this we need to provide a European experience even to those who are not mobile. In this context, making better use of digital approaches, virtual tools and online platforms plays a prominent role. Web—enhanced learning programmes, such as blended learning that combines digital media with traditional classroom methods, can complement physical mobility to widen access to the programme. It is in this vein that in June we launched a new Erasmus+ mobile application designed for students, vocational learners and participants in youth exchanges to facilitate the mobility experience for generations to come. This app will bring the Erasmus+ programme even closer to citizens, making it more user—friendly, accessible and inclusive and adapting it to the digital era. I welcome your support for strengthening Erasmus+ in order to allow it to reach many more Europeans and to continue building a stronger and better Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his understanding approach. I agree with you, Commissioner, that Erasmus+ is the most successful European programme. It is an investment in our future. We would like to ask the Commission about two very relevant points. What should be done to make the programme more accessible to more EU citizens? Secondly, what financial and budgetary reforms are needed to enable this flagship EU programme to reach its ambitious goals? This debate is very topical. Less than 5% of young Europeans benefit from the programme due to socioeconomic factors and limited funding. Erasmus+ is now facing increasing financial risks from other initiatives, such as the European Solidarity Corps. For this programme not to have any fresh money would be unacceptable for us.  I welcome the fact that volunteering is emphasised in our resolution because this value has to be enhanced. Erasmus+ has to be given priority and has to be more ambitious and reach more teachers, students, apprentices and volunteers, including people from disadvantaged groups. The question today is whether we are ready to fundamentally increase the budget of Erasmus+ in the upcoming financial period. I am convinced we should do that. Only then will the Erasmus+ programme be more inclusive and become a real investment in our future.  My last point is on the European Student Card, which is in the resolution. It is now up to the Commission to find a feasible solution and to take into account that the International Student Card already exists as a functional tool.  Erasmus+ is our common opportunity – let us invest in our future!

name: Silvia Costa
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, President Juncker today gave a political perspective to Europe, taking advantage of the change of wind that can swell the sails of the Union. But, curiously, he did not recall that the strongest wind comes from the new generations, those who live Europe as their home, reject the walls, are disappointed by Brexit and ask for more Europe, more opportunities to grow, to share, to have a future of European citizens. Thirty years after the launch of the Erasmus program, it was said, nine million young people, and not just young people, have experienced educational and training mobility, the practice of active citizenship, volunteering, sport: but they represent, in fact, only 5% of young Europeans. For this reason, the Committee on Culture and Education has asked for a strong signal in the next multiannual programming, to really put young people at the center of European policies. The S & amp; D group, as already requested by the Italian government - President Kammerevert reminded it the first - will fight to obtain the multiplication of the resources currently allocated, because we take seriously the commitment made, also in the White Paper of President Juncker to have at least 20% of the young people involved. However, we need to make the program more accessible, facilitate the credit recognition system and non-formal competences, invite universities to fully apply learning agreements as a mandatory part of mobility, including on platforms, increase the size of grants and introduce concessions. like the European student card we offer to access facilities and services throughout Europe. We want to restore mobility for high school students and strengthen mobility in vocational training and apprenticeships, making school partnerships more accessible, enriching learning content and strengthening participation in e-Twinning.The educational challenge among immigrants and refugees must be taken up, also by supporting integration projects and educational corridors.For loans to those attending masters, we must review the methods, because they are not working properly.But above all, the program must strengthen the added value of European cooperation, civic education, intercultural understanding as distinctive elements.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! I am definitely in favor of making the Erasmus program more flexible and enlarged in every sense, also in the budgetary sense. This program has worked well. Many students acquired greater competences and got to know the cultures of other European nations. It also needs to be strengthened financially. Instead of establishing new agencies, which President Juncker spoke about in his speech before noon, it is possible to successfully and for the benefit of the future of the young generation and of Europe as a whole to increase the budget for the Erasmus program. I also want to sensitize Commissioner Navracsics to another issue, namely the functioning of the program after Brexit. Great Britain was a very desirable country under the Erasmus program, and the British were visiting European countries during Erasmus. It should be ensured that the exchange on the Erasmus models continues despite Brexit. It is demanded by the European Christian Political Youth - one of the youth organizations operating at the European level. The resolution raises this point, and I fully agree with the arguments of that organization. Let us ensure that Brexit does not halt or annihilate the young generation's exchange between Great Britain and the European Union.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there is no doubt that Erasmus is one of the most successful EU programmes. Together with promoting student and staff mobility, the programme has proven to be a catalyst for encouraging higher education institutions to fully develop their cooperation, to modernise, and to become more international in their outlook. Many studies of the participants themselves have confirmed that an international environment is the best way to learn about different cultures, improve a multi-cultural understanding and knowledge of language, establish international contacts, develop new skills and grow as a person and as a professional. Undoubtedly, Erasmus is a tremendous success, but we should now focus on how further to develop, modernise and simplify the programme and make it more accessible and inclusive. The Commission, together with the Member States, should overcome the existing complexity of the application process and often slow administrative management. Commissioner, while shaping the future of the programme, we need to make sure that the voice of the youth is heard and that their vision on how best to improve the programme is taken on board.

name: Curzio Maltese
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all rightly proud of Erasmus and its history. So, let's try to improve it and, at least, not to make it worse as it sometimes happens. Erasmus cannot become a brand or an ATM to finance anything else. Erasmus is a magnificent project but it is still elitist and we must strive to guarantee more funds and more aid to students from the poorest families. The key is greater accessibility, rightly recalled by the Kammerevert resolution. But you have to be consistent. The loan system does not serve to guarantee greater accessibility: it has failed in this sense in the United States and there is no need to open up to this system, as has been done, albeit with limits, fortunately. So I invite you to vote on our amendment which aims to cancel this path and focus on scholarships, which remain a real key to inclusiveness. And then we must agree on values: from Socrates to Montessori, the task of the school has always been, in European culture, to spread knowledge and train citizens, not to classify young people in organizational charts. In recent years, questionable concepts and categories such as employability have been used very often, the result of an economist ideology that would like to appear modern and instead represents a true regression. Erasmus, school, education are not business courses: we must be clear about this.

name: Patrick O'Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, earlier this month world university rankings placed Oxford and Cambridge as the top two universities in the world. That league table made clear that Britain is Europe’s higher education superpower. Imperial College was also in the global top 10, but the only other European institution there was based in Zurich, outside the EU. Indeed, there was no non-British EU university within the top 20. This is an indication that one of the great challenges for the future of Erasmus+ will be to continue to secure access to UK universities. Without them, the programme will be greatly denuded. I implore the EU to be sensible in accepting the British offer of continued friendship and cooperation and not to allow the Brexit process to turn into a means of trying to punish the British people for their democratic decision. There is willingness in Britain to continue to facilitate the flow of outstanding EU students to our great universities. It would be the height of folly to put that in jeopardy through the adoption of a hostile posture on Brexit.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, on the occasion of the 30 years of the Erasmus program, my colleagues from the Committee on Culture and Education wanted to challenge the Commission on the future of this program. This question was motivated in particular by the Commission’s announcement that this emblematic program will also be used to fund new initiatives, such as the European Solidarity Corps, the relevance of which has yet to be proven. While I share some of my colleagues’s concerns, in particular about threatening the effectiveness of Erasmus by making it cover more and more political objectives, I would nevertheless like to broaden the field of questioning. Indeed, as the newspaper Le Monde recalled in an article of August 29, in fact, despite its relative success, Erasmus still mainly benefits socially advantaged young people. While this social divide is now known, I am also concerned about the tendency of the Commission to see mobility as the only solution to the unemployment problem. This view seems wrong to me. Mobility for mobility does not lead to anything. Still according to the article in Le Monde, only mobility geared towards prestigious institutions, for example, will benefit young people when they enter the professional world. Mobility as an end in itself ultimately only leads to the brain drain and uprooting, which is the source of identity anxiety. It therefore seems to me that the reflection on the future of Erasmus + should focus on these two questions: the development of opportunities for the less privileged deserving students, particularly those in rural and peripheral areas, and finally a necessary reflection on the question. brain drain and the challenge of continuing to make our territories attractive to young Europeans so that mobility does not become the hangman of rurality.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the Erasmus+ programme allows students, teachers and young people to study, work, volunteer, teach and train throughout Europe. Their experiences and the skills they learn help them develop personally, and will ultimately bring added value to the local economy. I am thinking of the many successful projects in my own constituency, including those led by Ballybeen and Kilcooley women’s centres. These include developing and delivering mentoring training programmes, supporting older people, developing innovative ICT training, developing training to raise awareness of domestic abuse among older victims and the DREAM programme, which aims to reinforce integration of migrants into local communities. In Brussels, in London and in Belfast, we should be working to forge a new and positive relationship with the European Union. These negotiations should not preclude programmes such as this, where it is cost—effective to do so. Instead, Brexit should be reviewed as an opportunity to revive and renew ties; to allow those in the education, youth or sports sectors to benefit from cross—border exchange projects as part of a new and special relationship. Whether this be in the form of participation in joint programmes or through new initiatives will ultimately be a matter for talks between the UK Government and Brussels. But the key is a willingness on all sides to negotiate constructively.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - It is generally accepted that Erasmus + is a success story, that it is the most positive European project. We were able to feel this in the summer as we celebrated the 30th anniversary of Erasmus. As a standing rapporteur for the European Parliament for Erasmus +, I am, of course, very pleased with this fact. It could explain at length and broadly the benefits it brings to participants, universities, businesses, local communities and, consequently, to Europe in general. But we also need to look at the matter from another angle. The total budget for education, youth and sport in the European Union remains a relatively small share of the overall multiannual financial framework, at 1.36%. Around 4 million people, or less than 1% of the population, are expected to participate in the various Erasmus + programs during this budget period. But the existing budget is far from covering all the interest. Success rate, which expresses the relationship between applications and accepted or. implemented in some parts of the Erasmus + program is significantly too low, only 26%. It will therefore be necessary to continue to close the gap between the limited budgetary possibilities and the broad potential of the program in the future. But there is only one way to do this: with an increased budget.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Let us ask ourselves what is the necessary condition for implementing the plans presented today by President Juncker? This necessary condition is conscious citizens, citizens who understand Europeanness and respect fundamental values ​​such as equality, freedom and the rule of law. The best carrier of a European identity understood in this way is the Erasmus generation. Therefore, Erasmus + must remain a properly funded, flagship program of the European Union. But even the best design has a margin of improvement. First issue: Erasmus must be accessible to everyone, including people from poorer backgrounds and people with disabilities. I repeat once again - the amount of scholarships must be adjusted to the living costs of the host country. The next issue: the recognition of periods of study abroad and the credit points obtained there must be respected in 100%, this cannot be a problem for students. The third issue: cooperation between national agencies is necessary to, on the one hand, develop high-quality information materials, simplify procedures, and, on the other hand, develop a minimum criteria for objective evaluation. One last thing, Commissioner, which I am asking you to do: Erasmus participants, especially younger ones, often produce material with lasting intellectual value. These are wonderful virtual tourist routes, they are descriptions of their regions, their customs. Let's try to put them on one portal that would not only present these works, but would also exemplify European values ​​and remain a permanent legacy of Erasmus.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Erasmus has really proved to be a very successful program. This is shown by the process that has been followed for 30 years: it has strengthened education and training, it has supported universities, it has supported students, mobility and, I would say, the economy. But further funding is needed. What we see is that there is bleeding. Funds are being withdrawn from Erasmus to support other projects such as the European Solidarity Corps. At the same time, refugees and migrants, who have funds to be funded from other sources, are also included as beneficiaries in Erasmus, thus reducing the final number of beneficiaries. In our view, Erasmus must be adapted to the economic needs of each country, it must be a breath of fresh air for the young people in Greece who are affected by the memoranda and unemployment, the young people in Greece who see their dreams being lost, who are now forced , due to the troika and lenders migrating. That is why there must be an increase in Erasmus funds and additional funds for Greece as well, so that our young people can really cope with these tragic moments they are living through.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, gan aon dabht, is céim chun tosaigh é Clár Erasmus. Léiríonn sé rudaí dearfacha faoin Eoraip. Tá go leor scoláirí tar éis buntáistí an chláir a chur i bhfeidhm ar mhaithe leo féin agus an tsochaí. Ba chóir go mbeadh an deis céanna ag gach scoláire, agus an bhuairt atá ormsa ná go mbeidh Erasmus+ mar chlár a bheidh dírithe orthu siúd leis an airgead. Caithfimid aghaidh a thabhairt ar na dúshláin ollmhóra atá againn ar fud na hEorpa maidir le dífhostaíocht, go háirithe an t-aos óg. Tá neart daoine óga ann atá gan dídean, gan féidearthachtaí agus gan achmhainní ar fáil dóibh chun éileamh ar Chlár Erasmus. Tá dualgas orainne na cláracha ar nós Erasmus+ a leathnú chun na ndaoine óga sin a bhfuil géarghá acu le cos suas maidir le hoideachas. Má táimid dáiríre faoi thacú agus saol níos fearr a chruthú sa todhchaí dár n-aos óg, caithfimid breis infheistíocht a sholáthar. Caithfidh Clár Erasmus a bheith ar fáil do gach duine, thuaidh agus theas in Éirinn; agus táim ag caint ar Bhreatamach sa réimse sin, mar aon le ceantracha gan dabht atá ag fulaingt de dheasca cúrsaí daonna.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! As you mentioned, Erasmus is a program that brings many benefits. This is evidenced by the fact that over 30 years it was attended by 9 million students, pupils, educators and teachers, and in the last 3 years alone, 2 million people from over 33 countries. We also know that the knowledge gained during the exchanges contributed to a fuller understanding and respect for other cultures and their values. Science and closer integration contribute to reducing the risk of radicalization and social exclusion. For the above reasons, I believe that the Erasmus + program is and will be an investment in knowledge, skills and competences, the beneficiaries of which are both individuals, including people with disabilities, and organizations, as well as the entire society, and that is why increasing funds for the development of the program is so important for future generations of Europeans. In order to make the program even more accessible, Member States should endeavor to facilitate the mutual recognition of courses and take into account the ECTS credits obtained during exchanges. I believe that only this can make the full use of the programme's potential and contribute to the achievement of the strategic framework of European cooperation in education.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Erasmus is one of the Union’s greatest success stories, not just in terms of employability and academic development, but also because it has helped to create a generation of proud, open-minded and resilient Europeans, including young British people. We must build on this success to widen access and ensure that more young people can benefit from this opportunity, in particular those in vocational training, vulnerable young people, people outside of formal education, migrants and people with disabilities. In fact, the very kind of marginalised young people that I was working with before I came into politics.  For this to be successful, we need political will and money. I therefore support the Erasmusx10 Campaign to increase the programme budget 10 times in the next financial period. I also want to reiterate that the UK must maintain its access to the programme, and I call for this to be a priority in the Brexit negotiations. British youth voted overwhelmingly to remain in the EU, and it is their future that is hugely at risk with the current negotiations.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Erasmus is the most successful European initiative. Thanks to this, our young people are studying and working in a Europe without borders. They find new opportunities and open their horizons. Within three decades, millions of citizens participated in these programs. Most of them, rest assured, would have neither the opportunity nor the financial means to study abroad without Erasmus. By supporting such policies, we are uniting our peoples and building Europe together. We must, however, give even more opportunities to the younger generation. We must highlight any initiative that supports employment, schools, universities and sport. The Erasmus program must be made available to more of our fellow citizens, to more organizations, to sports federations, for example, which fail to meet basic needs for the development and mobility of national teams. In my country, since 2014, about 12,000 people have participated in programs worth a total of 23 million euros. Each of these euros, rest assured, will have multiple benefits for both Greece and Europe as a whole. The Erasmus program is a real investment for our young people. We must all support it. We owe it to the new generation.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erasmus is undoubtedly the best known and most appreciated program by European citizens and, we must say, also the most effective. Last June we celebrated the thirtieth year of activity, which allowed more than nine million young people to enrich not only their study and professional experience, but to have a real life experience, to grow humanly, as only it can allow the meeting and comparison with new people, with their traditions, customs and culture. Because nothing like the tangible experience of the European human, cultural and spiritual heritage, of what unites us and what differentiates us, can break down prejudices and mistrust and contribute to European identity. It is time now to take stock and to chart the future of Erasmus + so that possibly all young Europeans, and not just a small part, can access it. In fact, in the period 2014-2020, less than 1% of European citizens will benefit from it. This is another reason why my country has proposed multiplying the Erasmus + budget by ten. To some it may seem unrealistic but it is important to grasp the political point of the proposal, that is to satisfy the countless requests not accepted and to reach a truly wider audience of young people, therefore beyond those enrolled at the university, who are the main users. So I make my own the words of President Juncker: "Every single euro we invest in Erasmus + is an investment in the future: the future of young people and the future of our European ideal."

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in my opinion, the Erasmus program has done more for the European Union than any Treaty that has been signed. We should be proud, because in the previous legislature, when the Union budget was reduced, we managed from this Parliament to increase the budget for Erasmus by 40%. The feeling of belonging to the European Union has been consolidated among those young people who have been able to enjoy this experience, for many of them the best of their lives. We must also take into account the future possibilities that it opens up to our young people. The recent crisis has shown that those with international experience and more knowledge of languages ​​were able to find employment more easily. However, not everything is positive. Only 5% of our young people enjoy the program. The funds they receive are not enough, so it is out of the reach of the less well off. I very much appreciate the inclusion of young people in vocational training, but it is essential to continue increasing resources so that all young people have the same opportunities.
