name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I think Erasmus + is the best investment Europe has made in young people: today, yesterday and, we trust, even more tomorrow. These thirty years of investment in human capital have given Europe a generation that is much more open-minded, more European, more aware of its own strengths and limitations, and it was also a key point of the young people who wanted to stay from England within the European Union, and precisely because of the Erasmus theme. I think there are also other very important programs that need to be financed more and more, among which we have Erasmus for young entrepreneurs: few of the young people know about this opportunity. Among others we have the European Voluntary Service, but above all the Youth Guarantee initiative. Here, in this I think that it is necessary to reduce the current level of unemployment, giving young people not only the opportunity to study abroad but to have the economic skills to be able to open a business and to be truly entrepreneurs of their own. themselves. I think that our future is in the hands of young people and today we are here to create their future and give them the possibilities that, perhaps, we did not have today.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, I listened with interest to your speech and I basically agree with everything. I am from the Czech Republic, where support for European integration has been declining recently. It is the Erasmus program that is a huge, visible, successful project that clearly and quickly explains what Europe is bringing, for example, to young people. The visibility of this program is absolutely extraordinary, in addition to being successful. Colleagues talked about some things that should be improved in the program in the future. First, it's money. I also agree that 5% of young people are small, that we should invest much more in this project in the future and expand young people's circles. Secondly, I think that the program should not be intended mainly for university students. Let's do everything we can to ensure that other young people make more real use of this program - apprentices, high school students, mostly university students. Thirdly, let us do more so that not only young people from the so-called new Member States travel to the 'old Member States', but also to make it more attractive for young people from Western Europe to study in Central Europe and in the new Member States. bilateral. As Mr Juncker said today, Europe has two lungs. And the last thing is the practical problems that have been mentioned here. I know students who have rejected Erasmus because of such practical problems that they simply could not complete their basic studies. So practical problems also need to be solved.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the time. No speaker seems to have touched on the fact that Switzerland has been suspended from the Erasmus programme. It is an interesting question – has this really made any difference to Switzerland, the Swiss people, or even to Swiss universities? It would seem not, because the top university in Switzerland rates higher than any university in the EU, outside of the UK. My colleague, Patrick O’Flynn, made a very important point which the colleagues were supremely disinterested in, which is that EU universities outside the UK simply do not rate very highly in world terms. UK universities, oddly enough, do. But I am not making a patriotic point. The point I am making for the colleagues to consider, particularly for the Commissioner, is that, as we have heard, the Erasmus programme primarily has a political motivation. It would be better for the young people of Europe if you drop some of this political motivation and concentrated on an educational function.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Erasmus program, 30 years after its creation, is today a worldwide reference in terms of the internationalization of education and has become one of the black beasts of the detractors of the European project because it is one of the integrating tools of the Union's greatest success, moreover, as we heard here from your colleague. The program has already benefited 9 million young Europeans. However, this figure - although impressive - represents less than 5% of young Europeans. Many are not covered due to factors and socio-economic factors, funding limitations, inequalities between and within Member States, as well as the complexity of application processes and the lack of consistency in the recognition of the European credit transfer system acquired during the period of application. mobility. It is therefore important that, in view of the negotiations for the next multiannual financial framework, the new Erasmus + program, to be introduced after 2020, should be able to have the additional funds necessary to become more accessible, comprehensive and inclusive, once and for all losing its fame of elitist. Dear colleagues, we cannot and must not forget that Erasmus + is the biggest investment that Europe can make in itself.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank you for the debate. I think it was a really fruitful debate, and while we are drawing our conclusions from this debate and planning the future of Erasmus+, I think we can easily agree that Erasmus is one of the biggest successes of European integration. However, this must not make me complacent, and we always have to seek new ways of broadening and widening the social appeal, the geographical appeal and also the age appeal of Erasmus+.  A lot of people raised the need for a special programme for secondary schools, for instance, or to include younger people – not only students but also students from secondary schools – in Erasmus+ in the future. We just heard a lot of interventions on the need to make Erasmus+ more socially sensitive, and I totally agree with your observations and your interventions. Of course, it is mostly a question of funding. When we are preparing our positions for the next MFF negotiations we have to bear in mind that it is not only spending money for a special purpose, but it is an investment in the future. So this is the moment when we can fund the future of Europe and the future of the next generations.  I absolutely agree with the opinion that Erasmus+ is not an employment policy instrument. It is a complex way of developing education, culture, sport, youth policy, and also employment policy and the future of the world of labour and the intercultural co-existence of future societies. That is why I think accessibility is a crucial issue for Erasmus+ in the future. However, we are not without success at the moment. More than 35 000 students from disadvantaged backgrounds have already benefited from Erasmus+, and additional funding is foreseen. I know there is not enough. That is why I was very happy to hear your encouragement to go forward in this way and to make Erasmus+ more socially sensitive. Let me address some concerns regarding the European Solidarity Corps. For me, and I hope for you too, the European Solidarity Corps is a great opportunity to show our solidarity with the young people of Europe. The first deployment proved this hypothesis. In Norcia and Spoleto, where I was two weeks ago, I saw great evidence of European solidarity. It is based on volunteering. That is why the first phase of the existence of the European Solidarity Corps can be funded by Erasmus+ by volunteering sources, because it is the same activity. These funds came from Erasmus+. It has so far covered European Voluntary Service activities and now it covers European Solidarity Corps activities. In the future, the European Solidarity Corps is going to have its own separate budget, with fresh money. Up to 25% of the new budget will be fresh money and it will be a separate budget, funding those activities which have volunteers – not only young volunteers but also people who are seeking better opportunities on the labour market –with apprenticeships and, in the future, with better job offers, I hope. That is why I think we have to support the European Solidarity Corps’ activities in the future as well, because it simply does not endanger the existence of Erasmus+ and the funding of Erasmus+. Last, but not least, the European Student eCard. We are now working to put together three separate Erasmus+ funded projects: the European Student Card, the Erasmus Without Paper (EWP) and Emrex. We are trying to identify the synergies of these three projects and develop more comprehensive projects which make Erasmus+ students’ lives easier, bringing together the results of those three projects and developing a European Student Card in the future which can embrace all the achievements of these three projects. Once again, thank you for your contributions and let us continue this dialogue in the Committee on Culture and Education in the future.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received a motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, 14 September 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - Erasmus is undoubtedly one of the most successful mobility programs in the EU, with more than 3 million students studying abroad so far, and a total of 9 million young Europeans have had the opportunity to gain experience abroad. The European Parliament remains committed to the program so that as many young people as possible can take part in it and, in addition to knowledge, enrich themselves with cultural experiences, experiences, new skills and abilities abroad. The program has undoubtedly had a positive impact not only on the professional and personal lives of young people in Europe but also in neighboring and candidate countries. The results obtained so far show that almost 90% of all participants in vocational training in the Erasmus program say that their employment has increased as a result of the experience. However, in view of the still high unemployment, the Erasmus + program should strongly support actions to achieve better employment opportunities. It should be emphasized that in the next budget period (2020-2027) it is necessary to increase the budget of the program, additional resources will need to be added in order to provide as many young people, students and teachers as possible with the opportunity to participate in the program.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Being a part of the Erasmus + program is much more than just studying abroad. Namely, it is an experience that opens eyes to new opportunities, friendships, knowledge and values. Launched in 1987 as a voluntary collaboration of 11 European countries, the program has today developed into a single global network. 2017 marks the thirtieth anniversary of this program, and in the last 30 years the program has undergone a thorough transformation and left its mark on the private and professional lives of about 9,000,000 students, trainees, volunteers, teachers, staff, educators and youth workers. The Erasmus + program is still available only to a very limited number of European citizens, but a further budget increase is expected by 2020. This ungrateful situation creates a feeling of dissatisfaction because the program does not meet the high expectations of EU citizens. The Commission will adopt the necessary financial and budgetary reforms to ensure that this EU flagship program achieves the ambitious goals of improving the conditions for anyone who decides to join the program. I believe that the Resolution on the Future of Erasmus + helps EU citizens to find their place in our societies and to develop a sense of European identity - an identity that complements our national, regional and local identities. I see this Resolution as a step forward in improving the functioning of the program in order to further impact the daily lives of EU citizens, especially young people.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is, for joint discussion, - the report by Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the negotiations relating to the modernization of the trade pillar of the EU-Chile Association Agreement ((2017/2057 (INI)) ((A8-0267 / 2017)); - the recommendation by Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández, on behalf of the Trade Committee international, concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Chile on trade in organic products ((2016/0383 (NLE)) (A8-0257 / 2017)); - the Recommendation by Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its States mbri, to the Third Additional Protocol to the Agreement establishing an association between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Chile, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Union European Union ((2017/0042 (NLE) (A8-0277 / 2017)).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández
text: speaker. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the shadow rapporteurs for their contributions and their willingness to dialogue, which have led to a very good report. I also congratulate the European External Action Service and the Commission, led by Commissioner Malmström, for their excellent work in strengthening relations between the European Union and Latin America and, particularly, with Chile, a stable and reliable partner of the Union and a necessary partner in the achievement of a fairer global governance. By the way, I would like to take the opportunity to greet the ambassador of the Republic of Chile to the European Union, who has had the pleasure and interest of being here with us today. In relation to the Agreement on the bilateral trade of organic / ecological products, I want to emphasize that it is the first that the European Union signs of this nature with the interest of contributing to the development and expansion of organic agriculture. It is based on a strict procedure of mutual recognition, certification with high guarantees of control and safeguards, providing for the creation of a Joint Committee to supervise its application, as well as a unilateral suspension clause in case of non-compliance. Chile recognizes all certified European products, but the European Union excludes Chilean animal and feed products, as well as aquatic crops that lack regulation. We support this Agreement, Commissioner, but I ask you to commit to properly informing this Parliament of its implementation, and I also ask you to carry out an evaluation before the end of the implementation period and, if necessary, every three years thereafter. Regarding Croatia's accession to the current Association Agreement, I just want to point out that it responds to the ordinary adaptation procedure after a new accession, following the World Trade Organization procedure. Finally, I will refer to the most relevant report, the future modernization of the Association Agreement with Chile. It is true that the current Agreement has worked very well since its entry into force in 2003. However, its modernization is necessary because it is outdated, because it does not respond to the new demands of trade policy and because both parties have concluded more ambitious agreements with third countries. Without a doubt, the European Union-Chile trade relations framework cannot be left behind. The modernization of the Chile Agreement is also a great opportunity to implement a more ambitious trade policy favorable to sustainable development. We share the same principles and values. And in this report - which, by the way, has been approved by a very large majority in the Committee on International Trade, the largest ever achieved in a trade agreement in this legislature - what are the recommendations that this Parliament makes? First, we require more transparency and parliamentary and civil society participation, and we demand the immediate publication of the negotiating mandate as soon as it takes place. We call for ambitious improvements to market access, but protecting sensitive agricultural and industrial products and prioritizing the defense and well-being of people. We request the right and ability of the parties to regulate in favor of the general interest, including, of course, public services, and that this be explicitly and unequivocally ensured throughout the Agreement. We demand a modern investment policy, which must consider both the protection and the obligations of investors; preserve the right of governments to regulate; avoid unfounded litigation and, of course, replace the private arbitration system with a public, transparent and guarantee system that seeks the commitment of the parties to give priority to recourse to the competent courts while progressing in the creation of the multilateral investment court . And, of course, we demand an ambitious chapter of sustainable development with binding, enforceable provisions, subject to dispute resolution mechanisms and that considers the imposition of sanctions while promoting corporate social responsibility.We want firm commitments in the fight against tax evasion, against corruption and, of course, we ask for a specific chapter on SMEs and on something that I know you are firmly committed to, as is Chile, which is that, forFinally, the European Union will sign a trade agreement with a specific gender chapter.Therefore, I ask all the Members of this Parliament to support this report in a majority tomorrow and I ask the Commission and the Council to take these recommendations into account because they are good, they are necessary and because, furthermore, this Parliament will be the one who has to say itslast word.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: miembro de la Comisión. – Señor presidente, quiero empezar por agradecer a la ponente, Inmaculada Rodríguez Piñero, así como a todos los otros ponentes de los otros grupos, por su trabajo, muy ambicioso, sobre estos tres informes que afectan a nuestras relaciones comerciales con Chile. Chile, together with Mexico, is our longest standing preferential partner in Latin America. It is a key ally in multilateral fora. We have had an association agreement in place since 2003. It has worked well and has allowed for substantial increase in our bilateral trade, but now that it is 2017, it is more than correct that we address what has happened during these years and that we modernise the agreement. This is why the Trade for All communication identified Chile as one of the countries with which we should aim to upgrade our trade relations. This initiative is framed by our strategy to promote openness, based on values and standards, and to build bridges with partners across the world – and not walls. We have here an opportunity to conclude an agreement of the highest calibre on all issues, including on matters reflecting shared societal values, trade and sustainable development, SMEs, anti—corruption and – as the rapporteur pointed out – for the first time in an EU agreement provisions on trade and gender, where Chile has done a lot of work already. This modernised agreement should allow the development of a more modern and effective working method and contribute to the creation and enhancement of the role of contact networks and people—to—people links between us and Chile. We have done our part in the Commission. You have done your part here in Parliament. In May, together with the High Representative, we adopted in the Commission a recommendation to start negotiating and recommended directives to modernise the agreement. These proposed texts are now under discussion in the Council, and on our side we are ready to start negotiations a soon as we receive the authorisation and the negotiating directives from the Council. In this context, we very much welcome your resolution. It is a highly valuable contribution and will give us a steer during the following negotiations. Regarding the Croatian Accession Protocol, this is another example of excellent cooperation and our good relations with Chile. Chile is one of the few trading partners that applied unilaterally the provisions and benefits of the Association Agreement to Croatia without waiting for the formal adoption of the Protocol. We are very grateful for Chile’s helpful attitude in this process and we look forward to receiving Parliament’s consent on the Accession Protocol. Finally, regarding the agreement on trade in organic products, by signing this agreement the European Union and Chile mutually recognise the equivalence of our respective organic production rules and control system in order to ensure a high level of respect for the principles of organic production. This agreement is broad in scope and will allow for products produced and controlled according to EU rules to be directly placed in the Chilean market and vice—versa. I would again like to thank the rapporteur and the Committee on International Trade for the excellent work they have done on all three of these files and particularly for the resolution on the modernisation of the agreement. It captures Parliament’s concerns well and we will carefully bear these in mind during the negotiation process.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the work of my colleague Inmaculada. I think she has done an excellent job and it is only fair to acknowledge it today in this debate. I want to convey the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture specifically on the Recommendation of the proposed Decision regarding the Agreement on trade in organic / organic products - which was approved by the majority in the Committee on Agriculture, where we are always somewhat more protectionist with our products, but that here gave majority support and I want to transfer it like that. It is an Agreement that, in addition, we see positively, because we are talking about ecological standards and they are the standards that we consider superior. Therefore, that this is specifically reflected in the first agreement of its kind signed by the European Union, I think it is a good thing and that is why it has been very positive in the Committee on Agriculture. The only thing that we would also have liked in the committee is that the Organic Agriculture Regulation, on which we have been working for three and a half years and which is still in the trilogue negotiations, would have also been ready now, but it has not been possible. That has nothing to do with the Agreement. And to say that we liked the incorporation of those amendments that ask for an initial evaluation to be carried out after the first two years of their application. They are good sensitivities for European agricultural productions. I believe that it will be a good agreement and I transfer this opinion of the Committee on Agriculture in favor of finally being approved tomorrow.

name: Gabriel Mato
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, you know very well that I am a supporter of trade agreements in general, but I am even more so that the sacrifices that these agreements always entail are shared fairly between the different sectors. You have heard me say many times that, in these agreements, the bill is usually paid by the agricultural sector. And so it usually is. In any case, I welcome the modernization of the trade pillar of this agreement, which has led to significant growth in bilateral trade. We have a privileged commercial relationship with Chile and that is globally very positive, and it should continue to be that way. Regarding the Agreement on trade in organic / organic products, I still have some doubts that our farmers have expressed. The European Union will recognize as equivalent products - and, on this occasion, I am not going to mention the banana as I usually do in defense of the Canarian banana - that are produced under different conditions. I am not going to get into environmental conditions, not even social standards, but I am concerned about the possible use of substances whose use is not allowed in the European Union. In any case, I want to congratulate the rapporteur. She has made an enormous effort to reach a majority agreement - I believe almost unanimous - and that is very positive. And I therefore want to show our strong support for these agreements and trust, above all, in something in which I know the Commissioner fully trusts: that the safeguards that are put in place are really effective.

name: Francisco Assis
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, in the excellent speech that Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker made this morning to this Parliament, it was not by chance that he made an initial reference to the importance of international trade and did so for reasons that we cannot fail to to share. The European Union can and must be a key regulator of the ongoing globalization process. We defend a European Union open to the world and not a European Union closed in old protectionisms, which are economically negative and politically unacceptable. This agreement with Chile is of the utmost importance. Chile is a partner and is a friend of the European Union. We have every reason to seek to encourage relations with the countries of Latin America. We share values, principles, references, models of political, economic and social organization with most countries in Latin America. We have very close relations with Chile, with whom we share, in a very evident way, these values, these principles and these models and, perhaps, for this reason, it was easier in this case to move towards the modernization of this trade agreement, integrating news as important as some that have already been mentioned here. I allow myself to highlight the one that has precisely to do with the issue of gender, which, for the first time, is now materialized in a commercial agreement. So it goes in the right direction. It is clear that trade agreements require commitments. A trade agreement, in essence, if it is well negotiated, is won, but there are always some gains and some losses. I believe that the ongoing process allows foreseeing a very favorable final resolution for the European Union. In conclusion, I would naturally like to welcome the rapporteur of this opinion or this report, this resolution, because it seems to me that, once again, she revealed with her intelligence and her commitment, her great dedication, what I know is a cause your which is precisely to promote relations with Latin America, in general, in this case we are talking about Chile, I hope that soon we can also modernize the agreement with Mexico and we can guarantee the implementation of a trade agreement with the Mercosur countries.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, in these times of increasing protectionism, the European Union should, now more than ever, persevere in its mission to promote a free trade agenda with like-minded partners, and I can think of few better examples than Chile. Chile and the European Union share many common values, including in the field of trade. Our shared vision has allowed both parties to take full advantage of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Chile. Since the Agreement entered into force in 2003, our trade has more than doubled. There is no doubt that the Association Agreement has brought us many opportunities and benefits for our companies and citizens, but this Agreement is now obsolete and it is now that we have to reflect today's reality. There are several elements of our trade that we can and must improve. It is very important to progress in the area of ​​services, for example, but also in others such as non-tariff barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary standards, access to public procurement, agricultural products and digital commerce. We should also introduce new individual chapters dedicated to topics important to our current trade. Specifically, chapters related to investment, intellectual property rights, energy and SMEs. It is time to move forward in our relations with Chile. This report is a clear vote of confidence to the process of modernization of the Agreement by this house and I want to congratulate the rapporteur for her work. And I also hope that the Council will approve the mandate to negotiate modernization as soon as possible and to start negotiations this year.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to begin this speech by remembering the President of Chile, Salvador Allende, whose assassination at the hands of the fascist coup d'état of Pinochet was the anniversary of a few days ago. I think it is important to remember this, at a time when the attempts to destabilize progressive experiences in Latin America are far from having ceased. I sincerely want to thank the rapporteur for these reports, the Hon. Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández, because I believe it is important to recognize the elements of dialogue, efforts and listening skills in politics. So, I sincerely thank you, because I believe you have done an important job and, in particular, I thank you because I believe that, having included a chapter on gender for the first time in a resolution on a trade agreement, is really an element of novelty that I will not fail to underline in my report on the theme "gender and commercial exchanges", which is currently under discussion between the INTA and FEMM commissions. The reason why we will abstain on this report: I think that in this report there are important chapters on sustainable development, on social and environmental standards and on the fact that the possibility of introducing sanctions is finally considered if the standards are not respected . I believe that the sanction mechanism is a real step forward and I hope that the Commission will take these recommendations into consideration. But there is a red line for us, which is called the "public judicial system for investments", which we consider only a small modification of the old ISDS. For us this is a red line because it is about allowing large investors to be able to decide above our constitutions and we will not support agreements that contain, in fact, these mechanisms such as the public judicial system for investments from CETA in then.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, first of all, I want to say to Ms Forenza that of course we cannot wait for her report on gender and trade. I am really looking forward to it. I am going to focus on just one aspect of the EU-Chile trade arrangements. Here I have just part of the existing EU-Chile Trade Agreement. This runs over 1 400 pages of densely written text. In all that text there is no clause – none – that requires the so-called free movement of people. It is also highly unlikely that the modernised Chile trade agreement which we are discussing now will have a free movement of people clause.  Further, the European Union has over 100 trade agreements. I make it 141, actually. Only two of those agreements – the EFTA and the EEA agreements – have a requirement for free movement of people.  Nevertheless, in the context of Brexit, so much of the media tells us that free movement is a precondition for any country having a free trade agreement with the EU, and this is simply untrue. Fake news is something that the EU crusades against. Free movement: the manipulation and denial of the facts concerning free movement of people in EU trade agreements, against the clear evidence, is fake news personified. Perhaps the Commissioner will join me in correcting this fundamental misunderstanding.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Rodríguez Piñero, for the excellent work she has done. I would like to note with satisfaction, as Mr. Assis has done, the fact that this morning the President of the Commission, in his State of the Union address, expressed his desire to modernize, update and update the Association Agreements with Mexico and Chile and to conclude the Agreement with Mercosur on the terms set. I know that behind this statement by President Juncker is the committed, tenacious and effective work of Commissioner Malmström. I have the honor of being the speaker of the Agreement on Political Association, Economic Agreement and Cooperation with Chile, which is in force, and here Mr. Mato recalled the excellent results that this Agreement has produced. Now it is a matter of updating it, modernizing it and taking out all the potential that it entails. For this reason, Mr. President, you will always find support in our political group for this country, small perhaps in its size, but great in our hearts and in our affections.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I expressly congratulate the rapporteur on the fact that her report describes many modern requirements for a trade agreement. I particularly support the requirement on the Commission to define binding investor obligations in this agreement, as well as instruments for the binding implementation of the sustainability chapter, which is so important for people here and there. However, I would like to reiterate that a dispute with an investor must be resolved through due legal process. Courts decide on the basis of a constitution, while investment tribunals only use a trade agreement as a basis. My group cannot agree to agreements with special courts for investors. With a view to President Juncker's speech today, Mrs Malmström, I look forward to the publication of the draft negotiating mandate, which will certainly be followed by further discussions. We would have liked to have approved the agreement on trade in organic products if it had described a common high standard of what a reliable organic product is. Unfortunately, only the mutual recognition of the respective standards was decided. This threatens to endanger producers and consumers and can further undermine citizens' trust in EU trade policy.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all, thank you also to the rapporteur for her excellent report. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and Latin America are united by diverse and deep ties and also by common values. They are committed to open trade and global governance, and Chile is an example of all this. The Association Agreement with this country has allowed the development of an important commercial relationship that has resulted in a 100% increase in bilateral trade. Its future dynamism now also depends on the modernization of the Agreement, which dates, as I said before, fifteen years ago. I want to underline that, in many countries of the European Union, the export sector has been key to getting out of the crisis. Now, with a declining demographic, very limited levels of public spending and weak domestic demand, we Europeans need to continue turning to the outside, and for this I congratulate you, Commissioner, for this work of continuing to weave a commercial network more and more wide. Now we have negotiations with Mercosur, also with Mexico, and what I hope is that, as soon as the Council approves the negotiating mandate that you have prepared in the Commission, the negotiations can begin as soon as possible. Chile is an important country, it is a key country, with a very dynamic economy and, above all, a member of that increasingly dynamic Pacific Alliance.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, I am a strong supporter and supporter of trade agreements, and I am very pleased that even this example of a trade agreement with Chile clearly shows how beneficial these agreements, as colleagues have said, have doubled trade in the existence of this agreement.Before the holidays, we evaluated the trade agreement with South Korea here, which also led to a several-fold increase in mutual trade.This means that it can be made clear that this is a good policy direction, and I am glad that Mr Juncker paid great attention this morning to trade agreements with third countries, with our partner countries.Chile is clearly our important partner in Latin America, and I look forward to the new agreement coming into force quickly, and in a few years we will evaluate how beneficial the new version of trade agreements with Chile has been and strengthened economic ties as well asother areas, such as trade in organic products.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the Chilean people are a likeable people and they have suffered a lot. I think he needs our support. However, the modernization of the trade agreement, although it raises interesting issues such as the issue of gender equality, has in fact been tainted by the TTIP and CETA agreements and brings back issues that have been much debated and objected to: first, it abolishes essentially the judicial system of the Member States and restores this well-known system of private arbitration, which is unacceptable; secondly, it is a mixed agreement which must also be ratified by the Member States. I hope that the trick done with CETA will not be repeated, that is, that it will be applied temporarily until it is ratified by all the Member States. In addition, there is a lack of transparency in the negotiations. There is no protection of public goods and, finally, this agreement follows the classic model: it strengthens the industrialized countries to the detriment of the European countries which are heavily dependent on agriculture.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you and the honourable Members for this debate. Several of you referred to the fact that President Juncker underlined today the importance of concluding trade agreements with friends and allies: countries with whom we share values, where we share a belief in the importance of the multilateral system, the belief that trade agreement is a good way to open new possibilities, and that you can have win—win agreements and  sustainable, good, fair trade agreements to the benefit of companies, consumers and citizens. Chile is such a partner, but it is important, as you have all said, to update the old agreement because it has become, obviously, a bit obsolete with the changes that have occurred in the last 14 years. As soon as we get the mandate (I hope that will be quite soon), we will start negotiating. I am confident that this will go quite smoothly with Chile. We did a lot of very thorough preparation before we started, so we have a good basis for this. We have taken good note of your recommendations and your viewpoints in the resolution, and I will make sure that you are fully informed once we start the negotiations. I also take note of your wish to be regularly informed or to have some sort of evaluation process of the organic products.  I will pass this wish to my friend and colleague Phil Hogan and see what can be done in this regard. To the Earl of Dartmouth, who has just left the room, I would like to say that, yes, trade agreements are complex – you might find out about their complexity very soon – but also tell you that, no, there is no need to have freedom of movement in a trade agreement: that is between the partners. It is, however, a requirement if you want to have access to the internal market of the European Union, but I think that this is a debate that is slightly outside this agenda. Thank you very much for your support. I look forward to regularly informing you about how we develop in our Chile trade relations.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández
text: speaker. - Mr President, I would like to end by reiterating my thanks to all the shadow rapporteurs. My opening words and your words show that, indeed, we have had that will, that capacity for dialogue and consensus. I also want to thank all the other Members who are here participating in this debate and, of course, the Commissioner. I have full confidence in the working capacity of your Commission, in yours personally and in your dedication, and I believe that we will be able to achieve that agreement that we have been able - I insist - to reach a consensus in this report, widely supported by all groups politicians. I think we have come a long way. We have all agreed on what we want in the sustainable development chapter. I think we have work to do to agree on what investment policy should be. But I do not want to end without again appealing to the opportunity that this Agreement represents. I was just looking at the guest rostrum and, seeing here the representative of the Republic of Chile participating in this debate, shows the ties, interest and desire to modernize this Agreement. Because we want more than just deepen our business relationships, we want to deepen our role as policy makers to have fairer global governance. Citizens expect from their politicians that we are capable of responding to their daily problems, and our obligation is to live up to what they ask of us. And I think that together we will be at that height. So thank you very much, and I reiterate my gratitude and my willingness to continue working as we have done so far.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, 14 September 2017.
